data: Cambodia's two-party opposition asked the Asian Development Bank Monday to stop providing loan to the incumbent government, which it call illegal. Negotiations to form the next government have become deadlocked, and opposition party leader Prince Norodom Ranariddh and Sam Rainsy are out of the country following threat of arrest from strongman Hun Sen. Hun Sen complained Monday that the opposition wa trying to make it members' return an international issue. Hun Sen's ruling party narrowly won a majority in election in July, but the opposition claiming widespread intimidation and fraud ha denied Hun Sen the two-thirds vote in parliament required to approve the next government. Meanwhile, it say, the old government is holding power illegally. Ranariddh and Sam Rainsy renewed their international lobbying campaign against the old government Monday in a letter to ADB President Mitsuo Sato calling for the bank to stop lending money to it. We respectfully advise the Asian Development Bank not to provide any new loan to the current regime in Cambodia, the two party leader wrote. At best the current regime could be considered a caretaker government a it ha not been approved by the National Assembly. After a meeting between Hun Sen and the new French ambassador to Cambodia, Hun Sen aide Prak Sokhonn said the Cambodian leader had repeated call for the opposition to return, but expressed concern that the international community may be asked for security guarantee. There have been report that there is an attempt to internationalize the return of those member of parliament on the excuse of security problem, Prak Sokhonn said. Some (opposition politician) have wanted the United Nations to help guarantee a safe return for them. The UN. secretary-general's representative office in Phnom Penh provided monitor to opposition politician after they returned to Cambodia to participate in the July election. The monitoring ended Sept. 30. Our office ha not received any official request for that operation to be started up again, UN. diplomat Jonathan Prentice said Monday in reaction to Prak Sokhonn's statement. The opposition ha insisted that any further talk on the next government must take place outside the country, but the ruling party ha rejected allegation of intimidation and recently guaranteed opposition members' safety inside the country. Diplomatic effort to revive the stalled talk appeared to bear fruit Monday a Japanese Foreign Affairs Secretary of State Nobutaka Machimura said King Norodom Sihanouk ha called on Ranariddh and Sam Rainsy to return to Cambodia. Less than two week after abandoning hope that he could influence the party to reach a compromise, Sihanouk is now strongly interested in presiding over a summit meeting of the three party leader in Cambodia, Machimura said. Cambodian politician expressed hope Monday that a new partnership between the party of strongman Hun Sen and his rival, Prince Norodom Ranariddh, in a coalition government would not end in more violence. Hun Sen and Ranariddh, co-prime minister in a coalition formed in 1993 after a landmark U.N.-sponsored election, often clashed over power-sharing and the integration of guerrilla fighter from the crumbling Khmer Rouge. Their argument turned bloody last year when Hun Sen ousted Ranariddh in a coup. The prince fled Cambodia and did not return until a few month before election in July. Hun Sen's Cambodian People's Party narrowly won the poll, but a strong second-place finish by Ranariddh's FUNCINPEC gave the royalist party leverage in post-election negotiation. After a three-month impasse, they agreed last week to a coalition deal that will make Hun Sen sole prime minister and Ranariddh president of the National Assembly. This will not be a repetition of 1993 because there will not be two prime minister, said Hun Sen aide Prak Sokhon, who attended last week's summit. When we had two prime minister, everything moved very slowly and decision were made more politically than technically. Ranariddh said Saturday that the two party agreed to keep the ministry of interior and defense under co-ministers. Senior FUNCINPEC official Ahmad Yahya revealed Monday that it wa also agreed that the CPP would control the foreign affair and finance portfolio. FUNCINPEC will take justice and information. The party are to form working group this week to divide remaining government post and draft a constitutional amendment to form a new Senate. Hun Sen and Ranariddh are scheduled to meet Nov. 23 two day before parliament reopens to review the result of the working group and give their final approval, Ahmad Yahya said. Their ability to repair their relationship and work together will be the key to a stable coalition. I consider this a remarriage, Ahmad Yahya said. They have to be careful with the way they work and what they say. They will have to compromise to achieve result. Ranariddh's ally, Sam Rainsy, whose party placed a distant third in the election, wa left out of last week's deal. Sam Rainsy, a virulent critic of Hun Sen, and his party's 14 other member of parliament have remained outside Cambodia since September amid fear for their security. In a letter to King Norodom Sihanouk released Monday, Sam Rainsy complained that Hun Sen had not responded to his query on security, making it unsafe for his people to return for the reconvening of parliament. Sam Rainsy said he had been told by Ranariddh that his party and former Khmer Rouge guerrilla had been implicated by Hun Sen in a rocket attack on the Sept. 24 opening of parliament. Authorities have called it an assassination attempt on Hun Sen. A police general investigating the attack said Monday that likely suspect have been identified, but he would not reveal name or their political affiliation. Cambodia's ruling party responded Tuesday to criticism of it leader in the US. Congress with a lengthy defense of strongman Hun Sen's human right record. The Cambodian People's Party criticized a non-binding resolution passed earlier this month by the US. House of Representatives calling for an investigation into violation of international humanitarian law allegedly committed by Hun Sen. Events mentioned in the resolution include Hun Sen's coup last year against his co-prime minister, Prince Norodom Ranariddh, and his violent crackdown in September against anti-government demonstration. A copy of the resolution ha since been submitted to the US. Senate Committee on Foreign Relations. The CPP would like to launch an appeal to US. senator to wisely and realistically consider this draft resolution and give justice to the CPP, Hun Sen and the Cambodian people by not approving it, the party said in a statement. It defended Hun Sen's ouster of Ranariddh a a proper response to the prince's attempt at the time to negotiate the defection of senior Khmer Rouge rebel. It also repeated claim that the prince's party had moved rebel soldier into Phnom Penh, a contention that remains unproved. The killing of nearly 100 of Ranariddh's supporter documented by UN. human right worker in the aftermath of the coup were dismissed by the CPP a mostly fabrication meant to distort the political situation. Ranariddh and his core supporter did not return to Cambodia until a few month before an election in July this year that the ruling party narrowly won. Ranariddh and his opposition ally, Sam Rainsy, refused to accept the election result, alleging widespread intimidation and fraud by the CPP. When their claim were dismissed by a Hun Sen-friendly court, they rallied their supporter into the street of Phnom Penh. After two week of tolerating the demonstration, Hun Sen ordered a violent crackdown that resulted in the death of at least four protester. UN. human right worker later discovered more than 20 body many bearing sign of torture in and around the capital, prompting speculation that the death toll could be much higher. The ruling party supported the police action in it statement, noting that public property wa damaged by protester and that grenade were thrown at Hun Sen's home after Sam Rainsy suggested in a speech that the US. government should fire cruise missile at Hun Sen. The opposition claim the grenade attack wa staged a an excuse to begin the crackdown. The leader of illegal demonstration are the one who must bear responsibility for the consequence deriving from the protest, the CPP said Tuesday, referring to the deadly violence a minor incident. The ruling party also reminded the United States that Washington supported a Cambodian exile government dominated by the brutal Khmer Rouge in the 1980s. The Khmer Rouge wa responsible for the death of a many a 2 million people during the guerrilla group's 1975-79 rule of Cambodia. After a series of border clash, the Khmer Rouge wa ousted from power by an invading Vietnamese army that set up a surrogate Cambodian communist government later led by Hun Sen. The ruling party accused US. policy-makers of not taking timely action to save the Cambodian people from the Khmer Rouge. They must not make unjust accusation against those who led the struggle to liberate the people from genocide, it added. Cambodia's bickering political party broke a three-month deadlock Friday and agreed to a coalition government leaving strongman Hun Sen a sole prime minister, King Norodom Sihanouk announced. In a long-elusive compromise, opposition leader Prince Norodom Ranariddh will become president of the National Assembly resulting from disputed election in July, even though Hun Sen's party hold a majority of 64 seat in the 122-member chamber. Hun Sen's Cambodian People's Party dropped insistence on a joint assembly chairmanship shared by Ranariddh and party bos Chea Sim, the current speaker. It wa one of the main stumbling block in month of discord. Instead, Sihanouk announced, the constitution will be modified to create a new Senate, which Chea Sim will head. Chea Sim will still serve a acting head of state during the king's frequent absence from the country. The major political crisis in the country ha been resolved and the political deadlock facing the nation ha also come to an end, the king said in his statement. The Senate will initially be appointed by the king. The agreement did not say how many seat there would be, nor how they would be divided. The party will hammer out detail later. Pok Than, one of Ranariddh's negotiator, said the Senate would serve a mostly advisory role to the assembly. The senior Senate leader will join those of the assembly, the prime minister and the country's top two Buddhist monk in a delicate balance of power on the council that will choose Cambodia's next king after Sihanouk dy. The two party said that the assembly would convene again Nov. 25. The agreement came surprisingly quickly following Ranariddh's return Thursday from Thailand, where he had been holed up with other opposition figure for week amid fear for their safety if they stayed in Cambodia. The deal should allow rapid formation of a government between the CPP and Ranariddh's royalist FUNCINPEC to allow international donor and business to again operate in the poverty-stricken country, which is in desperate need of aid. It could also hasten Cambodia's entry into the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, put on hold last year after Hun Sen deposed Ranariddh a co-prime minister in a bloody coup. Earlier, a both side arrived at the Royal Palace for a second day of meeting, Sihanouk said they had agreed in principle to form a coalition and made important concession. The king, the sole force in Cambodian politics able to broker a deal, pressured both side to reach agreement before he leaf Saturday for medical treatment in Beijing. Sihanouk reported that Hun Sen responded positively to a request by Ranariddh for five of his key supporter to receive political pardon. All five were convicted of political crime by court that are widely seen a loyal to Hun Sen. The king ha power to grant pardon, but ha awaited agreement from Hun Sen in politically sensitive case. Former battlefield enemy, the CPP and FUNCINPEC have been at loggerhead since the CPP narrowly won parliamentary election in July. The vote failed to put an end to instability that followed last year's coup. The CPP fell short of the two-thirds majority needed to form a government alone. Ranariddh's party and opposition ally Sam Rainsy held back their support, claiming the CPP won due to fraud and intimidation. The opposition organized protest in Phnom Penh seeking Hun Sen's ouster that were violently dispersed. Sam Rainsy, under investigation by a Phnom Penh court for his role in the demonstration, ha remained abroad. His 15 seat in the 122-seat assembly are irrelevant to forming a working government. Cambodian leader Hun Sen on Friday rejected opposition parties' demand for talk outside the country, accusing them of trying to internationalize the political crisis. Government and opposition party have asked King Norodom Sihanouk to host a summit meeting after a series of post-election negotiation between the two opposition group and Hun Sen's party to form a new government failed. Opposition leader Prince Norodom Ranariddh and Sam Rainsy, citing Hun Sen's threat to arrest opposition figure after two alleged attempt on his life, said they could not negotiate freely in Cambodia and called for talk at Sihanouk's residence in Beijing. Hun Sen, however, rejected that. I would like to make it clear that all meeting related to Cambodian affair must be conducted in the Kingdom of Cambodia, Hun Sen told reporter after a Cabinet meeting on Friday. No-one should internationalize Cambodian affair. It is detrimental to the sovereignty of Cambodia, he said. Hun Sen's Cambodian People's Party won 64 of the 122 parliamentary seat in July's election, short of the two-thirds majority needed to form a government on it own. Ranariddh and Sam Rainsy have charged that Hun Sen's victory in the election wa achieved through widespread fraud. They have demanded a thorough investigation into their election complaint a a precondition for their cooperation in getting the national assembly moving and a new government formed. Hun Sen said on Friday that the opposition concern over their safety in the country wa just an excuse for them to stay abroad. Both Ranariddh and Sam Rainsy have been outside the country since parliament wa ceremonially opened on Sep. 24. Sam Rainsy and a number of opposition figure have been under court investigation for a grenade attack on Hun Sen's Phnom Penh residence on Sep. 7. Hun Sen wa not home at the time of the attack, which wa followed by a police crackdown on demonstrator contesting Hun Sen's election victory. The Sam Rainsy Party, in a statement released Friday, accused Hun Sen of being unwilling to make any compromise on negotiation to break the deadlock. A meeting outside Cambodia, a suggested by the opposition, could place all party on more equal footing, said the statement. But the ruling party refuse to negotiate unless it is able to threaten it negotiating partner with arrest or worse. Worried that party colleague still face arrest for their politics, opposition leader Sam Rainsy sought further clarification Friday of security guarantee promised by strongman Hun Sen. Sam Rainsy wrote in a letter to King Norodom Sihanouk that he wa eager to attend the first session of the new National Assembly on Nov. 25, but complained that Hun Sen's assurance were not strong enough to ease concern his party member may be arrested upon their return to Cambodia. Hun Sen announced a government guarantee Wednesday of all politicians' safety and their right to conduct political activity in accordance with the law in force. Sam Rainsy, who earlier called Hun Sen's statement full of loophole, asked Sihanouk for his help in obtaining a promise from Hun Sen that all member of the Sam Rainsy Party were free from prosecution for their political activity during and after last July's election. Sam Rainsy, a staunch critic of Hun Sen, wa forced to take refuge in a UN. office in September to avoid arrest after Hun Sen accused him of being behind a plot against his life. The alleged assassination attempt came during massive street demonstration organized by the opposition after Hun Sen's Cambodian People's Party narrowly won the election. The opposition, alleging widespread fraud and intimidation, refused to accept the result of the poll. Fearing for their safety, Sam Rainsy and his then-ally Prince Norodom Ranariddh led an exodus of opposition lawmaker out of Cambodia after parliament wa ceremonially opened in late September. Ranariddh, whose FUNCINPEC party finished a close second in the election, returned last week and struck a deal with Hun Sen to form a coalition government. The agreement will make Hun Sen prime minister and Ranariddh president of the National Assembly. The two party have formed three working group to hammer out detail of the agreement, including the establishment of a Senate to be the upper house of parliament. Sok An, representing Hun Sen's party, said Friday that one working group had completed it work on a joint political platform to be implemented by the new government. The platform is said to emphasize administrative, economic and judicial reform, but Sok An would not reveal detail, saying Hun Sen would announce it when he present his Cabinet choice to the National Assembly. King Norodom Sihanouk on Tuesday praised agreement by Cambodia's top two political party previously bitter rival to form a coalition government led by strongman Hun Sen. In a short letter sent to news agency, the king said he had received copy of cooperation agreement signed Monday that will place Hun Sen and his Cambodian People's Party in firm control of fiscal and administrative function in the government. The protocol on cooperation between the CPP and FUNCINPEC will certainly bring peace and progress to our nation and people, Sihanouk wrote. Uncompromising enemy just a few month ago, Hun Sen and FUNCINPEC President Prince Norodom Ranariddh agreed Nov. 13 to form a government at a summit convened by Sihanouk. The deal, which will make Hun Sen prime minister and Ranariddh president of the National Assembly, ended more than three month of political deadlock that followed a July election narrowly won by Hun Sen. Key to the agreement wa the formation of a Senate a the upper house of Parliament, to be led by CPP President Chea Sim, the outgoing head of the National Assembly. Sihanouk, recalling procedure used in a past government, suggested Tuesday that he should appoint the first two member of the upper house. The remaining senator, he said, should be selected by a method agreed upon by the new government and the National Assembly. Hun Sen said Monday that the CPP and FUNCINPEC had agreed that the Senate would be half a large a the 122-seat National Assembly. Other detail of the Senate, including how much power it will be given in the promulgation of legislation, have yet to be ironed out by the two party. King Norodom Sihanouk ha declined request to chair a summit of Cambodia's top political leader, saying the meeting would not bring any progress in deadlocked negotiation to form a government. Cambodian leader Hun Sen's ruling party and the two-party opposition had called on the monarch to lead top-level talk, but disagreed on it location. Papa will not preside over any summit meeting between the three party, whether it is held in Phnom Penh or Beijing, because such a meeting will certainly achieve no result, Sihanouk wrote in an Oct. 17 letter to his son, Prince Norodom Ranariddh, leader of the senior opposition FUNCINPEC party. A copy of the letter wa obtained Thursday. In it, the king called on the three party to make compromise to end the stalemate: Papa would like to ask all three party to take responsibility before the nation and the people. Hun Sen used Thursday's anniversary of a peace agreement ending the country's civil war to pressure the opposition to form a coalition government with his party. Only those who want to prolong the anarchy and instability prevent effort to set up a new government, Hun Sen said in a televised speech marking the anniversary of the 1991 Paris Peace Accords. Hun Sen's party won 64 of the 122 seat in parliament in July's national election, but not the two-thirds majority necessary to form a government on it own. Opposition party led by Ranariddh and former finance minister Sam Ram Rainsy have refused to enter into a coalition with Hun Sen until their allegation of election fraud have been thoroughly investigated. International monitor said the election wa relatively free and fair. Hun Sen said his current government would remain in power a long a the opposition refused to form a new one. Ranariddh and Sam Rainsy have remained outside the country since the Sept. 24 ceremonial convening of parliament. Citing Hun Sen's threat to arrest opposition politician following two alleged attempt on his life, Ranariddh and Sam Rainsy have said they do not feel safe negotiating inside the country and asked the king to chair the summit at his residence in Beijing. Hun Sen ha rejected the opposition's reservation, saying it would be inappropriate to hold a summit outside the country. Negotiations so far have proved fruitless except for the opening of parliament after a Sept. 22 summit led by the king. Hun Sen implied Thursday that the opposition failed to follow through on promise made at the summit. If those result are strictly respected, there seems no reason to hold another summit, Hun Sen said in a speech on the anniversary of the 1991 Paris Peace Accords. Sihanouk is reportedly set to fly to Beijing next month to receive medical treatment from his Chinese doctor. The 75-year-old monarch suffers from a variety ailment and periodically make extended trip to Beijing. He wa diagnosed with colon cancer in 1993, but it ha since gone into remission. In September, thousand of people filled the street of Phnom Penh to protest against the alleged election fraud. Hun Sen ordered police to break up the demonstration. At least four demonstrator were killed by police, but the discovery of more than 20 body in the aftermath ha prompted speculation that the death tally could be much higher. In his speech, Hun Sen blamed the violence on opposition leader, saying the demonstration instigated social and economic chaos. Cambodia's leading opposition party ruled out sharing the presidency of Parliament with it arch foe Saturday, insisting it alone must occupy the top position in the legislative body. Disputes over the presidency have been a major stumbling block in talk between the two-party opposition bloc and the Cambodian People's Party to form a new government. Cambodian leader Hun Sen, who head the CPP, ha offered to share the legislature's top job with the royalist FUNCINPEC party of Prince Norodom Ranariddh in order to break the impasse. The prince's party, in a statement dated Friday and seen Saturday, said such a scenario wa unconstitutional. Co-sharing anything with the CPP mean surrendering full power to them. Furthermore, such a proposal is unconstitutional, the faxed statement said. The royalist party also rejected Hun Sen's call to hold bilateral talk, insisting that Ranariddh's main ally Sam Rainsy also be included. No party with seat at the National Assembly should be left out if transparency and a check and balance system is to be used in government, the statement said, adding that the Sam Rainsy Party should also be given chairmanship of one of the national assembly's nine commission. Noting that FUNCINPEC allowed the CPP to hold the presidency despite it win in the 1993 general election, the statement said it wa now it turn to take the post. In the most recent election, held in July, Hun Sen's party collected 64 of the 122 parliamentary seat, but wa short of the two-thirds majority needed to set up a new government. Fearing arrest, many opposition member of Parliament left Cambodia after the ceremonial opening of the National Assembly on Sep. 24. A series of negotiation to forge a new government have failed. The talk have been complicated by the CPP-FUNCINPEC quarrel over the Parliament's top job. Hun Sen's party recently called on Ranariddh to return to the negotiation table and said it wa willing to make an appropriate concession to break the deadlock over forming a government. FUNCINPEC ha demanded from Hun Sen written guarantee for the safety of it member and activity a a precondition for re-entering negotiation. Cambodian leader Hun Sen ha guaranteed the safety and political freedom of all politician, trying to ease the fear of his rival that they will be arrested or killed if they return to the country. The assurance were aimed especially at Sam Rainsy, leader of a vocally anti-Hun Sen opposition party, who wa forced to take refuge in the UN. office in September to avoid arrest after Hun Sen accused him of being behind a plot against his life. Sam Rainsy and the 14 member of parliament from his party have been holed up overseas for two month. But a deal reached between Hun Sen and his chief rival, Prince Norodom Ranariddh, on forming a new government last week ha opened the door for their return. In a letter to King Norodom Sihanouk the prince's father and Cambodia's head of state that wa broadcast on television Tuesday, Hun Sen said that guarantee of safety extended to Ranariddh applied to all politician. His assurance come a week before the first session of Cambodia's new parliament, the National Assembly. Sam Rainsy said Wednesday that he wa unsatisfied with the guarantee. He said it contained indirect language and loophole that suggest he and his Sam Rainsy Party member are still under threat of arrest from Hun Sen's ruling party. It should be easy for them to say, `Rainsy and the SRP member of the assembly have no charge against them and will not be arrested,' the opposition leader said in a statement. But instead they make roundabout statement, full of loophole that can easily be exploited by a legal system that is completely in their control. Ranariddh told reporter Wednesday that he believed it wa safe for Sam Rainsy in Cambodia. Speaking upon his return from a brief stay in Bangkok, the prince said he would soon meet with Hun Sen to discus the apportioning of ministry in the new coalition government. Last week, Hun Sen's Cambodian People's Party and Ranariddh's FUNCINPEC party agreed to form a coalition that would leave Hun Sen a sole prime minister and make the prince president of the National Assembly. The deal assures the two-thirds vote in parliament needed to approve a new government. The men served a co-prime minister until Hun Sen overthrew Ranariddh in a coup last year. I think Hun Sen ha got everything. He's got the premiership and legitimacy through the election and recognition from his majesty the king. I don't think there is any benefit for Hun Sen to cause instability for our country, Ranariddh said. The prince also said that his top general, Nhek Bunchhay, would not be given back his previous position a the second-ranking general in the Cambodian military's general staff. Nhek Bunchhay's outnumbered force in the capital put up tough but unsuccessful resistance to last year's coup.

r2: Cambodia King Norodom Sihanouk praised formation of a coalition of the Countries top two political parties, leaving strongman Hun Sen as Prime Minister and opposition leader Prince Norodom Ranariddh president of the National Assembly.The announcement comes after months of bitter argument following the failure of any party to attain the required quota to form a government.Opposition leader Sam Rainey was seeking assurances that he and his party members would not be arrested if they return to Cambodia.Rainey had been accused by Hun Sen of being behind an assassination attempt against him during massive street demonstrations in September.
r3: Cambodian prime minister Hun Sen rejects demands of 2 opposition parties for talks in Beijing after failing to win a 2/3 majority in recent elections.Sihanouk refuses to host talks in Beijing.Opposition parties ask the Asian Development Bank to stop loans to Hun Sen's government.CCP defends Hun Sen to the US Senate.FUNCINPEC refuses to share the presidency.Hun Sen and Ranariddh eventually form a coalition at summit convened by Sihanouk.Hun Sen remains prime minister, Ranariddh is president of the national assembly, and a new senate will be formed.Opposition leader Rainsy left out.He seeks strong assurance of safety should he return to Cambodia.
r4: Prospects were dim for resolution of the political crisis in Cambodia in October 1998.Prime Minister Hun Sen insisted that talks take place in Cambodia while opposition leaders Ranariddh and Sam Rainsy, fearing arrest at home, wanted them abroad.King Sihanouk declined to chair talks in either place.A U.S. House resolution criticized Hun Sen's regime while the opposition tried to cut off his access to loans.But in November the King announced a coalition government with Hun Sen heading the executive and Ranariddh leading the parliament.Left out, Sam Rainsy sought the King's assurance of Hun Sen's promise of safety and freedom for all politicians.

data: Hurricane Mitch cut through the Honduran coast like a ripsaw Thursday, it devastating wind whirling for a third day through resort island and mainland community. At least 32 people were killed and widespread flooding prompted more than 150,000 to seek higher ground. Mitch, once among the century's most powerful hurricane, weakened today a it blasted this Central American nation, bringing downpour that flooded at least 50 river. It also kicked up huge wave that pounded seaside community. The storm's power wa easing and by 1200 GMT, it had sustained wind of 80 mph (130 kph), down from 100 mph (160 kph) around midnight and well below it 180 mph (290 kph) peak of early Tuesday. After remaining virtually stationary for more than a day, the US. National Hurricane Center said Thursday the center of the 350-mile-wide (560-kilometer-wide) storm had moved slightly to the south but remained just off the Honduran coast. Hurricane-force wind whirled up to 30 mile (50 kilometer) from the center, with rain-laden tropical storm wind extending well beyond that. Caught near the heart of the storm were the Bay Islands, about 25 mile (40 kilometer) off Honduras' coast and popular with diver and beachcomber. The hurricane ha destroyed almost everything, said Mike Brown, a resident of Guanaja Island, 20 mile (32 kilometer) off the coast. Few house have remained standing. Honduran official said 14 people had died on that small island alone, and at least nine had died elsewhere in the country. More than 72,000 people had been evacuated to shelter. Nine other death had been reported elsewhere in the region by early Thursday more than a day after Mitch drifted to just off the coast and seemed to park there. An American wa thrown from his boat south of Cancun, Mexico, on Monday and wa presumed dead. Eight others died in Nicaragua in flooding. Honduran official said more than 200 town and village had been isolated by the storm, left without power, telephone or clean drinking water. Agriculture Minister Pedro Arturo Sevilla said crucial grain, citrus and banana crop had been damaged and the economic future of Honduras is uncertain. Rain-swollen river knocked out bridge and road, isolating La Ceiba, a coastal city of 40,000 people located 80 mile (128 kilometer) from the Bay Islands. About 10,000 resident fled to crowded shelter in school, church and firehouse. While supply of food and gasoline seemed to hold up, driver worried about the coming day formed long line to fill their tank at gas station and some supermarket took measure to limit panic buying. La Ceiba official appealed for pure water for those in shelter and some resident set out plastic bucket to collect rainwater. Only a few hotel and office with their own generator had electricity. Wind-whipped wave almost buried some house near the shore. People evacuated low-lying house by wading through chest-deep water with sodden bag of belonging on their head. In neighboring Belize, most of the 75,000 resident of coastal Belize City had left by Wednesday, turning the country's largest city into a ghost town. Police and soldier patrolled the street, and a few people wandered amid the boarded-up house. The cable television company wa broadcasting only The Weather Channel. With the storm seemingly anchored off Honduras, official in Mexico to the north eased emergency measure on the Caribbean coast of the Yucatan Peninsula, where hundred of people remained in shelter a a precaution Wednesday night. More than 20,000 tourist had abandoned Cancun and nearby resort area, leaving hotel at about 20 percent of capacity. Houston accountant Kathy Montgomery said that she and her friend Nina Devries had tried to leave Cancun but found all the flight full. It's been horrible, said Montgomery, a she and her friend drank cocktail at an outdoor restaurant. We couldn't go out on a boat, we couldn't go snorkeling. Even Carlos' N Charlie's and Senor Frog's are closed, she said dejectedly, referring to two restaurant. Some vacation. The US. Agency for International Development sent two helicopter each to Belize and Honduras to help in search, rescue and relief effort. At it peak, Mitch wa the fourth-strongest Caribbean hurricane in this century, behind Gilbert in 1988, Allen in 1980 and the Labor Day hurricane of 1935. BRUSSELS, Belgium (AP) - The European Union on Tuesday approved 6.4 million European currency unit (dlrs 7.7 million) in aid for thousand of victim of the devastation caused by Hurricane Mitch in Central America. EU spokesman Pietro Petrucci said the fund will be used to provide basic care such a medicine, food, water sanitation and blanket to thousand of people whose home were destroyed by torrential rain and mudslide. The aid will be distributed in Nicaragua, El Salvador, Honduras and Guatemala which have most suffered from Mitch's deadly passage, the EU executive Commission said in a statement. Officials in Central America estimated Tuesday that about 7,000 people have died in the region. The greatest loss were reported in Honduras, where an estimated 5,000 people died and 600,000 people 10 percent of the population were forced to flee their home after last week's storm. El Salvador's National Emergency Committee listed 174 dead, 96 missing and 27,000 homeless. But it own regional affiliate in San Miguel province reported 125 dead there alone. Guatemala reported 100 storm-related death. The latest EU aid follows an initial 400,000 ecu (dlrs 480,000). the EU approved for the region on Friday. The full 6.8 million ecu (dlrs 8.18 million) will be channeled through humanitarian group working in the region. At least 231 people have been confirmed dead in Honduras from former-hurricane Mitch, bringing the storm's death toll in the region to 357, the National Emergency Commission said Saturday. Mitch once, 2nd graf pvs Nicaraguan Vice President Enrique Bolanos said Sunday night that between 1,000 and 1,500 people were buried in a 32-square mile (82.88 square-kilometer) area below the slope of the Casita volcano in northern Nicaragua. That is in addition to least another 600 people elsewhere in the country, Bolanos said. Honduras braced for potential catastrophe Tuesday a Hurricane Mitch roared through the northwest Caribbean, churning up high wave and intense rain that sent coastal resident scurrying for safer ground. President Carlos Flores Facusse declared a state of maximum alert and the Honduran military sent plane to pluck resident from their home on island near the coast. At 0900 GMT Tuesday, Mitch wa 95 mile (152 kilometer) north of Honduras, near the Swan Islands. With wind near 180 mph (289 kph), and even higher gust, it wa a Category 5 monster the highest, most dangerous rating for a storm. The 350-mile (560-kilometer) wide hurricane wa moving west at 8 mph (12 kph). Mitch is closing in, said Monterrey Cardenas, mayor of Utila, an island 20 mile (32 kilometer) off the Honduran coast. A delegation of Chilean legislator lobbying against the possible extradition of Augusto Pinochet to Spain to face trial, warned Thursday that Chile wa on the brink of political turmoil. A ruling that the investigation are outside the jurisdiction of Spanish law would made any extradition request difficult. The decision is likely to hang on how genocide and terrorism are interpreted, a these crime are specifically mentioned in the Spanish legal code. The British and Spanish prime minister said Sunday that the fate of former Chilean dictator Gen. Augusto Pinochet is in the hand of their judicial authority and they will not interfere. Both myself and Mr. Aznar agree this is not a matter for u to discus, British Prime Minister Tony Blair said, referring to Spanish leader Jose Maria Aznar. I've avoided commenting on that judicial process and I don't intend to do so. Aznar made similar comment when he meet journalist on the margin of a European Union summit in this Alpine lakeside resort. Pinochet is under arrest in a London hospital where he'd gone for back surgery. He wa detained on a warrant from a Spanish magistrate seeking to extradite him on charge of genocide, terrorism and torture during his 1973-90 rule. The Chilean government ha urged Britain to release Pinochet on humanitarian ground, and argued that a a senator, he is entitled to diplomatic immunity. Aznar dismissed report that the bid to try Pinochet will damage Spain's relation with Latin America. It's important we don't talk nonsense about this issue. This is stupid.

In a statement provided by Tim Pendry, his London-based adviser, Idris said: I have absolutely no relationship with any Islamic terrorist organization anywhere in the world. I have never met Mr. bin Laden, I have never spoken with him, I have never had any financial or business relationship with him, nor knowingly with anyone acting a his agent. US. official say they have also received new report of an increase in the Iraqi presence in Sudan since the missile attack. At the time of the Aug. 20 cruise missile attack, Clinton administration official acknowledge, they did not know that Idris owned the Shifa factory. MUNICH, Germany (AP) US. prosecutor have asked for a 20-day extension to provide Germany with paperwork necessary to extradite a top lieutenant of Saudi terrorist suspect Osama bin Laden, official said Saturday. Mamdouh Mahmud Salim, 40, of Sudan, ha been jailed since his arrest near Munich on Sept. 16 by Bavarian authority acting on a US. warrant. Under German law, US. official have 40 day after the arrest to turn over supporting evidence so a German court can rule on their extradition request. Quoting unidentified Bavarian law enforcement source, Focus newsmagazine reported Saturday that the evidence turned over so far wa not very strong. The magazine said much of it wa based on the testimony of an FBI informant, a former bin Laden associate, who made only vague connection between Salim and terrorist activity. Sometime in the summer of 1997, an operative for Osama bin Laden sat down at his personal computer in a hideaway in Kenya. He wa worried, he wrote in an angry dispatch, about the security of the East Africa network of bin Laden, the Saudi exile accused of masterminding a worldwide terrorist conspiracy against Americans. The organization, the author complained, had declared war against the United States, yet he had learned of that only from the news medium. The writer, who federal authority believe wa Haroun Fazil, who wa to become one of the central suspect in the bombing of the US. Embassy in Nairobi a year later, noted with alarm British press report about the arrest of an aide to bin Laden. Striking almost bureaucratic tone, he said he wa worried that an important man with close link to bin Laden, seemed to have fallen into the enemy's hand. He said the Americans were breathing down the neck of his associate in Nairobi and that he had to take precaution. The cell is at 100 percent danger, the operative warned. The letter, an extraordinary bit of digital evidence in a cloak-and-dagger case, wa retrieved from a computer in a house where Fazil had been staying, according to paper filed in US. District Court in New York City. The paper said the computer wa seized in August 1997 in a raid by Kenyan authority that wa attended by an FBI agent. The document did not make clear whether the FBI had translated and read the document before or after the bombing of the US. Embassies in Nairobi and Dar e Salaam, Tanzania, on Aug. 7 of this year. The timing is potentially important because there have been mounting question since the bombing about whether the United States adequately followed up warning of a possible terrorist attack on American target in Kenya. Officials of the FBI and the US. attorney's office in New York City refused to say Tuesday night at what point FBI agent learned of the computer file, nor would they make any other comment. Fazil eluded American investigator after the bombing a he traveled from Kenya to his home in the Comoros Islands and then to the Middle East. He remains a fugitive. The dispatch provides a remarkable insight into the working of a terrorist network in the twilight of the 20th century. The author talk of how he and his fellow operative follow event on CNN and use the Internet to communicate. He refers to himself a the medium information officer of the East Africa cell and complains that he is not being kept in the loop on big decision. The writer of the document warned that the follower of bin Laden, whom he referred to a the sheik, had become America's primary target. He said his comrade in East Africa should know that there is an American-Kenyan-Egyptian intelligence activity in Nairobi aiming to identify the name and residence of the member who are associated with the sheik since America know well that the youth who lived in Somalia and were member of the sheik's cell are the one who killed Americans in Somalia. They know that since Kenya wa the main gateway for those member, there must be a center in Kenya, he wrote, concluding: We are really in danger. The government ha asserted that one of Fazil's duty wa to prepare and transmit report to bin Laden and his top lieutenant. He repeatedly expressed his fear of American intelligence, which he believed wa in the midst of a worldwide search for bin Laden and his associate. On Aug. 7, they charge, Fazil drove a pickup truck to the embassy, leading the way for a vehicle carrying the bomb that killed more than 200 people, including 12 Americans. The author of the report said that he stood ready to fight the force of atheism and dictator who wreaked havoc on earth. He said that the group did not have to inform it Nairobi-based operative of all it global plan, but they needed enough warning to go underground for a while if authority intensified the pressure in Nairobi. We, the East Africa cell member, do not want to know about the operation plan, he wrote, since we are just implementers. If Osama bin Laden ever stand trial in New York for the bombing of the US. embassy in Africa and other act of terror, it is already clear who prosecutor will call a a chief witness: One of his senior aide who ha been talking to US. investigator for two year. One of the clear but unstated objective of last August's raid on Afghanistan wa to kill Osama bin Laden and a many of his lieutenant a possible, administration official now acknowledge. According to the official, White House lawyer conducted a secret review in the month before the attack and concluded that such operation are legal under US. and international law. US. intelligence official say they now believe that bin Laden wa in the camp on the day of the attack, but he appears to have left unscathed before the missile hit. Administration official have denied since August that the raid wa intended to kill bin Laden, a Saudi exile who ha been charged by federal prosecutor with leading a global war against US. interest. We weren't quite successful, Cohen continued, but we sent a message. Kenneth Bacon, the Pentagon spokesman, said the secretary had not retracted his statement. The Los Angeles Times recently reported that the administration believed that it had a legal right to use deadly force against terrorist leader. Bin Laden's organization wa a significant concern for the Clinton administration even before the bombing of the US. embassy in East Africa. Last spring, official said, US. intelligence considered a daring raid into Afghanistan to capture the Saudi exile. Officials said that at roughly the same time, the White House drafted the legal justification for military attack against a terrorist leadership. That review, official said, provided the legal basis in August to fire cruise missile into the meeting at which it wa believed bin Laden and his lieutenant would be gathered. The review, by the National Security Council, wa the basis for saying this operation did not violate the presidential order banning assassination. That ban wa imposed by President Ford in 1975, after congressional investigator uncovered evidence that the CIA had plotted to assassinate Fidel Castro, the Cuban leader, and others. The order said: No person employed by, or acting on behalf of the United States government shall engage in, or conspire to engage in, assassination. While it is, on it face, a sweeping and unqualified ban, it ha been subject to interpretation and intense debate over the year. In 1986, the Reagan administration responded to a terrorist attack against US. soldier in Germany with a bombing raid on Libya. The National Basketball Association, embroiled in a labor dispute with it player, Tuesday canceled the first two week of the 1998-99 season. A small, grass airstrip 8 kilometer (5 mile) away from Kalima is just barely long enough for the rebels' Russian-built Antonov AN-72 transport aircraft. The rebel have targeted Kindu since late August, when they were forced to retreat from the outskirt of Kinshasa after Angola and Zimbabwe sent troop to bail out Kabila. Rebels still control a string of town in eastern Congo, including Kisangani, the country's third-largest city. A day after shooting down a jetliner, Congolese rebel and their Rwandan ally pushed Sunday through government defense line, showing the confidence of a victor in a week-old battle for a strategic air base. Fighting in Kindu, 32 kilometer (20 mile) northeast of the Elila River bridge, died down after the rebel fired a barrage of artillery into the government-held quarter and the air base, four kilometer (two mile) away. Rebel commander Fino Kabangu Kalunga said the government force, surrounded by 3,500 rebel troop from three direction, failed to respond to Sunday's attack. Some troop reportedly retreated through a single road corridor leading out of the town. On Saturday, the rebel said they shot down a Congolese Boeing 727 which wa attempting to land at Kindu air base with 40 troop and ammunition. In Kinshasa, the private Congolese Airlines, which owned the aircraft, said the victim were civilian fleeing fighting in Kindu. It wa not possible to confirm independently either claim. Kalunga said the airport, although still under government control, wa in effect unoperational because of the rebel surface-to-air-missiles deployed nearby. War-weary, physically exhausted and sweaty, hundred of rebel troop and Rwandan soldier marched through dense tropical forest went to reinforce their comrade at Kindu. After a week of battling for Kindu, rebel fighter had made little progress and failed to capture the town outright. The rebel see Kindu a a major prize in their two-month revolt against President Laurent Kabila, whom they accuse of mismanagement, corruption and warmongering among Congo's 400 tribe. Kabila ha turned Kindu into a launching pad for a counteroffensive against rebel position in eastern Congo. The conflict ha drawn in many of Congo's neighbor. There are unconfirmed report that troop from Chad and the Sudan are involved in defending Kindu. Kabila accuses Rwanda and Uganda former ally who installed him in power in May 1997 after an eight-month rebellion of sponsoring the new fighting. Both country say they have legitimate security interest in eastern Congo and accuse Kabila of failing to rid the common border area of Rwandan and Ugandan rebel. Tanks, aircraft and troop from Angola, Zimbabwe and Namibia are supporting Kabila. The assistance wa essential in routing an early rebel offensive in the west that had reached the outskirt of Kinshasa in mid-August. The rebel say they now control one-third of Kindu and are poised to overrun the rest of the town. Under a scorching sun, the column of rebel reinforcement heading to Kindu sneaked through abandoned roadside hamlet. The silence of their march wa interrupted only by the singing of cricket and the clanging of the bullet belt hanging around the soldiers' neck. Soldiers walked by empty hut made of mud and palm leaf. Some rested in the shade of the umbrella-shaped acacia tree. The soldier stopped for the night at the bridge over the chocolate-colored Elila River, which guard the path to Kindu. There wa no immediate comment on the latest development from the government in Kinshasa, which claimed earlier in the week it wa in control of the tarmac bridge.

data: After an unusual, one-on-one chat Tuesday night, the Philippine and Indonesian president were considering staying away from an Asia-Pacific summit in Malaysia to protest the treatment of their jailed friend Anwar Ibrahim. Both president have hinted they might not attend the meeting of the 18 Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation nation next month in the Malaysian capital out of concern for Anwar. The former deputy prime minister and finance minister of Malaysia wa arrested Sept. 20 on corruption and illegal sex charge, then brought to court with a black eye and bruise. Philippine President Joseph Estrada told business and political leader in Singapore on Tuesday that he had not made up his mind. Estrada called Anwar his friend and said, I think all of u here believe that due process and human right should be respected. Indonesian President BJ. Habibie may also stay away, his foreign minister, Ali Alatas, said after the two new Southeast Asian leader held a half-hour private meeting. If Habibie pass up APEC, Alatas said, it will be because he ha difficulty leaving the country while there is no vice president, while there are so many problem to deal with. Habibie ha already canceled a state visit to Malaysia, citing difficulty at home. The meeting wa delayed for almost 90 minute when a mechanical fault wa discovered in one of two Indonesian helicopter that were to have flown Estrada and his entourage through heavy rain from Singapore. A ferry wa chartered for the 45-minute sea journey. Habibie apologized when Estrada finally arrived at the Melia Panorama Hotel. Estrada replied, That's all right. The two men, who have each been in power le than five month, met alois June 30 inaugural speech to give the underclass a fairer share of the country's wealth. Habibie took office May 21, hour after his predecessor and mentor, Suharto, wa forced from power after national protest and street riot over Indonesia's collapsing economy. Top finance official from 14 country in the Asia-Pacific region advised Asia's battered economy on Sunday to adopt further reform in their effort to restore stability. Among the necessary step is for country to restructure their economy and corporation to make them le susceptible to abuse by narrow political interest, the official suggested. The deputy finance minister and deputy central bank governor met for two day to review progress on the Manila Framework, an agreement reached last November that aim to promote regional economic stability. Many of Asia's economy have plunged into recession since that agreement. Collapsed currency, weakened demand and higher unemployment now characterize a region that once boasted some of the world's highest economic growth rate. The worsening financial gloom is likely to dominate talk at next week's summit in Kuala Lumpur of leader from the 18-nation Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum. The summit is to take place on Nov. 17-18. In a joint statement, the official cited risk including slower global growth, with particular mention of Russia's worsening economy, and the need to speed up social program to help the poor in the worst-hit country. Stanley Fischer, deputy managing director of the International Monetary Fund, noted that some country have already reformed their banking sector. But he stressed the need for corporate restructuring a well. These are not easy thing to do, he said. Meanwhile, Malaysia's most prominent dissident predicted that the country's prime minister would declare a state of emergency after the APEC meeting end in Kuala Lumpur, a report said Sunday. Former Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim, now on trial on charge of corruption and sexual misconduct, made the warning in an interview with Monday's edition of Time magazine. Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad fired Anwar in September, saying he wa morally unfit to lead, then had him expelled from Malaysia's ruling party. Anwar denies the allegation and say they were fabricated because Mahathir considered his popularity a threat to the prime minister's 17-year rule. The Philippine ambassador to Malaysia said Friday he wa summoned to the Malaysian Foreign Ministry to explain his president's statement in support of dissident Anwar Ibrahim. Ambassador Jose Brillantes said in a radio interview from Kuala Lumpur that he wa called Thursday after the Malaysian dissident's eldest daughter met Philippine President Joseph Estrada. They expressed their concern about what's happening and the statement coming out of the Philippines, Brillantes told radio station DZXL in Manila. Brillantes said he explained that following the 1986 people power revolt against the late dictator Ferdinand Marcos, Filipinos' react strongly to real and perceived violation of human right. I just explained our culture to them, he said. Anwar wa fired a deputy premier in September and later arrested, appearing in court with a black eye, bruise and a neck brace. He say he wa beaten by security guard. Estrada ha expressed support for Anwar, whom he considers a personal friend, and indicated he may not attend a summit of Asia Pacific Rim nation in Malaysia next month. He ha also said Anwar should be held in house arrest during his upcoming trial on corruption and sexual misconduct charge. Anwar ha denied the charge, calling them politically motivated. On Thursday, Estrada told Anwar's daughter, Nurul Izzah, to tell her father not to waver because he is fighting for a cause, the cause of the Malaysian people. He said, however, that his support is personal and moral and not meant to interfere in the internal problem of Malaysia. Brillantes said: The expression of personal opinion is allowed in our culture and it is not surprising for that to happen. He also said there is no connection between Anwar's case and the summit meeting in Malaysia of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum. We still consider, a expressed by our president, that APEC is important to u, he said. He did not say how the Malaysian official reacted, but he said he wa not reprimanded. Meanwhile, a group Philippine legislator said they plan to attend Anwar's trial, which open Nov. 2. We feel that being observer to his trial will be our silent statement of our democratic aspiration for all Asia, the group said in a statement. Again bowing to Chinese pressure, Taiwan will send it chief economic planner to represent President Lee Teng-hui at November's Asian Pacific Economic Cooperation forum summit in Kuala Lumpur, the Foreign Ministry said Friday. Lee decided to send Chiang Pin-kung to the informal leader summit on Nov. 17-18 after giving much thought to an invitation from Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, the ministry said. Presentation of an invitation to Lee by the host nation with the understanding that it will be politely refused is an annual formality that allows Taiwan to maintain a semblance of dignity and the host to avoid controversy with China. Beijing's threat to boycott APEC's annual meeting if Lee attends ha forced him to send a stand-in every year since the inaugural summit in 1993. China claim Taiwan a a breakaway province and argues that only sovereign nation are allowed to send their head of state. APEC group Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, the Philippines, Singapore, Taiwan, Thailand and the United States. Russia, Vietnam and Peru will join in November. Indonesian President BJ. Habibie find attending a summit of Asia-Pacific leader difficult because of his concern about the arrest of Malaysia's former deputy prime minister, a Thai newspaper reported Sunday. Asia-Pacific leader are scheduled to meet next month in Malaysia for an annual economics meeting. Last week, Philippine President Joseph Estrada said he wa considering not going to the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum because of Anwar Ibrahim's arrest. I'm very concerned over how my friend Anwar Ibrahim ha been treated, Habibie wa quoted a saying by the English-language newspaper The Nation. I'm concerned because people should not forget that Anwar Ibrahim had contributed a lot for the benefit of his country. Anwar is a charismatic politician who wa once picked to be the successor to Malaysia's long-serving Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad. But he wa suddenly fired by Mahathir on Sept. 2 after the two differed on economic policy. He then began speaking out against Mahathir and wa arrested Sept. 20. Anwar ha been accused of engaging in homosexual act illegal under Malaysia law, but the charge are generally seen a a pretext for his political persecution. In a court appearance last week, Anwar's face wa bruised and he said he had been beaten by police, heightening international attention to his case. Because of human right involved and I think it is universal people should be given the chance to defend themselves, Habibie wa quoted a saying in the interview conducted Saturday. People should not be tortured. Habibie said Anwar's dismissal should not have been based on thing which had not been proven. On attending the APEC meeting, he said, It's difficult for me. But he said he would consult parliament, adding, I'm not coming personally but a the president of 211 million people of Indonesia. Like Estrada, Habibie served a his country's vice president when Anwar wa deputy prime minister, making them counterpart on the international affair circuit. A group of high-powered US. investor in Southeast Asia on Monday applauded effort to perk up Thailand's staggering economy, saying they had been assured by top Thai official that key economic reform package will soon be approved. After meeting with Thai Cabinet member, including Prime Minister Chuan Leekpai, member of the U.S.-ASEAN Business Council said they were confident in the future of Thailand's economy and promised their company would continue to invest here and elsewhere in the region. We would be quick a observer to applaud the aggressiveness of the reform package that we see being proposed in front of your government today, said business council chairman George David, who is also chairman and CEO of United Technologies Corp. Thailand wa hit hard by last year's Asian economic crisis, and the proposed economic reform legislation focus on resolving the massive bad debt of private company, which is hindering a recovery. This is very aggressive, good reform. It's very impressive, David said, adding that Finance Minister Tarrin Nimmanahaeminda promised Parliament would pas reform measure in month, not year. The U.S.-ASEAN Business Council is a private organization comprising about 300 US. company with substantial investment in Southeast Asia. David said the five executive in the delegation represented dlrs 300 billion in asset. The council's lobbying effort with the US. and Southeast Asian government have concentrated on removing tariff and other barrier to overseas trade. The delegation will travel to Kuala Lumpur for the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum Nov. 14-18. David said free trade should be a focus of discussion among the government leader attending. What I hope they will say at APEC is a very strong affirmation of the free-trade agenda and a very strong affirmation of the foreign direct investment agenda, he added. In little more than a week, the world's leader will converge on this businesslike city in the heart of Southeast Asia for the annual meeting of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum. They could hardly be meeting in a more provocative place. On Sept. 1, Malaysia discontinued trading in it currency, the ringgit, and imposed sweeping control on the flow of capital in it stock and currency market, particularly on investment from overseas. In doing so, the Malaysian prime minister, Mahathir Mohamad, in effect slammed the door on the global economy that President Clinton and the other leader are coming here to champion. Mahathir's decision drew jeer from international investor and policy- maker, who warned that Malaysia wa seeking a quick fix that would retard it desperately needed reform and leave it the odd man out when Asia finally recovered from the regional malaise. Now, though, Mahathir's ally are marshaling new economic data that they say indicate that capital control are breathing new life into the country's moribund economy. Malaysia's foreign reserve rose strongly in September, and there is anecdotal evidence that consumer are starting to spend again. It's nice to be able to say that since we adopted capital control, the economy ha improved, said Zainal Aznam Yusof, the deputy director of the Institute of Strategic and International Studies, a research organization here that helped draft the policy. But we want to see whether this is strongly sustainable. Critics said it wa predictable that capital control would be a short-term tonic to Malaysia's economy. Because the country is sheltered from the vagary of capital flow and currency fluctuation, they said, the government had been able to ease interest rate and encourage consumer spending. Still, the mere fact that Malaysia's experiment ha yielded some positive result guarantee that the issue will come up during the APEC meeting. With Mahathir leading the campaign, the cause of capital control will have a fiery advocate who ha a penchant for getting under the skin of Westerners. Mahathir is a very outspoken political leader, said Chia Yew Boon, an independent analyst in Singapore. There is no way the like of Clinton or Jiang Zemin are going to be able to muzzle him, he added, referring to President Jiang of China. Policy-makers in the United States have expressed fear that if Malaysia's gambit is seen a successful, other economically weakened country in the region, like Indonesia, might be tempted to try it. So far, Indonesian official have said they would stick to the recovery plan devised by the International Monetary Fund, which stress economic austerity and open market. But official in Japan have expressed some sympathy for Mahathir's policy, while Paul Krugman, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, ha advocated using them a an emergency measure. Yusof said recent event had vindicated Malaysia's contention that it needed to insulate itself from the ravage of the global financial system. He said the recent near-collapse of a prominent American hedge fund underscored how sudden flow of capital can have destructive consequence. The Long-Term Capital Management hedge fund, based in Greenwich, Conn., wa nearly wrecked by a series of wrong bet on Treasury security after the collapse of the economy in Russia prompted a flight of capital out of that country. The LTCM fiasco really provides a case study of what could go wrong in the global economy, Yusof said. With capital control a protection, Yusof said Malaysia wa picking up the piece of it shattered economy. In addition to growing foreign reserve, he said Malaysia had improved it trade balance and revived consumer purchase of durable good. Foreign investor have also not wholly abandoned Malaysia, a expert had predicted they would. While foreign direct investment fell in September to $142 million, from an average monthly rate of $321 million for the period from January through September it did not dry up completely. For every comforting statistic, though, the critic produce an alarming one. They said the increase in Malaysia's foreign reserve wa merely due to the new capital restriction, which stipulated that Malaysian currency held outside the country would be worthless unless repatriated by Sept. 30. The skeptic also noted that bank lending declined in September, despite several reduction in interest rate. So the consumer who are buying new car and home appliance are merely dipping into their saving, which mean the buying spree will end when their saving are depleted. The argument wa that by imposing capital control, you'd regain control over monetary policy, which would increase the supply of money and lessen the liquidity crunch, said KS. Jomo, a professor of political economy at the University of Malaya here. But that's not happening. The biggest flaw in Malaysia's policy, Jomo and others said, is it timing. With the Asian crisis more than a year old, much of the foreign capital that wa in the country ha already gone. The critic said Mahathir had spooked would-be investor without even locking in the one who used to be here. There is a case to be made for the temporary imposition of capital control, but to avert a crisis, not to respond to one, Jomo said. In fact, other Asian currency, like the Indonesian rupiah and the Thai baht, have actually rebounded since Malaysia suspended trading in it currency and fixed the exchange rate at 3.8 ringgit to the dollar. Analysts liken the situation to buying an insurance policy for a disaster that ha come and gone. More important, the capital control are slowing down much-needed corporate and banking reform. The government's rescue of Renong, a major conglomerate with close tie to Mahathir, is going ahead, though some analyst predict the government will eventually scrap the much-criticized plan. The rescue of politically connected company remains a tense issue here. On Monday, during the trial of Malaysia's former deputy prime minister, Anwar Ibrahim, on charge of corruption and sex-related crime, Anwar angrily denied Mahathir's claim that he had approved the bailout. Anwar's sensational trial is a reminder that Mahathir's economic policy cannot be disentangled from politics. Malaysia's 72-year-old prime minister clashed with his former protege over how to respond to the Asian crisis, and he dismissed Anwar the day after imposing capital control. During boom time, Mahathir won support for his policy by wrapping them in anti-foreigner language. In a speech on Monday, he attacked a familiar target, saying foreign currency trader are the cause of the currency turmoil, adding: They spread it worldwide. They precipitated the current recession in every country. But Mahathir's treatment of Anwar ha stirred anger and sparked growing social unrest in Malaysia. With protester chanting for reform on the usually orderly street of this city, expert said Mahathir needed capital control to work in order to soothe the country's agitated population. Things will heat up if the economy doe not improve, said Chandra Muzaffar, a professor of political science at the University of Malaya. Then the whole question of Mahathir and his leadership will remain an issue. In that regard, at least, the leader who converge on Kuala Lumpur in two week will be able to identify with their embattled host. The leader of Malaysia's ruling party met Tuesday to discus a replacement for ousted deputy prime minister Anwar Ibrahim, who face trial next month in a case that will test the country's legal system. Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, 72, said last week he could drop dead at any time. But because of the large number of candidate for the deputy's job within the ruling United Malays National Organization, a decision wa not expected quickly. The party leader, who have been conducting a national campaign to explain to Malaysians why the popular Anwar wa fired Sept. 2, will also confer on what to do now that the High Court judge ha banned all comment on Anwar's guilt or innocence. The ruling coalition had scheduled a giant rally in the capital Saturday, aimed at drawing in the youth to whom Anwar's campaign of reform ha the most appeal. Mahathir, who had heart bypass surgery in 1989, had groomed Anwar, 51, a his successor. But he fired his protege from his post a deputy prime minister and finance minister on ground he wa morally unfit to lead. The two had differed over economic policy and Anwar ha said Mahathir feared he wa a threat to his 17-year rule. Anwar wa also dumped from the ruling party, and after two week of nationwide rally at which he called for government reform and Mahathir's resignation, he wa arrested under a law that allows police to hold him indefinitely, and prevent him from seeing his family and lawyer. On Tuesday, Mahathir denounced demonstrator who had flocked by the thousand to the street of downtown Kuala Lumpur in recent week, calling them part of a plot to topple the government. Baton-wielding riot police had dispersed the crowd with tear gas and water cannon, arresting more than 100 people. They decided that the government should be brought down through demonstration, riot, the Bernama news agency quoted Mahathir a saying in Sarawak state on Borneo Island. He wa expected to return to Kuala Lumpur later Tuesday to chair the UMNO meeting. After Anwar appeared in court with a black eye, bruised face, neck and arm, his case drew international attention, particularly from the president of the Philippines and Indonesia, who have raised the possibility they might not attend an 18-nation summit in Malaysia next month. The United States would downgrade President Bill Clinton's visit to Kuala Lumpur next month if Anwar continued to be mistreated, the Wall Street Journal quoted an official in Washington a saying. Clinton is scheduled to go to Malaysia for the meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum. Wearing a neck brace Monday after a court-ordered hospital checkup, Anwar wa ordered to stand trial Nov. 2 on four charge of abusing his power to interfere with a police investigation. His trial is to halt on Nov. 14 and resume after the APEC meeting. He ha pleaded innocent to all charge, including another corruption count and five charge of sodomy. He face 14 year in prison and a fine on each corruption count and 20 year, plus whipping, on each sexual charge, if convicted. Anwar wa arrested Sept. 20 under the Internal Security Act, which allows jail without trial. Under the same law, police also arrested 17 people considered Anwar associate and a risk to national security. As of Tuesday, 12 had been released. The UMNO supreme council wa expected to prepare a list of top candidate for Anwar's job for Mahathir's final decision. The Star newspaper, which is close to the government, listed the favorite a Foreign Minister Abdullah Ahmad Badawi and Education Minister Najib Tun Razak. Other top contender included Mahathir's confidant Daim Zainuddin, a former finance minister brought back into the Cabinet in June a special function minister in charge of economic recovery. Rafidah Aziz, the international trade and industry minister, and Tengku Razaleigh Hamzah, a former finance minister, were also in the running. The last time the Asia-Pacific region held it annual summit to promote free trade, Japan's prime minister assured everyone that his economy wouldn't be the next victim of Asia's financial crisis. Canada, the host country, wa criticized by some in Canada for cracking down on demonstration against Suharto, Indonesia's iron-fisted ruler at the time. And President Bill Clinton, whose popularity and booming economy were the envy of the planet, joined everyone else in urging country such a Thailand and South Korea to bite the bullet and comply with the tough economic reform that the International Monetary Fund wa demanding. My, how the challenge have grown, a the 21-nation Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum prepares for it November summit in Malaysia. Japan the world's second largest economy, and Asia's financial anchor is suffering through it worst recession since World War II, and that bad news cost Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto his job. Suharto, who ruled Indonesia for 32 year, wa driven out of power by a violent, pro-democracy movement, and the world's fourth most populous country is in real trouble financially. Wall Street is now coping with a steep downturn. And even though Clinton ha promised to attend the APEC meeting, some people wonder how he can do that while facing an impeachment inquiry back home, thanks to the Monica Lewinsky sex scandal. Worse still, Asia's economic crisis is showing sign of going global, and more and more economist are criticizing the IMF for the way it is handling it bailouts. Other well-respected economist are going even further, questioning whether a free-market philosophy doesn't leave some country too vulnerable to the chaos of major market speculator. In fact, Malaysia isn't the only country trying self-defense mechanism such a capital control. Hong Kong recently spent a fortune investing in it stock market to ward off speculator. And Washington is trying to figure out what to do with hedge fund after watching it Federal Reserve help bail out a major one that wa going under, and seeing the investment of others send the US. dollar into a tailspin against Japan's yen. Ironically, Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, who made one of his typical anti-free-market comment during last year's summit, probably could have opened this year's with an I told you so. But even he is having major domestic problem. Mahathir, 72, who is widely credited with creating modern Malaysia during his 17 year in power, dismissed Anwar Ibrahim, his expected successor, in an apparent dispute over how to battle the country's economic mess. Instead of stepping aside, Anwar launched a reform movement across Malaysia that quickly led to big rally demanding that Mahathir step down. The prime minister used riot police to thwart the protest, and jailed Anwar, charging him with corruption and sex crime, and scheduling his trial for Nov. 2. The trial will be interrupted during the Nov. 12-18 APEC meeting, but Mahathir's treatment of Anwar and his reform movement already have been criticized by APEC member such a Australia, Indonesia, the Philippines and the United States. President BJ. Habibie of Indonesia and Philippine President Joseph Estrada consider Anwar a friend, and Estrada won't say whether he plan to attend this year's APEC summit. John S. Wolf, the US. ambassador for APEC, recently acknowledged that it won't be easy for APEC member to meet in Malaysia a the Asian crisis ricochet around the world with no clear sign what will happen next. But he also said the leader of the 21 APEC member should aim for a productive meeting. Wolf said such gathering give member a chance to discus IMF bailout strategy and the free-market philosophy, to resolve bilateral dispute, and to continue to reduce tariff rate to help struggling country improve their export. This ha been a lousy year in general. It ha affected all of u. It ha set APEC back, and there is no silver bullet to solve the crisis right away, said Wolf. But we should welcome the chance to work together and to develop a sense of what's possible. So far, APEC ha been criticized for doing little during the financial crisis. But next month it hope to complete a plan that would lift trade barrier in nine key industries: environmental product and service, energy, fishery, forestry, toy, jewelry, medical good, chemical product and telecommunication. Besides the United States, APEC, which account for half of all global trade consists of these members: Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, the Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Taiwan and Thailand. During the Malaysia meeting, APEC also will include three new members: Russia one of the latest victim of the financial crisis Vietnam and Peru. The agenda might be global, but the menu will be Malaysian when world leader meet next week for the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum. Pacific Rim leader, including US. President Bill Clinton, will sample local dish at a luncheon planned for the end of their two-day summit. It's expected to be a hot affair. Spicy delicacy on the menu are satay kajang, a beef or chicken kebab in peanut sauce; ayam percik, chicken curry with chilies; soto ayam, a Malaysian chicken soup, and fried rice village-style, the Star newspaper reported in Monday edition. Desert will be simple: fresh tropical fruit, said Maleia Marsden, general manager of the Cyberview Lodge, where the leader were expected to stay during the summit Nov. 17-18. APEC group Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, the Philippines, Singapore, Taiwan, Thailand and the United States. Russia, Vietnam and Peru will also join APEC this year.
