data: Blood and soot-blackened water ran in rivulet from the charred wreckage. A burly policeman bent to cover a bloodied corpse with whatever wa at hand a sodden piece of cardboard, a plastic shopping bag. Two people were killed and at least 21 injured when an explosives-rigged car blew up Friday at Jerusalem's Mahane Yehuda market, only meter (yards) from the site of a suicide bombing 16 month ago. At police barricade set up along Jerusalem's busiest thoroughfare, soldier and police held back crowd of people, some frantic about loved one who had been shopping in the crowded market only hour before the start of the Jewish Sabbath. Please, please, is there a girl with red hair who is hurt? an older, heavyset woman said tearfully, trying to push her way past police. A young female soldier patted her arm consolingly. Some of the onlooker gave vent to fury over the new peace agreement, which wa being debated by Israel's Cabinet even a the blast occurred. Death to Arabs! Death to Arafat! a small crowd of demonstrator shouted. Police tried to grab one of them, but he escaped into the crowd. The explosives-rigged car wa a mass of twisted metal, with only the steering column intact. Next to the wreckage lay a completely charred body with stump of arm and leg apparently that of the bomber. Witnesses said they heard a series of explosion. Although shop window closest to the car were shattered, market stall only a few more foot (yards) away were completely intact, and stacked with neat pile of banana and onion. Eyewitness Yaakov Shlomo said initial, smaller blast scared most onlooker away. When the big explosion went, there were already not that many people nearby, he said. That wa a miracle from heaven. Shlomo Meir, a black-clad Orthodox Jew, wa standing nearby when he heard a blast. When he tuirned he saw fire. It wa terrible, he said, red-eyed. I thought, `Again!' Only a block away, some stall were still open and shopper were buying produce. One woman, with almost maniacal determination, sorted through a pile of orange. We can't stop what we're doing when this happens, she said grimly. By the police barricade, wearing bright-orange vest, stood a group of Orthodox Jewish volunteer who search scene of accident and attack for body part, in keeping with their religious belief that body must be buried intact. One young volunteer squinted down the street a his group waited for permission to begin it grisly task. It's hard, this work, but it's very important to u, he said. A defiant Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Saturday that Israel would continue to build Jewish neighborhood throughout Jerusalem, including at a controversial site in the traditionally Arab sector of the city. We will build also in Har Homa a we will build in every part of Jerusalem, Netanyahu told a crowd of political supporter in Jerusalem, By 2000 there will be home at Har Homa. Har Homa is the site of a planned Jewish neighborhood in traditionally Arab east Jerusalem, which Palestinians want to have a the capital of their hoped-for independent state. Groundbreaking at the site led to angry Palestinian protest and a breakdown of peace talk in March 1997. Netanyahu's Cabinet delayed action on the latest Israeli-Palestinian accord following Friday's suicide bombing at a Jerusalem market, and his remark about building on Har Homa may be seen a a provocation by the Palestinians at a politically sensitive moment. US. Secretary of State Madeleine Albright told Netanyahu by phone that she expects Israel's Cabinet to ratify the new peace accord within a few day despite the market bombing, Channel Two television reported Saturday. The radical group Islamic Jihad claimed responsibility Saturday for the market bombing and vowed more attack to try to block the new peace accord. This heroic operation is not the first and not going to be the last, the group said in a leaflet faxed to news organization. We refuse any political agreement that would recognize the Zionist enemy. An Islamic Jihad official in the Syrian capital of Damascus confirmed that the group's leader Ramadan Abdullah Shallah claimed responsibility for Friday's bombing in an interview with the Paris-based Radio Monte Carlo. Palestinian security source and the family of the dead bomber had already identified them a Islamic Jihad activist. At least half a dozen other Islamic activist have been rounded up since the bombing, the source said. Palestinian political leader said Israel should not use Friday's suicide bombing, which killed the two assailant and wounded 21 Israelis, a an excuse to stop the peace process. One of Israel's key demand is that the Palestinians do more to fight attack by Islamic militant against Israeli target. The Palestinians, however, said the two bomber had come from Israeli-controlled area and that Israel thus bore at least part of the security responsibility for the attack. The Israeli military said it could not confirm the suicide bombers' identity and hometown, but they were disclosed by Palestinian security official and also reported by Palestinian medium. One lived near the Anata refugee camp, north of Jerusalem, and the other lived in the West Bank village of Silat al Harithiya, outside the town of Jenin. Both family held so-called mourning house on Saturday, but not actual funeral, since Israeli authority still have their body. The family of Suleiman Musa Dahayneh, 24, said he had been married for three month to Zughayar's sister, Basma. They met when she wa visiting her brother, who wa in prison with Dahayneh, the family said. Israel's Cabinet announced within hour of a market bombing Friday that it will put off a vote indefinitely on whether to ratify the Wye River accord until Palestinians crack down further on terrorism. Israel radio said the 18-member Cabinet debate on the Wye River accord would resume only after Yasser Arafat's Palestinian Authority fulfilled all of it commitment under the agreement, including arresting Islamic militant. The Cabinet also insisted that Arafat convene the Palestinian National Council, a parliament in exile, to abrogate the Palestinian National Charter, which call for Israel's destruction. The Israeli Cabinet had convened for a second day in an attempt to approve the Wye agreement. To our sorrow, since the Wye agreement . there ha been relentless terrorist attack against Israeli citizen, according to a Cabinet statement read on the radio. Israel radio quoted official saying the Cabinet would also decide to renew construction of the Har Homa neighborhood in the traditionally Arab sector of Jerusalem. Groundbreaking there in March 1997 led to a break-off in negotiation with the Palestinians. The militant Palestinian movement Islamic Holy War said Saturday that it carried out the suicide bombing in a Jerusalem market on Friday, which prompted arrest by the Palestinian Authority overnight. Palestinian official said they had jailed several of the small but radical group's member from the West Bank, and raided and then shut down a nursery school linked to the organization in Bethlehem, which is controlled by the Palestinians. The two bomber who carried out Friday's attack, which led the Israeli Cabinet to suspend deliberation on the land-for-security accord signed with the Palestinians last month, were identified a member of Islamic Holy War from West Bank village under Israeli security control. Ramadan Abdallah Shallah, the Damascus-based leader of Islamic Holy War, said martyr from his movement had carried out the Jerusalem attack in response to Israel's settlement policy and Judaization of the West Bank. He spoke in an interview with Monte Carlo Radio, an Arabic station broadcasting from Paris that is widely listened to in the Middle East. A leaflet signed by the group and faxed to Reuters in Jerusalem said the heroic attack, in which 24 people were injured and the 2 bomber killed, had been carried out to confront the great conspiracy that aim to liquidate the Palestinian cause through the Oslo and Wye Plantation agreement of submission. Islamic Holy War and it counterpart, Hamas, have denounced a a sellout of Palestinian right the 1993 Oslo self-rule accord and the latest agreement, known a the Wye Memorandum, named for the Wye Plantation in Maryland, where the deal wa worked out with strenuous American mediation. Shallah's claim of responsibility from abroad contrasted with the muted response of Islamic Holy War's leadership in the Gaza Strip, which ha reportedly given commitment to the Palestinian Authority to refrain from such attack. We have no knowledge in the movement about the operation that occurred in Jerusalem, said Nafez Azzam, a senior leader of Islamic Holy War in Gaza. From it condition we consider it likely that it wa an individual effort. The Palestinian cabinet, in a statement issued after a meeting on Friday night, accused foreign force of standing behind the attack. One cabinet member, who declined to be identified, pointed a finger at Iran, saying a search of one bomber's home had uncovered a letter he had written to the Iranian supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, expressing condolence for the recent killing of several Iranian diplomat in Afghanistan. The Palestinian cabinet promised to crack down on the militant, who it said were jeopardizing the recovery of Palestinian land and hope for statehood by giving Israel a pretext to postpone carrying out the Wye accord. The Israeli Cabinet suspended a meeting to ratify the agreement after the bombing, demanding that the Palestinians conduct an all-out war on terror. Israeli official had no comment Saturday on the measure taken by the Palestinian Authority on Friday. The Wye agreement call for an Israeli troop withdrawal from 13 percent more of the West Bank in exchange for specific Palestinian measure against violent militant. A Palestinian security official said several Islamic Holy War member were arrested in the West Bank on Friday night. Arrests were also reported in the Gaza Strip. Itaf Alayan, a supporter of the group who run the Islamic Purity Nursery in Bethlehem, said Palestinian officer had raided the school and confiscated videotape and educational cassette before locking it up. The two bomber were identified a Youssef Zughayer, 21, from Anata, near Jerusalem, and his brother-in-law, Suleiman Tahayneh, 24, from Silat al-Harithiya, near the West Bank town of Jenin. Both had served time in Israeli jail and were known to be member of Islamic Holy War. We never thought he would do something like this, said Muhammad Zughayer, Youssef's father. We condemn such act, but the only thing we can do now is to say may he rest in peace. On a warm, sunny morning last Friday, at the time he usually left for work at his family's produce store, Youssef Sughayer said goodbye to his grandmother for the last time and rode off to his death. Relatives say that the 21-year-old Palestinian from this village near Jerusalem showed no sign that he wa heading for a suicide mission with his brother-in-law a part of a secret cell of Islamic Holy War. Their car-bomb blew apart two hour later in a Jerusalem market, killing both men and wounding 24 people. Don't grieve for me, he wrote in a farewell note, according to relative who found it later. If you cry, cry with happiness that I'm a martyr. Don't serve bitter coffee, serve sweet. I'm going to Paradise. At the family's stone house outside Jerusalem on Sunday, visitor paying condolence call were served sweet juice, not coffee, a Sughayer's relative tried to make sense of what he had done. The young man, once an ace student, had come of age in Israeli prison. Jailed for a year at age 15 for stoning Israeli car during the riot of the Palestinian uprising, he wa imprisoned again at 17, that time for three-and-a-half year for similar offense and affiliation with Islamic Holy War. Relatives said he wa an impressionable teen-ager, influenced by Islamic militant with whom he wa jailed. Sughayer came out of prison more devout, and hardened by mistreatment at the hand of the Israelis, relative said. His cellmates taught him the doctrine of holy war and about the glory of martyrdom, said an older brother, Samih Sughayer. They sowed it in his heart, he said. He wanted to be a martyr in the cause of God. But that reality, suddenly so clear Sunday, wa not so apparent when Sughayer wa freed seven month ago. He seemed normal, said his brother. He went to work at the grocery store, he finished his high school class and he wanted to enroll in the university. He wa supposed to take a driving test in a few day. If he wa planning something, we didn't see it. He would stay up late at night after work, studying the Koran and praying, but he showed no outward sign of rage toward Israel. He would joke about thing and say that whatever happens is God's will, said a brother-in-law, who insisted on anonymity. He wa an easygoing guy. Last Thursday, Sughayer bought a battered red Fiat and parked it near his house. When someone at home asked about the car he said nothing, and family member assumed it wa one of the stolen vehicle often found here. On Friday morning he left with the car, meeting his brother-in-law and old jail buddy, Suleiman Tahayneh, who came from his village near the West Bank town of Jenin. Tahayneh had his own score to settle with the Israelis. His leg had been amputated after he wa shot in a confrontation with Israeli troop during the uprising, his relative said. The Fiat wa loaded with explosive, and the two men drove to the market. That evening, when concerned member of the Sughayer family gathered to await news of their missing relative, a man arrived and told them that he had sold his car to Youssef the previous day. It wa a red Fiat, the same car they had seen near the house, and the same type of car that news report said had exploded in the marketplace. At midnight, Israeli security force raided the house and interrogated family member. The last, grim piece of the puzzle fell into place. Up to the last minute on Thursday night we were talking together, said Sughayer's oldest brother, Ali, who worked with him past midnight at the produce store. He asked me about someone who had moved his hardware shop to another village, about how he wa doing. Earlier we ate together, and we talked about giving charity to the poor. He wasn't nervous. He had plan for the future, Ali continued. Maybe the people in his group convinced him to do this, and he could not refuse. We did not expect this from him. A car rigged with explosive blew up Friday morning in Jerusalem's Mahane Yehuda market packed with Israelis shopping for the Jewish Sabbath, killing two people and wounding 21. The Islamic militant group Hamas, which ha tried to stop the peace agreement, claimed responsibility, police said. In response to the attack, the Israeli cabinet suspended ratification of the Wye agreement until there is verification that the Palestinian authority is indeed fighting terrorism. The Israeli Cabinet also announced it will begin to build house in the controversial Jewish settlement of Har Homa in east Jerusalem. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu had held up the work in recent month in an apparent attempt to not disrupt negotiation with the Palestinians. Aides to Netanyahu were not immediately available for comment. The Cabinet minister had just begun a second day of of talk on the peace agreement about a mile (kilometer) away from the entrance to the market and just meter (yards) from the site of a suicide bombing last year. In Friday's explosion, the rigged car, a red Fiat, blew up at about 9:45 am. (0745 GMT) at the entrance of Mahane Yehuda market, just meter (yards) away from the site of a suicide bombing in July 1997. Witnesses heard a series of small explosion. Yair Cohen, 43, said he wa buying cooky when he saw a car driving slowly, with smoke coming out of the hood and exhaust pipe. People started to shout `car on fire.' After a while, we heard a blast, and something hit me in the stomach, said Cohen who wa treated for minor injury at Hadassah Hospital. The car wa a mass of twisted metal sitting in the middle of the main intersection outside the market. Flames shot 100 foot (30 meter) in the air. A charred corpse, covered by a blanket, lay several meter away. Streams of soot-black water ran in the street. There wa hysteria, people were running, said Eliad Duan, an Israeli border policeman who wa patrolling the market and wa lightly injured. One heavy-set woman, apparently in shock, climbed into an ambulance, weeping. Three paramedic talked to her, persuading her that she did not need medical treatment, and after a few moment she climbed out of the vehicle again. Soldiers and police wearing plastic glove held back the crowd. It's dangerous stay back! they shouted. Just a block away from the blast, shopper went about their business. This is a crime and whoever commits this, hurt the interest of the Palestinian people. The leaflet could not immediately be authenticated, but it style wa consistent with that of past communication from the group. An Islamic Jihad official in the Syrian capital of Damascus confirmed that the group's leader Ramadan Abdullah Shallah claimed responsibility for Friday's bombing in an interview with the Paris-based Radio Monte Carlo. Palestinian security source and the family of the dead bomber had already identified them a Islamic Jihad activist. At least half a dozen other Islamic activist have been rounded up since the bombing, the source said. Although Hamas initially claimed responsibility through anonymous phone call to the police, all side now have agreed that it wa Islamic Jihad that carried it out. There wa no immediate explanation for the inaccurate claim, but the two group have carried out attack together in the past a part of their goal of stopping the peace process. Setting the stage for a new quarrel over how to crack down on militant, Israel is demanding that the military wing of two radical Islamic group be outlawed, while the Palestinian Authority insists it ha already banned them. Implementation of the Israeli-Palestinian land-for-security accord, signed Oct. 23 in Washington, wa to have begun this past week, but ha hit various snag. Most recently, Israel's Cabinet put off a vote to ratify the accord after a suicide bombing Friday in Jerusalem that killed the two assailant and injured 21 Israelis. The radical group Islamic Jihad claimed responsibility. David Bar-Illan, a top aide to Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, said Sunday that Israel expects Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat to formally outlaw the military wing of Islamic Jihad and the larger militant group Hamas. Hassan Asfour, a senior Palestinian official, said Hamas' military wing, Izeddine al Qassam, and the military wing of Islamic Jihad were outlawed by the Palestinian Authority in 1996. But Bar-Illan said the Palestinian legislature had never passed such a law. Why did Mr. Arafat agree in the Wye accord to outlaw them if he ha already done it? he asked. The Wye memorandum state that the Palestinian Authority will inform the United States fully of the action it ha taken to outlaw all organization (or wing of organization, a appropriate) of a military, terrorist or violent character, and their support structure and to prevent them freedom of action in the area under it jurisdiction. A Palestinian security official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said a joint Israeli-Palestinian meeting wa held Saturday night to discus security in the wake of Friday's attack. Participants included the head of the Palestinian intelligence, Amin Hindi, and the head of preventive security in the Gaza Strip, Mohammed Dahlan. The idea of outlawing Hamas and Islamic Jihad wa brought up in the meeting and also proposed by Netanyahu to Arafat during a phone call, the official said. The Palestinians said they could ban activity by Hamas or Islamic Jihad that endangered either Israelis or Palestinians, but could not outlaw them outright a political movement. Friday's bombing led to finger-pointing by both side. Israel said it showed Arafat's crackdown on terrorist had not been sweeping enough. The Palestinians, however, have also accused Israel of failing to take at least partial security responsibility for the attack, because both attacker came from Israeli-controlled area, and had recently served time in Israeli jail. Israel a a rule is harshly critical of the Palestinian Authority's security effort when attacker come from Palestinian-controlled area or have been released from Palestinian prison. On Sunday, Palestinian Justice Minister Freih Abu-Medein accused Netanyahu of using the blast a a pretext for delaying implementation of the peace accord. This attack is a gift to Mr. Netanyahu, Abu-Medein said. All the time he is praying to God to help him . to escape from the agreement. Under the accord, Israel is to hand over another 13 percent of the territory in the West Bank to the Palestinians in exchange for various security step. Israeli Defense Minister Yitzhak Mordechai predicted Sunday that the Israeli Cabinet would ratify the agreement in coming day. I estimate that the government will meet this week and will accept the decision of the majority (in favor of the agreement), he said.

data: BRUSSELS, Belgium (AP) - The European Union on Friday expressed it deep concern over report of physical abuse of Malaysia's former deputy-prime minister, Anwar Ibrahim, who wa arrested last month. The EU urge the Malaysian authority to ensure that similar incident will not occur again in the future and that Anwar Ibrahim be assured correct treatment while in custody, a statement by the 15 EU country said. The EU hope that appropriate action will be taken against any individual, including official, found responsible for such mistreatment, the statement added. On Sept. 2, Malaysia's Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad fired Anwar, calling him morally unfit for office. Mahathir and Anwar had differed over economic policy and Anwar say Mahathir feared him a an alternative leader. Anwar mounted a nationwide campaign against the prime minister before being detained a a national security risk and charged with illegal homosexual act and corruption in connection with those allegation. Earlier this week, Anwar appeared in court with a black eye and bruise on his neck and arm. He told the magistrate's court he wa beaten by police on Sept. 20, the night of his arrest. Faced with mounting public criticism, Mahathir called Thursday for a probe by the attorney general of the alleged mistreatment of Anwar. The EU statement welcomed the opening of this investigation. It also welcomed the release of seven youth leader, including Ahmad Zahid Hamidi, the head of the youth wing of the ruling United Malays National Organization and a former ally of Anwar, who were arrested last week in connection with demonstration in favor of the ousted deputy-premier. The EU express hope that the other political demonstrator still detained under the Internal Security Act will also be released soon, the statement said. The former deputy-premier, who wa also finance minister, pleaded innocent this week to charge of sodomy and corruption. A number of Anwar's associate are still detained. The leader of Malaysia's ruling party met Tuesday to discus a replacement for ousted deputy prime minister Anwar Ibrahim, who face trial next month in a case that will test the country's legal system. Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, 72, said last week he could drop dead at any time. But because of the large number of candidate for the deputy's job within the ruling United Malays National Organization, a decision wa not expected quickly. The party leader, who have been conducting a national campaign to explain to Malaysians why the popular Anwar wa fired Sept. 2, will also confer on what to do now that the High Court judge ha banned all comment on Anwar's guilt or innocence. The ruling coalition had scheduled a giant rally in the capital Saturday, aimed at drawing in the youth to whom Anwar's campaign of reform ha the most appeal. Mahathir, who had heart bypass surgery in 1989, had groomed Anwar, 51, a his successor. But he fired his protege from his post a deputy prime minister and finance minister on ground he wa morally unfit to lead. The two had differed over economic policy and Anwar ha said Mahathir feared he wa a threat to his 17-year rule. Anwar wa also dumped from the ruling party, and after two week of nationwide rally at which he called for government reform and Mahathir's resignation, he wa arrested under a law that allows police to hold him indefinitely, and prevent him from seeing his family and lawyer. On Tuesday, Mahathir denounced demonstrator who had flocked by the thousand to the street of downtown Kuala Lumpur in recent week, calling them part of a plot to topple the government. Baton-wielding riot police had dispersed the crowd with tear gas and water cannon, arresting more than 100 people. They decided that the government should be brought down through demonstration, riot, the Bernama news agency quoted Mahathir a saying in Sarawak state on Borneo Island. He wa expected to return to Kuala Lumpur later Tuesday to chair the UMNO meeting. After Anwar appeared in court with a black eye, bruised face, neck and arm, his case drew international attention, particularly from the president of the Philippines and Indonesia, who have raised the possibility they might not attend an 18-nation summit in Malaysia next month. The United States would downgrade President Bill Clinton's visit to Kuala Lumpur next month if Anwar continued to be mistreated, the Wall Street Journal quoted an official in Washington a saying. Clinton is scheduled to go to Malaysia for the meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum. Wearing a neck brace Monday after a court-ordered hospital checkup, Anwar wa ordered to stand trial Nov. 2 on four charge of abusing his power to interfere with a police investigation. His trial is to halt on Nov. 14 and resume after the APEC meeting. He ha pleaded innocent to all charge, including another corruption count and five charge of sodomy. He face 14 year in prison and a fine on each corruption count and 20 year, plus whipping, on each sexual charge, if convicted. Anwar wa arrested Sept. 20 under the Internal Security Act, which allows jail without trial. Hunger and malnutrition in Cambodia are reaching crisis level comparable to the effect of famine in North Korea, a UN. World Food Program representative said Tuesday. Though North Korea is suffering from a simple lack of food, a faltering economy in Cambodia combined with weak health care and education is causing similar level of malnutrition in child, said Ken Davies, the WFP's country director. There is enough rice. The problem is that people are too poor to access it. The problem is poverty, Davies said. The WFP is currently supporting 1.7 million hungry Cambodians about 15 percent of the population with food-for-work and direct assistance program, but Davies said he fear there are still plenty more that are not getting enough to eat every day. The problem is so bad that it is only a little worse in North Korea, Davies said. The situation is much worse than most people recognize. According to a recent WFP survey, 49 percent of Cambodian child under age 5 are stunted by lack of food and 20 percent suffer from acute malnutrition. By comparison, a similar survey of North Korean child under 7 found that 65 percent are stunted and 16 percent suffer from acute malnutrition. Cambodia ha produced a rice surplus for export in the last two year and expects another this year, but WFP statistic show that 25 percent of rice-growing area account for 75 percent of the surplus. The majority of Cambodian farmer are not producing enough to keep their family fed and are being increasingly saddled with debt incurred when they run out of reserve before harvest, Davies said. This mean a high likelihood of impaired mental and physical development, because the nervous system matures dramatically during this essential first year. The researcher said that available scientific data suggest that 10 year ago, malnutrition wa rare in North Korea. Even if the situation improves, it is unlikely to improve to the degree that the country will fully recover from what we saw, said Judit Katona-Apte, a senior program adviser for the World Food Program. People will be small and not a well developed a otherwise and somewhat limited in their mental capacity. Likewise, when Red Cross representative this year tested the water supply at the 840 hospital and clinic where they operate, they found that not one had water that wa suitable for human consumption, said Sten Swedlund, head of the Red Cross delegation in North Korea. But of course they drink it they have no choice, he said during a recent trip to Beijing. There is a very close relationship between the problem caused by the lack of food and a health sector that's in very bad shape. Virtually all the child under 7 who are malnourished also have diarrhea, he said. Liquidity problem at Bangkok Land, the company that owns the housing estate, threatened to prevent the company from finishing the complex in time for the Dec. 6-20 game. Deputy Prime Minister Bhichai Rattakul, who chair the organizing committee, expressed doubt last month that the complex would be completed on time because of the financial problem. Santiparb told the Post the money problem had been overcome by shifting 200 million baht (dlrs 5 million) worth of credit guarantee from a project that had been scrapped to cover the construction cost of the complex. Preparations for the game have been plagued by political interference by previous government, alleged corruption and incompetence. The decision to award the contract for the sport complex wa controversial, with critic calling it an attempt to bail out the property developer's failed housing estate. Doubts over Thailand's ability to stage the game increased over the past year-and-a-half after the country entered it worst economic downturn in decade. The body governing the game threatened several time to award Asia's version of the Olympics to other country, but Thailand argued that all would be ready by opening day. The Bangkok game are expected to attract more than 10,000 athlete from 43 nation. For some team, out of bound at the Asian Games mean more than just a line on a soccer field or basketball floor. That's because the host city offer the punchy mix of Viagra and notorious night life. The Pakistanis say all their athlete and official for the game opening Sunday have been told not to even think of the wonder drug and night life idea. The Indian team's solution is mandatory meeting for all athlete before bedtime. The Sri Lankan participant, who had to sign a code of conduct before coming to Bangkok, are being watched by an army brigadier with a track record of high discipline. The Chinese have done their homework on staying out of trouble. Thailand, especially the capital Bangkok, is known worldwide for it titillating night life. From taxi driver to local tourist magazine distributed free at hotel, there are messenger aplenty to advertise massage parlor and escort service. Minutely detailed photo album seek to arouse sensual fantasy. Estimates of the number of female sex worker in Thailand, a country of 60 million, range from more than 300,000 to 2 million. Under Thailand's drug rule, Viagra is not available in drug store, but is sold only in hospital pharmacy with a prescription from a urologist, cardiologist, endocrinologist or psychiatrist for 400 baht (about dlrs 10) a dose. But there is a black market in the drug that might prove an attraction for some among the more than 15,000 athlete, official and medium personnel in Bangkok. No way, said Gurdayal Singh Mander, leader of the Indian contingent, when asked if there wa a risk of lack in discipline. I believe no one will try anything silly in Bangkok. Even if they try, our watching system is watertight and we will know, said Mander, a former police officer. Indian official in charge of various sport meet their athlete at 10 pm. before bedtime at the Asian Games village. The Pakistanis have opted for trust and nationalism. Oh, Viagra, exclaimed Pakistani medical officer Yousef Baig. They know all about it and they know all about Bangkok. We have told them, don't break our trust and keep the good name of Pakistan flying high, Dr. Baig said. China ha taken a similar approach. We don't treat them a kid, telling them don't do this, don't do that. We just told them to leave a good impression of Chinese athlete, said Li Furong, deputy head of the Chinese delegation. For the Sri Lankans, we have told them that they will not be allowed outside the game village until they finish their discipline, said Upali Bandaratillaka, a serving brigadier in the Sri Lankan army. Even if they want to go to shopping, one of u will accompany them, Bandaratillaka said. His deputy is a police officer. Host Thailand is stressing that sex isn't lurking around every corner. A Traditional Thai Massage Parlor ha been opened at the games' village. Thai traditional massage is considered an art form, said Prarop Laovanich, secretary of the Asian Games Sub-Committee for Culture and Performance. A skilled masseur can cure ailment and muscular fatigue. And one must wear baggy white pajama before a traditional Thai massage. In rite building from low flare symbolizing dawn to a fiery cauldron lighting, Thailand's king opened the Asian Games Sunday night, giving Thais some respite from an economic crisis that once threatened the continent's Olympic-style event. King Bhumibol Adulyadej, the world's longest-reigning monarch, wa upstaged slightly by Japan's Naoko Takahashi. In a marathon run in early morning, to avoid the worst of Bangkok's tropical heat, she won the games' first gold medal in a time just one minute off the world record. Her medal ceremony immediately preceded the official opening festivity for two week of competition among 6,000 athlete from 41 nation. In all, 377 gold medal are at stake in 36 sport, including Asian speciality such a kabaddi and sepak takraw. But the king not only made the key proclamation and released the royal pigeon, he also anointed a plaque for the Royal Main Stadium and composed some of the music. Songs written by the king, a talented jazz composer, were played by the Bangkok Symphony Orchestra. Thai official who approached him at the ceremony did so on their knee. Others greeting the king included International Olympic Committee President Juan Antonio Samaranch. A cascade of firework in honor of his 71st birthday Saturday and dancer who prostrated themselves on the field welcomed the monarch to his seat in the royal box. Then came the athlete, starting with Cambodia and ending with the host Thai team. Saudi Arabia, which withdrew it team at the last minute, wa represented by only a flag bearer. The Sri Lankan team wa led by six dancer in bright costume, who delighted the crowd in the 60,000-seat stadium with acrobatic maneuver. Each team wa led by a Thai beauty queen holding it signboard. After the parade, five of the woman collapsed, and three were taken out on stretcher. A giant cauldron atop the stadium wa lit by touching a torch to a smaller cauldron inside a model of a temple, which then wa lifted on an elevator and sent an explosion of spark into the games' flame receptacle. Outside the stadium before the ceremony, long line of people waited to take photo of themselves in front of a plastic statue of the games' elephant mascot, Chai-yo. One, Sakchai Pungsrinon, a 30-year-old piping engineer, who paid 1,000 baht (dlrs 26) for his ceremony ticket, said, Thailand ha many problem. Asia also ha many problem. For two week, maybe we can forget about all these problem. Several thousand people without ticket milled around outside, waving small Thai flag and waiting for a glimpse of the king. They also could watch the ceremony on a large television screen. Security measure included bomb-sniffing dog. For the competing nation many sending reduced team to ease the pinch of the Asian crisis the game are a proving ground for the 2000 Olympics in Sydney, Australia. It's not just getting a gold, it's getting a gold with a result that is close or at world standard, said Li Furong, deputy head of China's Asian Games delegation. The main target is the 2000 Olympics. Sunday's focus wa more on pageantry, beginning with slightly built Prime Minister Chuan Leekpai leading off a torch relay at 9:09 am. (0209 GMT), reflecting popular belief that nine is a lucky number. Bhumibol is the ninth king of the current dynasty. The three-hour ceremony featured 7,614 performer in lavishly produced act with the theme Friendship Beyond Frontiers. Performers in ancient Thai garb paraded across the field, followed by people-drawn chariot. A martial art display celebrated Asian unity, and hundred of primary school student dressed in colorful outfit introduced the games' mascot. Parts of the ceremony were built around the Indian Ramayana epic, the basis for much of traditional Thai mythology, literature and performing and fine art. The field became a swirl of giant snake, swan, bird, angel, and other mystical creature. Another performance celebrating the unity of Asia capped the show, with four large swan float pulled to the middle of the field, each tethered to a giant balloon symbolizing the sun, moon, earth and a giant lotus. Fireworks burst overhead, searchlight played across the stadium and laser split the darkness before the royal anthem concluded the program. The combined budget for the opening and closing ceremony wa 70 million baht (dlrs 1.94 million), including a large share of donated and at-cost labor part of Thailand's remedy for overcoming financial problem that hit the game. In warming up the audience before the ceremony, a Thai comedian jested: If you're Saudi, raise your hand. Saudi Arabia withdrew from the game at the last minute, throwing some of the scheduling into disarray. It cited a national holiday and the Muslim fasting month of Ramadan, but many Thais saw the move a retaliation for the failure of Thai police to solve a number of serious crime against Saudi citizen. Thailand showed it nearly complete facility for the Asian Games to a tough jury Thursday the head of the organizing committee from the 43 nation competing in the December event. Thailand won host right for the quadrennial game in 1995, but setback in preparation led official of the Olympic Council of Asia late last year to threaten to move the game to another country. They complained that the Thai organizer were behind in constructing facility and had failed to keep them informed. It appeared that Thursday's tour wa successful in reassuring everyone. We have a strong of sense of relief, said Abdul Muttaleb al-Ahmad, director general of the Kuwait-based Olympic Council of Asia and a frequent critic of Thailand's organizing committee. Everything is 99 percent completed. In a welcoming speech, Thai Deputy Prime Minister Bhichai Rattakul, also chairman of the Thai organizing committee, told delegation member to cast aside any doubt over whether the Dec. 6-20 game will be a success. I can hereby confirm that regardless of what Thailand ha faced, we . have tried to accommodate all request for the 13th Asian Games, said Bhichai. Since the Thai organizer began their preparation, they have faced many difficulty, most of them resulting from the country's financial crisis, he said. But the country wa able to pull it through, he added. This is an example of Asia's resiliency. We have financial problem in all of Asia but still we are able to prepare commendably, said Manuel Veguillas, head of the Philippine delegation. I am impressed, said Tu Mingde, secretary-general of China's Olympic Committee. The game will be a success. Still, Bangkok's infamous traffic jam did not go overlooked. My only concern now is the road construction leading to the site, said Kenji Ono from Japan. Construction worker are trying to ensure that the road leading to the stadium, including a flyover at a key intersection, will be completed on time for the game. The Olympic Council of Asia, meanwhile, is working with the Bangkok Organizing Committee to come up with a contingency plan in case of any possible emergency, said it director general, Muttaleb. You cannot really anticipate anything, he said, a he toured the main stadium of the Sports Authority of Thailand. Any venue can have a problem, such a electrical failure. Saudi Arabia's abrupt withdrawal from the Asian Games left organizer scrambling Thursday to change schedule and Thai diplomat mulling a decade of relation strained by jewel theft and the murder of diplomat. Bhichai Rattakul, deputy prime minister and president of the Bangkok Asian Games Organizing Committee, asked the Foreign Ministry to urge the Saudi government to reconsider withdrawing it 105-strong team. The game open Dec. 6. We're not sure if this is related to the Saudi jewel scandal, Bhichai told Thai radio. But regardless, we should not mix sport with politics. In a letter to the Thai prime minister's office, reported Thursday by Bangkok newspaper, Saudi sport authority cited the looming Muslim holy month of Ramadan and national centenary celebration a reason for suddenly pulling out. But suspicion immediately arose that the real reason wa the continued strain in relation since a Thai janitor stole precious jewelry from the palace of a Saudi prince in 1989 and fled home. Thai police recovered the jewel and returned them, but many were fake leading the Saudis to conclude that corrupt officer and member of Thailand's power elite kept the loot. The real jewel have never been recovered. Tensions were aggravated in 1990 and 1991, when three Saudi diplomat were murdered in Bangkok. In retaliation, the Saudis barred new Thai guest worker and refused to renew the visa of the thousand already in the desert kingdom. The killing remain unsolved. Saudi Arabia ha said relation would be normalized only when the two case were solved. Kobsak Chutikul, a Foreign Ministry spokesman, said it would be understandable if Saudi Arabia pull out because of Ramadan fasting. If there is any other reason behind this, such a the jewelry case and the murder, we will regret it very much because sport should be separated from politics, Kobsak said. Organizers noted that 10 other Muslim nation are sending team. Suggestions were made that in the future, the Olympic Council of Asia should consider punishing last-minute withdrawal. Organizers need to hold new draw for both handball and basketball because of the pullout, but said the live television coverage schedule will not be affected. The withdrawal is expected to cost 30 million baht (dlrs 830,000) to cover the committee's expense for organizing program, accommodation and television schedule. They said they would consult with the council, which oversees the organization of the game, about the impact of the Saudi withdrawal. Officials, meanwhile, expressed shock over a brawl that erupted Tuesday during a friendly soccer match between Thailand and Qatar. The scoreless match wa suspended without further play after player from both side kicked, punched and body-slammed each other for about 10 minute. Several suffered light injury. As a host, surely the melee will have an impact on the image and reputation of Thailand, said Santiparb Tejavanija, chairman of the administrative committee. Nobody wanted that incident to happen. Officials said that forgiveness wa a better option than punishment and that both side would be admonished not to let a repeat brawl occur. A snooker game between longtime Asian rival India and Pakistan led to a flareup of temper Sunday, showing a depth of difference that shocked Thai organizer and spectator at the Asian Games. India and Pakistan have fought three war since becoming independent in 1947. A Thai referee's decision that India's Yashin Merchant had committed a foul during a decisive frame sparked a fierce debate with the referee that forced stoppage of play for 15 minute. Merchant defeated Mohammad Saleh 5-4 after order wa restored, but the incident not only violated the sport's strict etiquette, but showed the distrust between the two neighbor that often ha spilled over into sport. The referee ruled that Merchant's white cue ball had first touched the black before hitting the target, red. Merchant protested. With the referee refusing to reverse his decision, Merchant sought help from the Indian team. Several Indian team member went to the playing arena, and one of them wrote a quick protest letter using the snooker table a a writing platform. Disgusted spectator viewed it a a breach of snooker etiquette. It doe not look nice for grownup men wearing necktie to fight, said Pakistani team manager Shahnawaz Khan. We just watched the whole drama, he said. Pakistani team official did not intervene, instead staying in their allocated seat. It wa made very clear to everybody that a referee's decision will be final, but now that the Indians have lodged a formal complaint, we have also done so, Khan said. The Indian complaint, however, ha no meaning now a Merchant ha won. Indian official were not available for comment. Tournament director Surasak Werapong said both complaint were thrown out because neither side paid the required dlrs 50 filing fee. The match wa one of the first a snooker made it Asian Games debut in style, with elated official greeting the opening with muffled clapping, in keeping with the sport's etiquette. A total of 19 country are vying for 10 gold medal in snooker and billiards. The preliminary elimination round began Sunday. This is the brightest day for u, said Manmohanjit Singh, the Singapore-born president of the International Billiards and Snooker Federation, the sport's world governing body. This is indeed a high step and this will greatly help to make the sport more popular in Asia, which is coming up fast, said Singh, whose family migrated to Singapore from India several decade ago. With the addition of snooker, the Asian Games now have 36 sport.

data: China's central government ordered the arrest of a prominent democracy campaigner and may use his contact with exiled Chinese dissident to charge him with harming national security, a colleague said Wednesday. Two Beijing police officer spent 30 minute telling Zha Jianguo to stop trying to set up a political opposition party. Underscoring the warning, they said his colleague, Xu Wenli, won't be released soon and may be charged for having link to reactionary group, Zha said. Xu and another influential dissident, Qin Yongmin, were arrested Monday night in police raid in two city that delivered the sternest blow so far to a five-month campaign to establish the China Democracy Party and challenge the ruling Communist Party's monopoly on power. Qin wa arrested for plotting to overthrow the government, a crime that could land him in jail for life. A third Democracy Party advocate, Wang Youcai, already in custody for a month, wa also formally arrested Monday although his family ha not been informed of the charge. Zha, who helped Xu organize would-be party member in Beijing and the nearby port of Tianjin, said police officer told him Xu's arrest wa ordered by the central government, not Beijing police. He took the police reference to reactionary group to mean exiled dissident in the United States. Under China's vague State Security Law, such link may also be punishable by up to life in prison. Zha pledged to work with dissident in China and exile in the United States to campaign to save Xu Wenli. On Wednesday, 190 dissident from around the country demanded in an open letter that the government release Xu, Qin and Wang Youcai, saying the arrest run counter to UN. human right treaty China ha signed over the past 14 month. The authority are deceiving and cheating international public opinion while on the other hand they are suppressing and persecuting domestic political dissident, said the letter faxed to foreign news agency. In Washington, White House spokesman Joe Lockhart said the United States deplored the detention and arrest of Xu and Qin. We believe the peaceful political activity of this kind and other form of peaceful expression that they've been involved in are fundamental human right that should be protected by all government, Lockart said. We call on the Chinese government to assure the protection in these case of Mr. Xu and Mr. Qin. State Department spokesman James P. Rubin said US. official conveyed their concern to the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs and urged that Xu be released immediately. US. official received confirmation Wednesday that Xu is being detained on suspicion of having conducted activity damaging to China's national security, Rubin said. He said he had no information from Chinese authority about Qin or Wang. Two other democracy party supporter taken into custody in central Wuhan city along with Qin Chen Zhonghe and Xiao Shichang were released Wednesday morning, said He Xintong, Xu Wenli's wife. She added that police questioned the pair about the party a well a Qin's human right monitoring organization. Qin and Xu are towering figure in China's persecuted dissident community. Their activism date to the seminal Democracy Wall movement of the 1970s. Wang wa a student leader in 1989's influential Tiananmen Square democracy movement. All have spent time in prison, Xu for 12 year, much of it in solitary confinement. Xu's wife said she doe not know where he is being held and, in her 20-year experience with the authority, belief they are unlikely to tell her. Released in 1993, Xu picked up his campaigning for political change soon after his parole ended last year. He ha tried to use China's nascent legal system and the international treaty it signed to push for reform. My husband is innocent and there's nothing he can be criticized for, said his wife, He Xintong. They're going to have to expend a lot of effort to make him a criminal. One leader of a suppressed new political party will be tried on Dec. 17 on a charge of colluding with foreign enemy of China to incite the subversion of state power, according to court document given to his wife on Monday. The decision to try the leader, Wang Youcai, a founder of the China Democracy Party, with unusual speed suggests how serious the Communist authority are in their campaign to destroy the fledgling party and silence dissident who had begun to speak out over the last year. The charge that Wang face, in a trial that will almost certainly be secret and quick, could bring a sentence of five year or more. Wang, 32, ha been imprisoned in his home city, Hangzhou in eastern China, for a month, but wa not formally arrested until Nov. 30. On that day two prominent dissident, both promoter of the new party, were detained. One, Qin Yongmin, 45, of the central city of Wuhan, and the other, Xu Wenli, 55, of Beijing, are being held on suspicion of subversive activity. Detailed charge have not been filed. Wang wa a student leader in the pro-democracy demonstration in Tiananmen Square in 1989. After the army had crushed the movement, Wang wa arrested and served two year in prison. Qin and Xu became known a democracy advocate in the late 1970s. Qin wa imprisoned for eight year. In 1993 he wa put in a labor camp for two year. Xu spent 12 year in prison. When President Clinton visited in the spring, Wang announced the formation of the Democracy Party. He and other dissident hoped that China's new friendship with the United States and it decision to sign a global covenant on political and civil right would give them room to promote political alternative. After Clinton returned home Wang wa detained, warned and released, only to be re-arrested a authority began what now appears to be a major crackdown on dissent. Monday, Wang's wife, Hu Jiangxia, wa handed the bill of prosecution, according to the Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in Hong Kong. Wang is charged with helping draft a party manifesto that state, in part, Only by establishing an opposition party can we be rid of this despotism. That is cited a ground for the subversion charge, the information center said. In addition to detailing Wang's organizing activity, the prosecutor charge that he colluded with enemy of the state abroad, making his crime far more serious under Chinese law. He used e-mail to send 18 copy of the party's founding document abroad, met with a member of a subversive foreign organization and received money from foreign source to buy a computer, the indictment reportedly say. China's government said Thursday that two prominent dissident arrested this week are suspected of endangering national security the clearest sign yet Chinese leader plan to quash a would-be opposition party. Foreign Ministry spokesman Zhu Bangzao refused to specify what law were broken or how Xu Wenli and Qin Yongmin endangered the state. A third leading advocate of the China Democracy Party who ha been in custody for a month, Wang Youcai, wa accused of inciting the overthrow of the government, the Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China reported. All three men could face up to life in prison if convicted of the harshest measure under China's vague state security law. The ruling Communist Party ha resorted to the law to silence dissent since it went into effect last year. The arrest of Xu and Qin at their home Monday night and the accusation against them and Wang were the sharpest action Chinese leader have taken since dissident began pushing to set up and legally register the China Democracy Party in June. Xu and Qin were suspected of involvement in activity endangering state security and their behavior breached relevant provision of the criminal law of the People's Republic of China, Zhu said at a twice-weekly briefing. Police in Hangzhou city notified Wang's wife Wednesday that charge have already been submitted to prosecutor, bringing him a step closer to trial, the Information Center said. Xu and Qin are influential figure in the dissident community, having started their campaign for change 20 year ago in the seminal Democracy Wall movement. Wang wa a student leader in the 1989 Tiananmen Square democracy demonstration. Both have served time in prison. Xu spent 12 year in jail, much of it in solitary confinement. Since dissident began organizing and trying to legally register the China Democracy Party, police have harassed and briefly detained more than two dozen member, but until now the government had not leveled such politically charged allegation. The Communist Party ha never allowed another political party to form since it took power in 1949. In Washington on Wednesday, White House spokesman Joe Lockhart said the United States deplored the arrest and said the dissidents' peaceful political activity were fundamental human right that all government should protect. US. official conveyed their concern to the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs and urged that Xu and Qin be released immediately. Zhu criticized the United States for condemning the arrest, saying that no country, including the United States, should interfere in China's internal affair. China in October signed a key UN. treaty on civil and political right that guarantee freedom of expression and freedom of association. It wa the 17th international human right treaty China ha signed. Zhu told reporter there wa absolutely no contradiction at all between China's support for these treaty and it arrest of the two dissident. In response to criticism from home and abroad, Chinese official broke their silence Wednesday to defend their arrest this week of a prominent dissident who wa trying to form an opposition political party. Xu Wenli is suspected of involvement in activity damaging to national security and ha violated relevant criminal code of the People's Republic of China, said a statement from the Foreign Ministry, which on Tuesday declined to comment on the arrest. The sudden arrest on Monday night of Xu, a well a several other activist involved with him in trying to form the China Democratic Party, set off strong protest from human right group, other Chinese dissident and Washington. We view his detention for peacefully exercising fundamental freedom guaranteed by international human right instrument a a serious step in the wrong direction, State Department spokesman James P. Rubin said in Washington on Tuesday. US. official in Beijing urged the government to release Xu and asked for clarification a to the exact nature of his crime. China signed the International Covenant of Civil and Political Rights with great fanfare in October, and Xu's arrest is seen by human right group a a test of the nation's commitment to it tenet. Dissidents in and out of China rose to Xu's defense, with more than a dozen activist around the country announcing that they would begin fast in support of Xu and another leader of the China Democratic Party, Qin Yongmin, who wa arrested in his home in Wuhan on Monday. Almost 200 dissident signed a letter to the Chinese government protesting the detention, said the Information Center for Human Rights and Democratic Movement in Hong Kong. Three other Democratic Party organizer were also detained on Monday, although two of them were released early Wednesday. But the two more prominent dissident, Xu and Qin, are likely to face a much longer haul since both have been charged with criminal act. Xu's wife, He Xintong, said Wednesday night that she had still not been informed of the specific charge against her husband, although she surmised from the aggressive behavior of the arresting officer that the sentence could be long. Qin's family wa told that he wa charged with plotting to subvert the government, a crime that for serious offense command sentence of three year to life. In the Chinese criminal code, this charge come under a grab-bag section called threatening state security, which make almost any political activity that question or hamper the authority of the Communist Party illegal, from violent or nonviolent activity aimed at overthrowing the government authority, to activity designed to change the basic nature of the state. Xu's and Qin's trouble almost certainly stem from their effort to gain recognition for the China Democratic Party, a loose network of pro-democracy activist in more than a dozen city around China that wa formed this year. In the last six month they have become increasingly aggressive and defiant in their attempt to register the party with the government, submitting repeated application even after local authority had declared the concept of an opposition party illegal. They say the Chinese Constitution doe not specifically forbid the formation of new political party, although there have been no new party since the founding of the People's Republic in 1949. In fact, the by-laws of the China Democratic Party are fairly tame; they carefully acknowledge the central role of the Communist Party, but also support free speech and free election for public official. My husband thought the time wa right to begin working to form a new party, since China recently signed the covenant on human right, Ms. He said. In September, a few Democratic Party member got some slightly encouraging signal from local government, which initially accepted their application to form a social organization to develop a party. But in recent week, a organizer like Xu became more insistent and defiant, harassment by the police increased. All this past week we felt something wa going to happen, Ms. He said. It seemed that anyone who came to visit u wa later detained for a while. And there have been a lot more car from the Public Security Bureau parked outside than is usual. Hours before China wa expected to sign a key UN. human right treaty and host British Prime Minister Tony Blair, police hauled a prominent human right campaigner in for questioning Monday. Qin Yongmin's latest run-in with the authority came a he tried for the second time in a week to legally register a human right monitoring group. Qin said a civil affair official in the Hubei provincial capital of Wuhan accused him of engaging in illegal activity. The police came soon after he returned home. As I'm sending this statement, the Wuhan Public Security Bureau is again taking me away, Qin said in a hastily scrawled message on the bottom of the typed statement faxed to reporter. Qin, detained briefly two week ago, wa questioned for about three hour before being released and threatened with prosecution if he persisted in trying to set up his China Human Rights Observer. Qin hoped the harassment would stop after China sign the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, but he said if local authority don't observe the treaty we will unswervingly push ahead with protecting human right to the last. China plan to sign the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights on Monday at the United Nations. By the time the ink is dry, Blair should be landing in Beijing on Tuesday morning for the first visit by a British prime minister in seven year. The treaty is supposed to guarantee freedom of speech and assembly. But even after China sign, the treaty would not come into force until ratified by the legislature, which may attach reservation effectively nullifying some provision. Blair ha vowed to discus difference over human right with Chinese leader. His visit ha drawn appeal from dissident and an international press freedom group urging him to persuade Chinese leader to free political prisoner. In an open letter, three dissident said that while Chinese leader say they respect human right principle, in law and practice the government allows right abuse and persecution of dissident. Thousands of political prisoner are believed to remain in Chinese prison, labor camp or detention center, said the letter, a copy of which wa released by the Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China. The letter called for the release of Shi Binhai, a journalist who compiled a popular book on political change; Fang Jue, a businessman who called openly for political reform; and other imprisoned activist. Paris-based Reporters Without Borders urged Blair to call for the release of Gao Yu, Liu Xiaobo and Liu Jingsheng. The three are among 13 journalist imprisoned simply for attempting to practice their profession, it said in a statement. Protesting the lack of a defense lawyer, the father of a prominent dissident is to seek a delay in his son's subversion trial, scheduled to start on Thursday in the central city of Wuhan. The defendant is Qin Yongmin, 45, a democracy advocate who ha spent 10 year in prison and labor camp and ha recently promoted an alternative, non-Communist political party. In a telephone interview Wednesday evening, his father, Qin Qinguo, 76, said that before the trial begin, he plan to hand the court a written plea for postponement. If the plea is ignored, he said he will walk out. I wouldn't be able to stand it, the father, a retired steelworker, said, citing his frail health and high blood pressure. Under China's code of criminal procedure, a defendant ha the right to a defense lawyer. But in this case, the elder Qin said, some lawyer he approached declined to take the case, while others were warned by security official not to get involved. The father said he did not agree with his son's political tactic but now he felt he had no choice but to protest his treatment. Wang wa a leader of student demonstration in Tiananmen Square in 1989 and served two year in prison after they were put down by military force. As the founder of the suppressed new political party, the China Democracy Party, he publicly announced it charter in June during President Clinton's visit to China. Scores of people around the country began to champion the new party, hopeful that closer tie between China and the United States, and China's signing of the international covenant on political and civil right, would mean a looser political climate. But the party wa soon declared illegal and many adherent were detained, at least temporarily. Wang now face charge that could land him in prison for five year or more. A third veteran dissident and promoter of the new party, Xu Wenli, ha been detained for week in Beijing and is expected to face similar subversion charge. In the last two day, at least 10 Democracy Party member or supporter in the Hangzhou area have been detained by the police and others have had their phone line cut, reported the Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China, based in Hong Kong. The separate trial of two prominent democracy advocate for inciting subversion of the state opened Thursday morning, with the family of both defendant protesting their inability to hire defense lawyer. The trial in the eastern city of Hangzhou of Wang Youcai, 32, founder of the China Democracy Party, which is now suppressed, wa in session for just two hour and 10 minute. It appears to be finished, although the court did not announce a decision or say when it would. I don't know what happens from here, said Wang's wife, Hu Jiangxia, who wa one of three relative allowed to attend the trial. I don't hold much hope, she added in a telephone interview. Wang, who spent two year in prison after the 1989 student demonstration in Tiananmen Square, wa accused of organizing a political party that sought to overturn Communist Party rule and of colluding with foreign enemy of the state. He could face five year or more in prison. Since all the lawyer his family approached were intimidated by security agent, Ms. Hu said, Wang tried to mount his own defense Thursday morning after prosecutor laid out their case. But the judge frequently interrupted him and cut him off after half an hour, saying he wa not responding to the specific fact of the case, she added. Wang argued that his activity were legal under China's constitution and under an international covenant on political right that China ha signed, Ms. Hu said. In the central city of Wuhan, the trial on similar charge of Qin Yongmin, 45, a veteran dissident, also continued for something over two hour. It will apparently be continued, said Qin's father, Qin Qingguo, since the session ended after the prosecution presented it charge. In that case, too, prospective lawyer had been intimidated or detained, family member said. The elderly father's request to the court Thursday morning for a postponement wa ignored, so he and one of the defendant's brother stayed outside the court building in protest, leaving another brother inside. We didn't feel there wa any reason to observe the trial because if Qin Yongmin did not have a defense attorney, then a far a we were concerned the proceeding were meaningless, the father said by telephone. The US. Embassy asked to observe the trial. When an embassy official arrived at the court in Hangzhou Thursday morning, he wa told that there were no seat available and instead waited outside, greeting Ms. Hu when she emerged, shaken, from the brief trial. Police detained and questioned the organizer of a group set up by dissident to monitor official corruption and told him the group's activity must cease, a human right group said Thursday. Police in Xinyang, in central China's Henan province, took An Jun away Wednesday afternoon and held him until past midnight for questioning about the group's member, said the Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China. Police wanted a list of member with their work and home address, a demand An Jun refused for fear of getting them into trouble, the Hong Kong-based Information Center said. Corruption Watch, founded by nine dissident in seven province, now ha nearly 100 member, the center said. It applied last month to the government to register officially, but received no response, the center added. The police officer who questioned An Jun said that without official permission, the group must cease it activity, the center said. Rampant official corruption is a major public gripe in China. The Information Center said Corruption Watch had already received report of graft in it first month of operation. In a separate report, the center said that an official in the Sichuan provincial government refused Thursday to accept an application by three dissident to form a branch of a would-be opposition group, the China Democracy Party. Groups of dissident in city across China have attempted to register the group, a required by law, but authority have rejected those application. Signaling that the Communist Party's 49-year-old ban on opposition group remains intact, police have detained and questioned many dissident associated with the group. With attorney locked up, harassed or plain scared, two prominent dissident will defend themselves against charge of subversion Thursday in China's highest-profile dissident trial in two year. Qin Yongmin's and Wang Youcai's family were running out of option Wednesday to help the pair, leading organizer of a budding opposition political party. Qin's family pleaded for a postponement at Wuhan's Intermediate People's Court, but court official denied the request. Police have detained one lawyer and threatened another, and subtler pressure have been used on others, family member said. Given the interference, Wang Youcai's wife assumes he will be convicted. Whether he ha a lawyer or not, whatever he say, the government ha already decided, Hu Jiangxia said. Qin and Wang will be tried separately, in city 500 kilometer (300 mile) apart and in proceeding attended only by family and a few observer selected by the court. Qin, 44, and Wang, 31, are accused of inciting the subversion of state power, apparently for helping to organize the China Democracy Party. They face from 10 year to life imprisonment if convicted under the harshest aspect of the law. By moving against Qin, Wang and the China Democracy Party, the ruling Communist Party appears to be signaling it determination to crush challenge to it monopoly on power. Authorities have detained or questioned more than 30 people associated with the party in a 17-day-old crackdown. Qin, a democracy campaigner for 20 year, and Wang, a student leader of the 1989 Tiananmen Square democracy movement, are among the most active and influential member of China's dissident community. A third prominent member of the dissident community, Xu Wenli, wa also arrested in the crackdown, but not yet charged. The Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said many more are missing and believed to be in custody. To prosecute Wang, authority violated the minimal right guaranteed suspect under Chinese law and ignored court order, his wife said. Even the judge asked me to hire a lawyer, but while I wa doing this, some people were doing thing to stop me, Hu Jiangxia said. During one meeting with a potential defense attorney, a police official stormed in and said, `Don't do anything for them. Don't take this case. Whoever take the case, you can't win,' Hu recounted. Four law firm refused to take Qin's case, his brother Qin Xiaoguang said. The Information Center said one lawyer who initially agreed to represent Qin on Monday went missing for four hour and then called Qin's family to withdraw. Qin Xiaoguang said he and his father have decided to stay away to protest the unfairness, but another brother will go. They were scared all the time, he said, referring to Yao's wife, Yu Yingzhang, and daughter, Yao Yiting, 14, who accompanied him. The family had a terrible life, especially the daughter. Secret agent followed them all the time. The family trading business, which wa 12 year old, wa shuttered by the government in 1996, said Wang, a former surgeon in Beijing, so they had no way of living. In addition, after Yao made organizational trip to several province, democracy activist urged him to go abroad, Wang said. They wanted him to tell the truth about what is really happening in China and to call on the whole world to pay attention, Wang said. Beatrice Laroche, liaison at the United Nations for Human Rights in China, a New York-based group, said the China Democracy Party wa a growing presence in some of China's most populous province, including Sichuan. Ms. Laroche said the Yao brother, especially the younger man, won prominence by helping to finance predecessor of the China Democracy Party with money from the family business before it wa closed by the government.

But by his own admission, Gingrich's vision seems to have blurred this time around, costing Republicans a net of five seat in Tuesday's election and leaving the party's narrow governing majority even narrower. The disappointing election result also left Gingrich open to a fractious challenge for his post a speaker. Members and aide said Wednesday that a fury at the speaker had bubbled up overnight and that some member were trying to organize a slate of candidate to replace Gingrich and his leadership team when House Republicans convene on Nov. 18 to select their leader for next year. As Rep. Mark Sanford, R-S.C., put it, When a company's stock price go down, it's usually the CEO who get fired. Top Republican aide, speaking anonymously, were even blunter. People were very angry last night, one aide said. Today it's a mixture of seething and dismay. It's just ugly. And Newt know it. His career is on the line. Another aide said, Most people are really angry with Newt, and no one know what to do with it. But some are dipping their toe in the water and seeing what the temperature is. A possible slate could contain the name of Reps. Robert L. Livingston of Louisiana to replace Gingrich, Steve Largent of Oklahoma to replace Dick Armey of Texas a majority leader, and Jennifer Dunn of Washington to replace John A. Boehner of Ohio a conference chairman. Rep. David M. McIntosh of Indiana is also said to be considering a run for speaker, but it wa not clear whether he would be part of any slate. Rep. Tom DeLay of Texas, the majority whip, wa said to be secure. Armey bluntly acknowledged the scramble going on in the wing to oust the leadership. Told on Nightline that there were Republicans after his head, Armey replied: They're welcome to it if they're big enough to take it. Publicly, Gingrich ha expressed confidence about keeping his job a speaker. But he ha been grim-faced over the last 24 hour and closeted himself Wednesday with his top strategist making call to shore up his support among member. He look like the victim of an accident, said Rep. Peter King, R-N.Y., who support Gingrich. He's very somber in tone. The question, a it always is with Gingrich, is how many member are prepared to rebel against his leadership. In the past, no more than a couple of dozen member have openly expressed their dissatisfaction with him, and a coup attempt last year fizzled for lack of support. I'm hoping more people will understand the need for a serious reassessment this year, said Rep. Charles T. Canady, R-Fla., who said he had hoped for a challenge to the speaker after the 1996 election, when the Republicans also lost seat. The reality is this: Our majority keep shrinking, Canady said. If it shrink any more, it will be gone. But Gingrich ha built support among moderate, and some perceived the election a a repudiation of the conservative. Rep. Sherwood L. Boehlert, R-Utah, said the result showed that this wa the right direction for the party. To maintain our majority, we've got to moderate some of our view, Boehlert said. Thomas Mann, a Congressional scholar at the Brookings Institution, said that moderate supported Gingrich in part because no appealing alternative had emerged. They know he see the broader world and is prepared to moderate if it make sense, Mann said. Newt's gone out of his way to support the moderate. He's nurtured a relationship with them. But Mann and others said that anger ha been building at Gingrich for several reason, including his signing on to a budget deal last month that seemed to capitulate to President Clinton, not offering a clear legislative agenda for Republicans and not communicating a clear political message. We are most defined by who we hate said Rep. Mark Souder, R-Ind. But voter are more sophisticated than that, and Republicans better have something to say about where we're going. The anger grew in the last few day when the speaker approved a $10-million anti-Clinton advertising campaign that allowed Democrats to turn the election into a referendum on Gingrich, who ha never been nearly a popular with the public a Clinton ha been. As late a Tuesday afternoon, he wa predicting a net pickup of between 10 and 30. Until we look at it better, I frankly don't understand all the thing that happened yesterday, he said, and I'm not sure anybody else in the country doe either. But he said Republicans should have maniacally focused on a basic message of cutting tax, saving Social Security and preventing drug abuse, and campaigned aggressively on those theme. He contrasted the lack of focus this year with the Contract With America that proved so successful in 1994. People thought we stood for something pretty big, he said. But Gingrich also seemed aware of the mounting concern about his leadership, repeatedly casting the election result a a victory for his leadership team because Republicans had stayed in the majority for three election in a row for the first time in 70 year. He also suggested that those who would challenge him have little support. An intense struggle for control of the House is underway, with Rep. Bob Livingston conducting a telephone campaign to replace Rep. Newt Gingrich a speaker and Gingrich fighting with a counter-campaign that ha given some member pause about ousting him. Stunned by the Democratic resurgence in the mid-term election, congressional Republicans tore into each other Wednesday over who wa to blame for their failure to make the traditional opposition party gain in an off-year election. Just four year ago, it wa a good bet that Newt Gingrich would be the pivotal figure in US. politics at the turn of the millennium. With a promise to balance the budget, end welfare and represent more conservative social value, he appeared to have rearranged the political map for Congress just a Ronald Reagan had done for the presidency. But Gingrich's leadership is now so shaky that even if he maintains his hold on the speaker's office, he is in danger of marginalization. A change this dramatic suggests something far more profound than a miscalculation about election tactic. What looked like one of the major realignments in US. political history might turn out to have been nothing but a temporary shift. The Gingrich revolution wa fueled by anger, a revolt of white working-class Americans against what they perceived a a Democratic bias in favor of black and other minority, and a middle-class rejection of the politics of big government and big deficit. They were the same resentment that Ronald Reagan had exploited so successfully. But old political habit and a moribund Republican leadership allowed the Democrats to retain control of Congress throughout the 1980s, and turned Reagan's economic program into an undisciplined tax-cutting spree that created prosperity along with huge budget gap. Gingrich's attention-grabbing rhetoric, energy and talent for political organization finally took Reagan's formula for success to the congressional election in 1994.
