The president co-opted part of the Contract With America, particularly the balanced budget and welfare reform. He adapted the Republican social message into a call for thing like school uniform and television rating system, which symbolized more responsibility and parental control without supporting government intrusion into private life. One Democrat also lost his re-election bid Rep. Jay Johnson of Wisconsin. The new House member include 17 Republicans and at least 22 Democrats. David Wu, a Democrat wa leading Molly Bordonaro, a Republican in the race for one House seat in Oregon, but the final victory announcement wa not expected until Friday after absentee ballot are counted. Unlike the self-proclaimed revolutionary of the Republican class of 1994, many of the newly elected member are career politician who rose through the rank of local and state government. Three of the Democrats are the son of former lawmaker, Mark Udall of Colorado, son of Morris Udall who represented Arizona; Tom Udall of New Mexico, son of the other Udall brother, Stewart, a former congressman and secretary of the Interior, and Charlie Gonzalez, who won the Texas seat of his father, Henry. A struggle for control of the House is under way, with Rep. Robert Livingston conducting a telephone campaign that could lead to him running against Newt Gingrich a speaker. But Gingrich's counter-campaign ha given some member pause about ousting him. At the same time, a small band of Republicans vowed on Thursday that they would not vote to re-elect Gingrich under any circumstance, a move that, because of the Republicans' shrunken House majority, could tie the party in knot for month. Rep. Matt Salmon, R-Ariz., said: I personally have made the decision that I cannot vote for Newt Gingrich for speaker in January, and there are six others who have told me they feel the same way, seven people who just will not, and it take six to deadlock the vote. Fury at the speaker ha boiled over since Tuesday's election, when Republicans suffered a net loss of five seat in the House. They blamed Gingrich, the party's chief strategist. But many were already angry at him for what they said wa his failure to articulate a clear message for the party going into the election and for a messy budget process that gave President Clinton a political edge and contradicted Republican principle of fiscal conservativism by containing massive amount of spending for local project. House Republicans are to meet Nov. 18 to vote by secret ballot for their leader. Whoever win the Republican nomination for speaker must stand for election by the full House in January. Even if Gingrich win the secret ballot, he could be denied re-election a speaker in January if Salmon and at least five others refuse to vote for him. Because the Republicans now control the House by only 12 seat, it would take just six vote against Gingrich to deny him a majority. With such a chaotic and unacceptable prospect looming, Livingston told Gingrich that he should step aside for the good of the party, Republican official said. The official said that Livingston spoke to Gingrich shortly after the election return but also before the election, reflecting Livingston's earlier displeasure with the speaker over the budget process. Several Republicans said that both Livingston, the chairman of the Appropriations Committee and one of the few member with the stature to stand for speaker, and Gingrich were working the phone on Thursday in a struggle for vote. Livingston ha said nothing publicly about a challenge to Gingrich, but several member and aide said on Thursday that he would announce his intention, possibly a soon a Friday, only after he had determined if he could win. Rep. Peter King, R-N.Y., wa one of several member who spoke with Livingston on Thursday. He told me he's making a number of phone call, that he's gotten a very positive response about running for speaker, and he'll decide within the next 48 hour, King said. He won't do it till he ha his duck in a row, and right now a lot of people are still loyal to the speaker, said an aide to a Republican who, like many others, is trying to straddle the line between fealty to a speaker who may retain power and encouragement to a challenger who offer a salve to an embattled party. Many Republicans immediately blamed Gingrich for the party's loss on Tuesday. Talk quickly emerged the next day of a slate of candidate to oppose Gingrich and his lieutenant. The list of possible candidate for leadership position included Rep.e Steve Largent of Oklahoma, who talked with Livingston on Thursday about challenging Gingrich, Republican official said, speaking on the condition that their name not be reported. Those official said that Largent told Livingston that he wanted to run with him on a ticket and that he would challenge Rep. Dick Armey, the majority leader. But, these official said that if Livingston did not challenge Gingrich, Largent would run for speaker instead. Other name were floated Wednesday for leadership post. They included Reps. David McIntosh of Indiana for speaker and Jennifer Dunn of Washington a conference chairman. Added to the mix on Thursday wa the name of Rep. Christopher Cox, a California conservative. As a sign of the uncertainty prevailing among House member on Thursday, Rep. Henry Hyde, the chairman of the Judiciary Committee and one of the House's most venerable member, rebuffed a chance to endorse Gingrich a speaker. Hyde said that Gingrich bore responsibility for the party's loss Tuesday. Leadership take credit when thing go right, he said. They ought to take the blame when thing go wrong. Asked if Gingrich should remain speaker, Hyde said: I rather think he will, but that remains to be seen. The energy that many vented publicly on Wednesday a anger toward Gingrich seemed devoted on Thursday to intense internal political calculation about whether Livingston could succeed in toppling Gingrich and whether he should succeed. While many support him a a veteran who understands the House and ha shown shrewd political skill in managing the massive federal budget, others are reviving image of the Louisianan a a hot-head who gave the party a bad name during the government shutdown two year ago and who tends toward arm-flailing in heated moment. One conservative leader said that he and his ally had reservation about Livingston because he wa obsessed about trying to keep social issue out of the budget process. The budget, he said, ha been a vehicle for conservative over the year to add restriction on federal money for abortion and other thing you can't get through the Senate or past a presidential veto. If Livingston is the challenger, I doubt that will cause a rallying of the real conservative in Congress. Some moderate said they were prepared to support him. Rep. Marge Roukema, R-N.J., said, I would be amenable to Livingston. Still, she cautioned, I'm not after Newt. But it's wrong not to sit down and seriously look at our option. Ken Johnson, an aide to Rep. WJ. (Billy) Tauzin, R-La., said that his bos wa emblematic of the confusion among the broad base of House Republicans. Billy ha been loyal to both Speaker Gingrich and Dick Armey, and he's still loyal to them, but he also want to hear what they have to say before committing to them in the next election, Johnson said. Everyone is asking the same question: Can we refocus the message and re-energize our base without re-aligning the leadership? Salmon said his refusal to support Gingrich no matter what wa based on Gingrich's track record of one failed strategy after another, including the impeachment process and the pork-laden budget. With the challenge under way, Gingrich ha been trying to show member that he is responsive to their concern. After an election night in which he portrayed the Republicans a victorious even a they lost seat, the next day he took responsibility for the loss. In another move, Gingrich ha indicated that he is willing to cede control over the party's congressional campaign committee, allowing the whole House to select it member. Gingrich is also making strong personal appeal to Republicans. Said one top House aide: He'll get support. How much? Only his own vote-counters know.

data: America Online is on the verge of agreeing to purchase Netscape Communications Corp., the Internet pioneer at the center of the government's antitrust suit against Microsoft Corp., executive involved in the talk said Sunday. The proposed deal is a complex, three-way transaction involving AOL, Netscape and Sun Microsystems Inc. AOL, the leading on-line service with more than 14 million subscriber, would acquire Netscape's popular site on the World Wide Web and it software business. AOL would also enter into a joint marketing and development partnership with Sun Microsystems to strengthen Netscape's other business of selling to large corporation the heavy-duty software needed to serve up Web page and other Internet technology to many thousand of user at the same time. The purchase, an exchange of AOL share for Netscape stock, is valued at roughly $4 billion. A completed deal could be announced a soon a Monday morning. But executive involved in the talk cautioned Sunday night that some detail remained to be negotiated. The Netscape deal, if consummated, would realign three business at the forefront of the modern economy on-line service, Internet software and electronic commerce. It would strengthen two of Microsoft's leading rival, AOL and Sun Microsystems. At the same time, however, it would end the independent existence of Netscape, an Internet software maker once regarded a the most serious challenger to Microsoft's dominance of the personal computer software market. Netscape, founded in 1994, ha struggled over the last 18 month under an assault from Microsoft. Its Navigator wa the runaway leader in the market for the browser software used to navigate the World Wide Web. But Microsoft, responding to the Internet revolution, entered the market aggressively, quickly matching the quality of Netscape's technology and then bundling the Microsoft browser, Internet Explorer, into it industry-standard Windows operating system and giving it away free. Eventually, Microsoft's browser technology caught up to Netscape's. Earlier this year, Netscape announced layoff and started distributing Navigator for free a well, a Microsoft steadily gained in the browser market. Since then, Netscape ha focused mainly on two business advertising and transaction fee from it Netcenter Web site and selling industrial-strength software to corporation that are building their own Internet site on which to conduct electronic commerce. AOL belief it ha the expertise to increase revenue from Netscape's Web site and, helped by Sun's programmer and vast corporate sale force, to accelerate Netscape's software sale a well, executive involved in the negotiation said. Among large corporation, Sun's version of Unix, Solaris, is among the most popular operating system for the powerful computer that run Netscape's server software. The much smaller Netscape would be placed under the wing of AOL and Sun Microsystems. The three company had combined revenue of more than $12.4 billion last year. Microsoft, by comparison, had revenue of more than $14 billion. This deal would insure that the fundamental element of Netscape survive within bigger company that can drive it technology forward, said David B. Yoffie, a professor at the Harvard business school and co-author with Michael A. Cusumano of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology of a recent book, Competing on Internet Time: Lessons from Netscape and Its Battle with Microsoft. The impact of the deal, if any, on the government's antitrust suit against Microsoft is uncertain. It doe appear to support a key theme of Microsoft's defense namely, that it operates in a fast-moving industry where corporate alliance shift all the time. Thus, Microsoft argues, antitrust policy should tread gently. But the deal, government official insist, should have no direct effect on the current case. No matter how much the alliance shift, it doesn't affect the central fact of Microsoft's monopoly and how it ha used and abused it market power to protect it monopoly, said David Boies, the Justice Department's lead trial lawyer in the Microsoft case. Executives representing Netscape, AOL and Sun Microsystems are government witness at the Microsoft trial. And the serious merger talk between Netscape Chief Executive Officer James Barksdale and AOL Chairman Steve Case began about a month ago, or just after the start of the Microsoft trial, according to people close to the talk. Industry analyst suggest that the company may have been emboldened to take stronger anti-Microsoft step based partly on the perception that the antitrust case would weaken Microsoft. And representative of Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, a Silicon Valley venture capital firm regarded a a power broker among Microsoft's rival, sit on the board of Netscape, Sun and AOL. Still, executive involved in the talk said that the timing of the proposed deal wa unrelated to the antitrust trial. Nor should it, one person noted, be regarded a a single-minded attempt to circle the wagon against Microsoft. Indeed, AOL, according to one person close to the talk, plan to keep Microsoft's Internet Explorer browser a the default choice on it on-line service. One of the government's allegation in the antitrust suit is that Microsoft won out over Netscape a the main browser for AOL because Microsoft used it Windows monopoly a a bargaining chip. To win the browser deal, Microsoft offered AOL prime real estate on the Windows desktop, the main screen on more than 90 percent of personal computer sold today. Staying with Microsoft's browser can be seen a proof that AOL still regard placement on the Windows desktop a crucial, a well a a careful step to avoid undermining one of the allegation in the government's case. For AOL, the Netscape purchase would accelerate it evolution toward the Internet. At present, it flagship on-line service is a hybrid to it own proprietary service, it ha added a gateway to the World Wide Web. In addition, for consumer who do not subscribe to AOL's dial-up service, it also ha it own Web site, aol.com, which attracts about 24 million visitor a month, according to Media Metrix/Relevant Knowledge, a market research firm. Its big Web site offer a wide range of information, entertainment, Internet chat and e-mail, a leading example of the all-in-one site that have become known a portal. Netscape's Netcenter traffic ha slipped a bit in recent month, to under 16 million visitor a month, but it, too, is a major portal. Together, they should be a huge player in the intensifying portal battle for viewer and resulting advertising revenue. Yahoo is the current leader among portal site with more than 25 million monthly visitor, while Microsoft's site attracts more than 20 million a month. Though known a a new-media company for consumer, AOL is also interested in boosting it electronic commerce business with the Netscape purchase. AOL ha recently done work with Eastman Kodak, American Greetings and other company, not only promoting their product to on-line subscriber but also building the Internet infrastructure of software to conduct electronic commerce. AOL note projection like a recent one from Forrester Research Inc., which predicted that worldwide Internet commerce could reach a high a $3.2 trillion by 2003, or 5 percent of global sale. Sun Microsystems, analyst say, could be a strong partner for AOL in the market for Internet commerce software. Sun is a corporate software company with a sale force of several thousand. As it move increasingly to Internet technology, AOL should prove an excellent partner for Sun in term of developing and using Sun's Java, an Internet programming language. And while Netscape's browser no longer generates revenue on it own, it is a distribution channel for Java technology. Having Netscape's browser safely in the hand of a friendly company is of strategic importance for Sun, since Microsoft owns the alternative in the browser market. AOL is expected pay little, if any, premium over Netscape's stock price on Friday, executive close to the deal said, since Netscape share have more than doubled in the last month. In the last week alone, Netscape's stock ha jumped about $12, or nearly 45 percent, following report that it wa discussing a possible partnership with AOL. The stock closed Friday at $39.1875, up $2625. AOL's share gained $1.50 Friday, closing at $84875. Envisioning a thoroughly networked world in which the World Wide Web is a limitless marketplace of information, entertainment, product and service, America Online Inc. Tuesday laid out the detail of it agreement to buy the Netscape Communications Corporation for $4.2 billion. By moving quickly toward what both company have recently come to see a the inevitable convergence of technology and medium, America Online hope that it will secure a solid lead in a battle already joined by giant like the Microsoft Corp. and the International Business Machines Corp. to transform the greater part of cyberspace into a vast virtual mall. Part of that vision rest on an alliance with Sun Microsystems that America Online negotiated a part of the deal. Sun not only brings a cyber-savvy sale force to the effort but, even more importantly, a strong technology partner in developing Netscape's industrial-strength software for running Internet site. Sun is indeed a technology heavyweight. It owns the Java programming language specially designed for Internet application, and Solaris, among the most popular commercial operating system for the powerful computer that big corporation use to serve up Internet service like the World Wide Web, e-mail and retail transaction. It also manufacture a highly respected line of powerful computer based on it own microprocessor chip. But for America Online and for the big Internet player against which it will compete the real potential gold mine lie further down the road, perhaps five year away, when people will venture on line for information or shopping not only from personal computer but from inexpensive Internet appliance costing $200 each, or maybe included free a part of a subscription service, just a some cellular phone are now. Today, being wired remains a comparatively elitist activity an estimated 25 percent of American household had access to the Internet last year, and 5 percent of household bought merchandise on line. But the executive at America Online and Netscape hope that their deal will accelerate the timetable for the day when the Net is ubiquitous, when people will tap into the World Wide Web from appliance-like device, pager, cell phone, television set-top box or computer a routinely a they use the telephone today. A new generation of Internet device to be able to deliver our service anywhere is a key part of what this deal is about in the long run, said Stephen M. Case, 40, the chairman of America Online. For the present, however, the idea is to make America Online, the nation's leading online service, the standard way to get onto the Internet, the executive explained. Netscape, the Internet pioneer, is a crucial part of that effort, they said. There is no assurance that this vision of the technological future will prove accurate or, even if it doe, that the America Online-Netscape combination will lead the way. Still, the long-range game plan help explain what brought America Online and Netscape together. And the ability of the companies' executive to sell that vision to Netscape's whiz-kid programmer in particular will determine whether the merger succeeds. Netscape's headquarters in Mountain View, Calif., is likely become a prime target for Silicon Valley headhunter. As is the case with any software company, Netscape's key asset is it talented programmer, and many of these code hacker may be reluctant to work for America Online, which still ha a reputation a a middle-brow service catering to online newcomer, known derisively a newbie. Stock option and other financial incentive will be tailored to try to keep Netscape employee on board. But these people want to change the world, and we've got to be clear that joining with America Online, along with the Sun component, really is a bigger opportunity for u, said Marc Andreessen, the 26-year-old cofounder of Netscape who led a team of young programmer from the supercomputing center at the University of Illinois to Silicon Valley to start the Internet software company in 1994. This ought to be the preeminent Internet company over the next decade, Andreessen declared, speaking from a cell phone on a streetcorner in Palo Alto, Calif. For his part, Andreessen, a Netscape executive vice president, will become Netscape's chief technology officer for the next three or four month, until the merger is completed. His new job at America Online ha not yet been determined, but it is likely to be chief technology officer of the combined company a well, an America Online executive said. Already, according to one Netscape board member, Andreessen ha delivered a 12-page single-spaced memorandum to Case, setting out his view of the technological road map the new company should follow into the future, emphasizing the opportunity for electronic commerce in an environment in which most people are linked to the Internet. Netscape, populated with computing sophisticate, and America Online, known a an on-ramp to the Internet for the technologically challenged, seem a corporate odd couple. But the two company, it executive explained, had been evolving toward each other for more than a year. In a telephone interview from America Online's headquarters in Dulles, Va., Case described Netscape a an enterprise that had morphed itself from a company dependent on sale of it software used to browse the World Wide Web and in Microsoft's cross-hairs into a business that relied on advertising and other revenue from it popular Netcenter Web site and from selling software to corporation to handle electronic commerce. The Netscape transformation wa largely a reaction to Microsoft's competitive assault on it browser business a central element in the government's antitrust suit against Microsoft. Microsoft bundled it browser into it industry-standard Windows operating system, and gave away the browser for free. The government alleges these step were part of a pattern of anticompetitive practice, while Microsoft maintains the move were intended mainly to benefit consumer. Early this year, after laying off worker and suffering a large loss last year, Netscape announced that it would also distribute it browser for free. It seems to have stabilized it business around it new model. Netscape announced Tuesday that it earned $2.7 million on revenue of $162 million in it fourth fiscal quarter, which ended in September. Yet America Online ha also changed in the last couple of year, moving well beyond it reputation a an online service for beginner. It now ha an Internet chat service and run it own all-in-one site on the Web, known a a portal, which includes e-mail, Internet searching, news, entertainment and online shopping. America Online ha really changed from a closed online service for novice user to an Internet medium and technology company with a diverse set of brand, Andreessen said. These two company have been moving in the same direction, and the fit is a good one. America Online Inc. want to become the next Microsoft in two promising information-age field where Microsoft Corp. is just another company the Internet medium business and electronic commerce. With it proposed purchase of Netscape Communications Corp., AOL, the nation's largest dial-up online service with more than 14 million subscriber, hope to take a significant step toward that ambitious goal. If the $4 billion deal is completed the company had not reached a final agreement a of Monday night AOL would acquire a leading Internet brand and enlarge it wired audience by absorbing the million who regularly visit Netscape's popular NetCenter site on the World Wide Web. Acquiring Netscape would really enhance America Online's role a the premier Internet medium company, said James F. Moore, president of Geopartners Inc., a consulting firm. America Online is assembling the kind of audience number that will convince people the Internet is becoming a mainstream medium. In the new medium business, a in traditional medium like television or newspaper, eyeball translate into advertising revenue. But what really intrigue medium executive and consumer marketer about the new medium news, entertainment and service rendered in computer code is that it is inherently a two-way medium with which people can interact with the tap of a key or the click of a mouse button The interaction that advertiser and marketer want to see, of course, is buying. And it is the potential for exploiting an instant, direct connection to consumer that ha fueled all the recent optimism about electronic commerce. Today, company are selling everything from book to baby clothes over the Internet. Most company have not progressed beyond the experimentation stage, but there are a handful of encouraging success story like Amazon.com, the on-line bookstore. By 2003, Forrester Research Inc., whose business is analyzing trend in cyberspace, project that Internet commerce could reach $3.2 trillion, or 5 percent of all sale worldwide. AOL is at the forefront of this convergence of medium and commerce converge, and integration reflected in the lineage of it leader. Steve Case, the chairman, wa once a new-product manager for Pepsico's Pizza Hut chain, while Robert Pittman, the president, is a former MTV executive. Microsoft is also investing heavily in new medium and electronic commerce. It ha an online service, MSN, which competes with AOL, a well a information-and commerce Web site that focus on travel, car and real estate. It also owns Sidewalk, a network of local site that list movie, restaurant and store in city around the country including Seattle and New York. Its MSNBC Internet news service is half of a joint venture with NBC. Microsoft is expected to be a formidable competitor in the media-and-commerce business. It ha no shortage of bright people and it ha more money than any rival. Besides deep pocket, Microsoft ha the built-in advantage in any computer-based medium because it Windows operating system run more than 90 percent of personal computer sold today. Its control of the Windows desktop give it the most valuable piece of commercial real estate in the information age. In theory, at least, owning that desktop screen should help Microsoft steer consumer to it online offering an issue that is key to the government's antitrust suit against Microsoft. But so far, Microsoft ha started slowly in the field of Internet medium and electronic commerce. Microsoft may want to, but it doe not dominate these new market, said Richard Shaffer, a principal of Technologic Partners, a research firm. America Online recognizes that the big opportunity is in these emerging growth business like electronic commerce instead of trying to take Microsoft on head-on. Still, if the Netscape deal is completed, AOL will also find itself in the software business in a way it ha never been in the past. Netscape is known a the pioneer in the commercial development of software used to navigate the World Wide Web. Microsoft saw the browser software a a direct threat to it industry dominance and pursued that market aggressively, bundling it own browser with it Windows and giving it away free tactic that have been challenged by the government. But Netscape no longer generates revenue from it browser, which it now also distributes for free, but from the sale of heavy-duty software sold to corporation. Much of this software is used a the technological back office for electronic commerce used in building Web site and processing transaction. A surprising element in the proposed deal is that AOL intends to hold onto Netscape's corporate software business instead of selling it off to an established software company. America Online just doesn't have credibility in that market, observed Michael A. Cusumano, a professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Sloan School of Management. Executives close to AOL explain the decision a the need to provide full-line offering for electronic commerce, from corporate Web site to the computer screen of consumer. But AOL ha decided it need help to preserve and strengthen Netscape's corporate software business. To do that, it ha brought in Sun Microsystems Inc. in a side deal, which ha complicated the transaction considerably. AOL, according to executive close to the proposed deal, will own Netscape, but it will have a joint marketing and development partnership with Sun. As part of the deal, AOL will agree to purchase about $300 million worth of Sun's computer for it service, while Sun will apparently agree to purchase sizeable amount of Netscape software, which Sun's sale force must sell. Still, AOL and Sun have a longer-term objective a well one that promise to place them in more direct conflict with Microsoft. For nearly a year, William J. Raduchel, Sun's chief strategist, ha been working closely with AOL, according to Sun executive. A former Harvard economics professor who taught Scott McNealy, the Sun chairman, Raduchel ha focused on Sun's Internet programming technology, called Java and Jini, both of which are seen a potential threat to Microsoft's dominance. By combining Sun's technology prowess with AOL's powerful consumer brand, the Sun executive say, there is the potential for a kind end-run around Microsoft's grip on desktop computing. In it research laboratory, Sun ha been working on a stripped-down network computer a simple-to-use information appliance, which could cost a little a $200 or be given away a part of a subscription service. The concept is that AOL's Internet medium and electronic commerce service could be delivered to many more home than today because many people still shun the expense and difficulty of using a personal computer. The appliance would be mainly a receiver and screen, with most of the computing power residing on vast central computer serving up information a user request by tapping a few button. Sun's technological specialty is this kind of centralized network computing. If the long-term AOL-Sun vision ever materialized certainly a three-to-five year bet, at the least it could give both company a boost and technological independence from Microsoft. Microsoft Corp. argued in federal court Monday that the proposed acquisition of Netscape Communications Corp. by America Online seriously undermined the government's antitrust suit against the software giant. From a legal standpoint, this proposed deal pull the rug out from under the government, William Neukom, Microsoft's senior vice president for legal affair, said Monday morning on the courthouse step. The reasoning behind this assertion, Microsoft say, is that the proposed deal demonstrates that Netscape and the larger software industry are healthy and vibrant even with all of the illegal and anti-competitive practice alleged in the government's suit. But David Boies, the government's lead attorney, said all of that wa irrelevant. Whatever the deal end up being if there end up being a deal is not going to remove any of the obstacle that Microsoft ha placed in the path of competition in this industry, he said. Michael Lacovara, a Microsoft lawyer who wa questioning a government witness, economist Frederick Warren-Boulton, suggested to him during the trial Monday that the proposed acquisition undermined Warren-Boulton's argument, that Microsoft seems headed toward obtaining a monopoly in Internet browser software to match the one it apparently hold in operating system. After all, about 22 percent of Americans who use the Internet reach it through America Online. And at present AOL us Microsoft's Web browser, Internet Explorer, a the service's default choice. In exchange for that, Microsoft place an AOL advertisement and Internet link in Windows 98. Lacovara asked the witness whether, once AOL's service contract expires in January, he would expect AOL to continue to distribute Microsoft software. Yes, Warren-Boulton responded. It is not at all clear to me that AOL's incentive to do this is changed by this proposed merger with Netscape. He noted that America Online official had said their need to be among the online service featured in Windows forced them to accept Microsoft term establishing Internet Explorer a the default choice. Lacovara then asked Warren-Boulton the question that lay under his entire cross-examination of the witness and Microsoft's larger assertion Monday about the proposed Netscape-AOL deal. Surely this combination, he asked, tell you something about the nature of competition in the software industry? Warren-Boulton's answer wa probably not the one Lacovara had been after. To the extent that this potential merger is the result of Microsoft's action with these exclusive contract and other action, he said, it is unfortunate to see the disappearance of a firm like Netscape, the brightest, newest star. Warren-Boulton's purpose on the stand for the government is to establish that Microsoft doe have a monopoly in operating-system software; more than 90 percent of the world's computer use a Microsoft operating system. That is the foundation under most of the government's case since federal antitrust law forbids certain behavior by a monopolist that would be legal for a firm that face healthy competition. Through repeated, often circumlocutious questioning, Lacovara tried to make the case that Microsoft's overwhelming market share wa ephemeral. The software industry is so vibrant and fast moving, he suggested, that Microsoft could be toppled from it position at any moment a point of view the company encourages among it employee. On Friday and Monday, Lacovara repeatedly pointed out that other company are placing other operating system on the market, and some software company principally Microsoft's greatest rival are writing software for these new system. But Warren-Boulton argued that the existence of these fringe competitor in the operating system market doe not mean in any way that Microsoft doe not have monopoly power. On Monday afternoon, Lacovara made an issue of the success Apple Computer Co. is having selling it new iMac computer. He entered into evidence an Apple news release issued last month showing, among other thing, that 12.5 percent of the people buying Apple's new iMac computer had previously owned a Windows machine. Apple computer use a different operating system, Mac-OS. The outcome of the Microsoft antitrust case may be a long way off, but one thing is already clear: This is the first major e-mail trial. The government's prosecution and Microsoft Corp.'s defense, to a striking degree, are legal campaign waged with electronic message. The human testimony often pale next to the e-mail evidence. On the stand or in videotaped testimony, the people being questioned shrug, mumble and forget. The e-mail is alive with idea and competitive zeal, punctuated with profanity and exclamation point. The second week of the trial ended with the prosecutor being frustrated because a lengthy cross-examination by Microsoft's lead lawyer left no time for the government to show several hour of a videotaped deposition of Bill Gates, the Microsoft chairman. With a new witness, an executive of Apple Computer Inc., taking the stand Monday, it is uncertain when the Gates tape will be played. The Justice Department and the 20 state suing Microsoft believe that the tape will strengthen their case because it show Gates saying he wa not involved in plan to take what the government alleges were illegal step to stifle competition in the Internet software market. The Gates videotape, said David Boies, the Justice Department's trial lawyer, offer an opportunity to judge Gates' credibility. But the Gates credibility gap, if there is one, becomes an issue not because of the videotape but because his taped remark can be compared and contrasted with the e-mail he wrote and received. The e-mail record, the government insists, show Gates waist-deep in plotting the anti-competitive deal and bullying tactic that he denies or professes to have never heard of in his taped deposition. If his machination are central to the government's case, why not summon Gates to the trial? The government doe not need to put Gates on the stand, because we have his e-mail and memoranda, Stephen Houck, a lawyer for the state, told the court. The Microsoft legal team ha for month been preparing it e-mail defense. First, Microsoft argues, anything that look damaging is taken out of context. I urge your honor, John Warden, Microsoft's lead lawyer, told Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, to view with considerable skepticism the crazy quilt of e-mail fragment that seem to form the core of the government's case. But Microsoft ha also mounted an e-mail counterattack, culled from the million of message it obtained by subpoena from competitor in pretrial discovery. Warden's cross-examination ritual is to present a government witness with an internal e-mail from his company and then pose a declaration a a question. These interrogation have two refrains: Isn't it true your company doe exactly what you are accusing Microsoft of doing, and isn't it true that Microsoft prevailed not because it is a predatory monopolist but because of it superior technology? Microsoft is accused of trying to prod company to stay out of it way. So last week, for example, Warden produced e-mail from Stephen Case, the chairman of America Online, suggesting a partnership with Netscape Communications Corp. in which both company would focus on their respective strength. That division of labor, Case wrote, would be the best way to achieve the goal that Marc Andreessen, Netscape's cofounder, described in an earlier e-mail a beating the Beast From Redmond that want to see u both dead a reference to Microsoft's headquarters in Redmond, Wash. Printouts of e-mail are just another form of written communication. By the 1920s, a typewriter became common, typed memoranda started to be used in court case. From the 1950s through the 1980s, legal expert say, there wa an explosion of documentation fueled by the new technology of electric typewriter, photocopying and fax machine, and then personal computer. And e-mail, they add, ha played an important role in legal inquiry for year, like the Iran-contra case in the 1980s when e-mail found in Oliver North's computer proved crucial. E-mail ha just revolutionized investigation of this kind, one senior Justice Department official said. And in their e-mail, people often communicate more frankly and informally than when writing a letter or a report tap it out, punch a button and it's gone into cyberspace. America Online is on the verge of agreeing to purchase Netscape Communications Corp., the Internet pioneer at the center of the government's antitrust suit against Microsoft Corp., executive involved in the talk said Sunday. The proposed deal is a complex, three-way transaction involving AOL, Netscape and Sun Microsystems Inc. AOL, the leading on-line service with more than 14 million subscriber, would acquire Netscape's popular site on the World Wide Web and it software business. But a part of the deal, AOL would also enter into a joint marketing and development partnership with Sun Microsystems to strengthen Netscape's other business of selling to large corporation the heavy-duty software needed to serve up Web page and other Internet technology to many thousand of user at the same time. The purchase, an exchange of AOL share for Netscape stock, is valued at roughly $4 billion. A completed deal could be announced a soon a Monday morning. But executive involved in the talk cautioned Sunday night that some detail remained to be negotiated. The Netscape deal, if consummated, would realign three business at the forefront of the modern economy on-line service, Internet software and electronic commerce. It would strengthen two of Microsoft's leading rival, AOL and Sun Microsystems. At the same time, however, it would subsume Netscape, an Internet software maker once regarded a the most serious challenger to Microsoft's dominance of the personal computer software market. Netscape, founded in 1994, ha struggled over the last 18 month under an assault from Microsoft. Its Navigator wa the runaway leader in the market for the browser software used to navigate the World Wide Web. But Microsoft, responding to the Internet revolution, entered the market aggressively, quickly matching the quality of Netscape's technology and then bundling the Microsoft browser, Internet Explorer, into it industry-standard Windows operating system and giving it away free. Earlier this year, Netscape announced layoff and started distributing Navigator for free a well, a Microsoft steadily gained in the browser market. Since then, Netscape ha focused mainly on two business advertising and transaction fee from it Netcenter Web site and selling industrial-strength software to corporation that are building their own Internet site on which to conduct electronic commerce. AOL belief it ha the expertise to increase revenue from Netscape's Web site and, helped by Sun's programmer and vast corporate sale force, to accelerate Netscape's software sale a well, executive involved in the negotiation said. Sun's version of Unix, Solaris, is among the most popular operating system for the large, powerful computer that run Netscape's server software. This deal would insure that the fundamental element of Netscape survive within bigger company that can drive it technology forward, said David B. Yoffie, a professor at the Harvard business school and co-author with Michael A. Cusumano of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology of a recent book, Competing on Internet Time: Lessons from Netscape and Its Battle with Microsoft. The impact of the deal, if any, on the government's antitrust suit against Microsoft is uncertain. It doe appear to support a key theme of Microsoft's defense namely, that it operates in a fast-moving industry where corporate alliance shift all the time. Thus, Microsoft argues, antitrust policy should tread gently. But the deal, government official insist, should have no direct effect on the current case. No matter how much the alliance shift, it doesn't affect the central fact of Microsoft's monopoly and how it ha used and abused it market power to protect it monopoly, said David Boies, the Justice Department's lead trial lawyer in the Microsoft case. Executives representing Netscape, AOL and Sun Microsystems are government witness at the Microsoft trial. And the serious merger talk between Netscape Chief Executive Officer James Barksdale and AOL Chairman Steve Case began about a month ago, or just after the start of the Microsoft trial, according to people close to the talk. Industry analyst suggest that the company may have been emboldened to take stronger anti-Microsoft step based partly on the perception that the antitrust case would weaken Microsoft. And representative of Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, a Silicon Valley venture capital firm regarded a a power broker among Microsoft's rival, sit on the board of Netscape, Sun and AOL. Stock price vaulted to record level Monday, furthering a recovery that a recently a two month ago seemed nearly unthinkable. I thought we were in the most serious correction since 1990, but I never thought or wrote that the bull market wa over, said Byron Wien, US. equity strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Co. Now it seems all of that is behind u. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 214.72 point, or 2.34 percent, to 9,37427. The record is the first since July 17, when the Dow closed at 9,33797. Since Aug. 31, when the Dow stood at 7,539.07 after a steep slide, the blue-chip gauge ha risen more than 24 percent. For the year, the Dow is up 18.54 percent and ha a chance of rising more than 20 percent for a fourth consecutive year, something never accomplished before. Broader average also climbed. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index set a record, rising 24.66 point, or 2.12 percent, to 1,18821. The Nasdaq composite index did not reach a new high but posted the biggest percentage gain Monday, rising 49.21 point, or 2.55 percent, to 1,97742. And the Russell 2000 index of smaller-company issue gained 3.86 point, or nearly 1 percent, to 39815. Monday's action wa energized by a daily record for the number of merger and acquisition valued at $1 billion or more. The merger announcement not only prompted investor to change estimate of how much company were worth but also indicated coming decline in the outstanding share of stock. This may be a supply-demand story, where demand for stock is rising and the supply of stock is reduced a one company after another merges, said Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer at First Albany Corp. The flow of money into mutual fund is fairly strong, and there is pressure on manager to put that money to work. Two deal seemed to be catalyst for broad swath of stock. News that Bankers Trust may be close to accepting an $8.9 billion offer from Deutsche Bank of Germany heightened interest in financial-services and bank stock. And word that America Online may acquire Netscape Communications for $4 billion in stock powered Internet and other technology stock to even loftier valuation. Among financial company, JP. Morgan gained 6 1/16, to 115 11/16. American Express wa up 4 3/8, to 108 15/16. Merrill Lynch jumped 4 3/8, to 76. And Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette rose 3 9/16, to 42}. Netscape wa the most active stock Monday, gaining 2}, to 41 15/16. America Online gained 4 3/8, to 89\. Other Internet stock also surged, and analyst said the group, which ha seen meteoric gain in recent week, wa ripe for a steep correction. Yahoo and Amazon.com both became $200 stock on Monday. Yahoo rose 30 7/16, to 221 7/16. And Amazon.com gained 37 3/8, to 218. The performance of the Internet stock is an unsettling sign, Wien said. Still, more-established technology share also had a very good day. IBM rose 7, to 166 5/8. Microsoft jumped 5 9/16, to 119 3/16. And Intel closed at 113 9/16, up 1{. After Monday's big price move, Wien said that according to his calculation, stock were about 10 percent overvalued. By contrast, in the middle of July the market wa 20 percent overvalued, he said. Nonetheless, the market's recovery, which ha been buttressed by three cut in interest rate by the Federal Reserve Board, ha left many longtime Wall Street hand grasping for historical parallel. At this point we are in new ground, said Laszlo Birinyi, who head his own market research firm. At the beginning of the year, I said my target for the Dow wa 10,000 by the end of 1998. If anyone had asked when the market went through what now look like a corrective blip, I would have said my new target would have been about 9,000. I am surprised the 10,000 figure came back on the table for this year. The New York Times said in an editorial for Wednesday, Nov. 25: America Online's effort to acquire Netscape and set up a partnership with Sun Microsystems is a reminder of how rapidly the corporate landscape can change in fast-moving technical field. But it doe not lessen the need for the Justice Department to vigorously pursue it antitrust suit against Microsoft, the dominant player in software. The department ha presented solid evidence that Microsoft ha used it monopoly in operating system to muscle rival and partner so a to head off competition in other software realm. The Internet ha risen so quickly a an information medium that only four year ago, in his book The Road Ahead, Bill Gates scarcely mention it. In addition, only a couple of year ago America Online, the world's biggest online service, wa having so much trouble getting rid of the bug in the system it wa widely derided a America On Hold. Now Microsoft ha moved so aggressively into the Internet that the Justice Department is accusing it of predatory behavior, and America Online ha rocketed forward to make deal with other Internet player. In it antitrust suit against Microsoft, the federal government charge that the company ha illegally bundled it own browser with it Windows operating system to smother Netscape's chance of marketing it browser. Now in the corridor outside the antitrust trial Microsoft's lawyer maintain that Netscape ha found a new partner in America Online and ha no need of protection from the government. But it could be a easily argued that Microsoft ha bludgeoned Netscape into dissolution, forcing a distress sale to America Online. Nor is it clear that customer of America Online will choose Netscape's browser a a vehicle for buying and selling on the Internet. Even in it newly musclebound form, America Online remains dependent on Microsoft's good will for favorable placement of an AOL icon on the main desktop screen. It may be that, year hence, America Online, Netscape and Sun will put together an alternative mean to the Internet through telephone line, cable or the like. But until that day, fairness requires Justice Department action to insure that Microsoft not use it current position to thwart consumer choice. Only when company know they can get their product to the consumer will they have the incentive to innovate and turn the Internet into the revolutionary medium it promise to be.

Kuchma did not elaborate in his comment to a group of Ukrainian economist, saying only that the change were necessary because of the country's economic problem. Kuchma urged the economist to come up with recommendation before a national meeting of economist in November, the Interfax news agency reported. Ukraine ha suffered economic problem since the 1991 collapse of the Soviet Union and it ha been especially hard hit by the financial crisis in neighboring Russia, it main trading partner. The Russian crisis ha hurt bilateral trade, caused the Ukrainian currency to fall and led to a withdrawal of investor from Ukraine. In recent month, Kuchma ha implemented some economic reform by decree, prompting the International Monetary Fund to release the first installment of a long-awaited dlrs 2.2 billion loan. Many reform, however, remain stalled. National Bank chairman Viktor Yushchenko wa in Washington this week for consultation with IMF official. Yushchenko ha warned that the bank would not spend it dwindling reserve to support the hryvna currency, but ha avoided comment on the currency in recent day. Kuchma met Friday with Yushchenko, Prime Minister Valery Pustovoitenko and other senior official to discus way to stabilize the hryvna. The government's press service said they focused on possible way to keep the hryvna under 3.5 to the US. dollar through the end of the year. The hryvna ha been trading at 3.4 to the dollar in recent day but trading ha been limited. There are wide expectation in Ukraine that the hryvna will fall even further, and Ukrainians have been stocking up on food, clothing and household good to save their fast-devaluing money. When the world's finance minister and central banker gathered last year in Hong Kong, they nervously congratulated each other for containing at least for the moment a nasty financial brush fire in Asia. In a year's time, many predicted in hallway chatter, the trouble in Thailand and Indonesia would look like a replay of Mexico in 1995 a rough bump in the road for a world enjoying remarkable prosperity. Talk about bad market call. Twelve month later, a the same financial mandarin clog Washington with their limousine and glide through endless reception at the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, just about everything that could have gone wrong in the world economy has: the worst downturn in Japan since World War II, economic meltdown in Russia, a depression in Indonesia that is plunging 100 million people below the poverty line, and deep fear over what happens next in Latin America. What make this year's IMF meeting most remarkable, though, is that the harshest criticism are directed at the monetary fund itself, and, by extension, at the US. Treasury, which is viewed a the power behind the IMF. This year, in place of confident prediction, there are mutual recrimination. Arguments are breaking out over whether the true culprit were crony capitalist and weakened leader like Russian President Boris Yeltsin, or huge investor who poured money into the world's emerging market with reckless abandon in the mid-1990s and panicked in the past twelve month. Whatever the reason, one reality prevails: Hundreds of billion of dollar have fled from economy on four continent seeking the safest haven possible, often in the United States and the money is not returning anytime soon. And the subtext of every seminar on capital flow and every conclave of nervous minister will be some painfully blunt questions: Can this be stopped? Or is the world headed for a global recession? Fifty-three year ago the IMF wa created after the Bretton Woods conference which sought to stabilize the world economy and secure the peace after World War II. Now it is under attack from all side, charged not only with worsening a bad situation by misjudging the economics, but with being politically tone-deaf in some of the most volatile capital in the world, from Jakarta, Indonesia, to Moscow. For the first time, there are disturbing question about whether the institution itself is still capable, financially or politically, of containing the kind of economic contagion that caught the world unaware. Once, the IMF's critic were largely found in Africa and South Asia, were the fund wa often viewed a arrogant; today they include Wall Street's biggest player and top official in the most powerful economy of Asia and Europe. Only a few including former Secretary of State George Schultz and member of Congress who are increasingly suspicious of all international institution are talking about scrapping the IMF altogether. But almost everyone is talking about creating a new financial architecture that can do what the old one clearly cannot: smother financial wildfire before they leap around the globe. Russia want the IMF to release the second dlrs 4.3 billion installment of a loan that wa approved in July, a month before the country's economy crashed and the government effectively defaulted on it foreign loan. In a season of crashing bank, plunging ruble, bouncing paycheck, failing cropsand rotating government, maybe it is not the ultimate insult. But the nation that bore Tolstoy and Chekhov, and still regard a well-written letter a a labor of love, is buckling a little this week, because it can no longer wish good health to Baba Anya in Omsk. A second airport is still demanding 3 million ruble for past-due debt. So much mail is backed up that post office in Moscow and elsewhere have simply stopped accepting out-of-town mail, except for area that can be easily reached by truck. Delivery schedule have fallen week, and perhaps month, behind. data: Endeavour's astronaut connected the first two building block of the international space station on Sunday, creating a seven-story tower in the shuttle cargo bay. It wa the first time that the Russian-built Zarya control module and the made-in-America Unity chamber had ever touched. It looked to be a perfect and, hopefully, long-lasting fit. We have capture of Zarya, commander Robert Cabana announced the two piece came together. Congratulations to the crew of the good ship Endeavour, replied Mission Control. That's terrific. The 240-mile-high construction job began two hour earlier with Nancy Currie's capture of Zarya (Russian for Sunrise) using the shuttle robot arm. We're halfway home, Cabana said. Then came the hard part: stacking the two giant cylinder in the cargo bay. The two station piece are so big 77 foot from the tip of one to the tip of the other with a combined mass of 70,000 pound that Currie and her crewmates had to rely on a computerized vision system and camera view, rather than direct line of sight. This wa the first time such a blind docking had ever been attempted. Currie positioned the solar-winged Zarya, still on the end of the shuttle robot arm, several inch directly above Unity. It wa slow going; she wanted and needed perfect alignment. Once she wa sure she had it, Cabana fired Endeavour's thruster, and the brief burst raised the shuttle and thereby Unity enough for the docking mechanism on the two station component to snap together. The historical moment occurred above the South Pacific. The union intended to last the station's 15-year or more lifetime set the stage for a spacewalk by two astronaut on Monday to attach electrical connector and cable between the two component. Mission Control thought Sunday's work might take hour longer than planned and gave the six astronaut plenty of time for the task. But everything occurred more or le when and how it wa supposed to, aside from a piece of space junk that strayed too close. Before beginning their final approach to Zarya, the six astronaut had to steer clear of a chunk of a rocket launched last month from California. Mission Control ordered the pilot to fire the shuttle thruster to put an extra three mile between Endeavour and the space junk, putting Endeavour a total of five mile from the orbiting debris. The smaller gap would have been probably a little too close for comfort, Mission Control said. The bigger worry, by far, wa over Endeavour's pursuit and capture of Zarya, and it coupling with Unity. The shuttle's 50-foot robot arm had never before handled an object a massive a the 41-foot, 44,000-pound Zarya, a power and propulsion module that wa launched from Kazakstan on Nov. 20. It will provide all of the necessary electricity and steering for the fledgling space station until a permanent control module can be launched next summer. Minutes after Zarya's capture, Cabana called down that two antenna on the module were still undeployed a Russian flight controller had feared. The antenna must be fully deployed in order for Zarya's manual docking system to work; that system won't be needed before next summer, official said. The only other problem wa with a Zarya battery; the astronaut took up a replacement part. The 36-foot, 25,000-pound Unity, the first American-made component, will serve a a connecting passageway, or vestibule, for future module. It wa crucial that Zarya and Unity be joined; if they could not be connected with the robot arm, NASA would have sent out two spacewalking astronaut to manually fit them together. In all, three spacewalks are planned for Endeavour's 12-day flight, not only to hook up electrical connection between the two module but to install handrail and other tool for future crew. The joined module will be released from Endeavour once all of the work is completed. NASA estimate 43 more launch and 159 more spacewalks will be needed after this mission to assemble the entire orbiting complex. Once completed, the 16-nation space station will have a mass of 1 million pound, be longer than a football field, and house up to seven astronaut and cosmonaut. WASHINGTON NASA and the Russian Space Agency have agreed to set aside a last-minute Russian request to launch an international space station into an orbit closer to Mir, official announced Friday. While putting the new station closer to Russia's 12-year-old Mir station would make it easier to transfer equipment and supply from the old outpost to the new one, the request came too late to be acted on, said Randy Brinkley, NASA's space station program manager. NASA wa surprised last week when Russia's prime station contractor proposed the orbital position change just two-and-a-half week before launch of the first part of the new station. Delaying the Nov. 20 flight by 10 hour to match the orbit would have forced similar shift in the subsequent assembly flight, and resulted in potentially unfavorable sun angle on the solar-powered station, engineer said. We have mutually concluded that it would not be prudent to make these change, Brinkley said during a news conference held at the Johnson Space Center in Houston. It added technical complexity and risk to the mission that were not justified. The decision, which followed frank and candid discussion between the two partner, wa not imposed by the United States, he said. The conclusion were mutual, Brinkley said. Both side concluded that it did not make sense. The Russians, struggling to find money for their space program with their nation in economic collapse, had said they wanted to transfer thousand of pound of newer equipment and scientific instrument from Mir a an economy move. However, some critic questioned the Russians' motif, wondering if the requested orbital change wa part of plan to delay the decommissioning and destruction of Mir, which the Russians have agreed to do next summer. The Russians have so little money that the United States and other partner in the international station fear that money spent on Mir will prevent Russia from meeting it obligation with the new project. The Mir competes with the international space station for very critical resource and for funding, Brinkley said. NASA will consider idea for salvaging Mir's research equipment to use on the international space station, he said, but only if it doe not interfere with assembling the new station. The United States and 15 other nation plan to begin building the new station in orbit next week when the Russians launch a module that will supply power and propulsion during the early stage of the five-year construction period. When Alfred Nobel wrote the direction establishing a literature prize in his name, he chose an unclear word and scratched out a few letter. Questions about the prize have engaged and piqued the literary world ever since. A new chapter in the mystery will be written Thursday, when the Swedish Academy announces this year's winner of the world's most prestigious prize for writer. The prize focus intense medium attention on the Swedish capital and the clamor of journalist generally drowns out a question: Why doe the world care so much about the literary choice of a handful of people in a quiet and remote country? Does the Nobel Prize really recognize the best? When asked that question, Swedish Academy permanent secretary Sture Allen smiled and said Look at the list of prizewinners! The answer obscures a much a it clarifies. On one hand, the Nobel Prize ha recognized world-renowned writer such a Isaac Bashevis Singer and brought little-known wonder to light, such a Wislawa Szymborska. But the prize arguably also ha honored the mediocre, heaping attention on those who would have been more fairly served by obscurity. Among them is the winner of the first prize in 1901, Sully Prudhomme. That choice wa denounced by Sweden's leading literary light, August Strindberg, and a group of Swedes sent a letter to Leo Tolstoy apologizing for the Academy's slight in not choosing him. Arguments over the Academy's choice are inevitable, considering the instruction they were given. Nobel's will say the prize should recognize literature that work in an ideal direction. What, exactly, he meant by ideal** is unclear and the Academy's choice have reflected the confusion. The Academy ha chosen to interpret the word to apply to work ranging from the good-hearted charm of Szymborska's poetry to the crushing hopelessness of Samuel Beckett's writing. When Nobel wrote the word ideal in Swedish idealisk** he superimposed the last couple of letter over previous one. Allen wa so curious to understand Nobel's thought that he engaged a forensic expert to try to find out what the earlier letter were. The expert succeeded to a point. He found that the first word Nobel wrote wa idealirad, a word that doesn't exist. Despite the inclarity around the edge, Allen said he is confident that the Academy's choice bolster Nobel's core idea that literature would be the basis for some kind of progress. But observer love to speculate on who might win, even who's on the shortlist for the prize, this year worth 7.6 million kronor (about dlrs 974,000). Names that freuqently come up in the guessing include VS. Naipaul, China's Bei Dao and Pa Kin, American poet John Ashbery, and Jose Saramago of Portugal. A day after winning the Nobel Prize for literature, Portuguese novelist Jose Saramago insisted that while he wa delighted to win the award, it could just a easily have gone to many other Portuguese writer. I'm not the only one who deserved it, said the first Portuguese-language author to obtain the prestigious award. There have been other Portuguse author, like Fernando Pessoa, whose work would justify 1,000 Nobels Speaking at a packed press coference in Madrid, Saramago joked about how he heard he had won the prize from German air hostess at Frankfurt airport a he waited for a flight home to Spain's Canary Islands. The news left the 75-year-old writer no choice but to leave the airport and return to the city's book fair to meet the press and public. At that moment I wa over the moon and returning to the book fair the only thing I wa worried about wa that the whole thing wa an error, said Saramago. Dismissing the Vatican paper's disapproval Thursday of his achievment, Saramago, a known atheist, quipped that he wa aware that the Pope had been among the jury, I wouldn't have won the prize. The Vatican is easily upset, said Saramago, I think that the Vatican should keep it mind on it prayer and leave people alone. The two leading daily, Publico and Diario de Noticias, gave over their entire front page to Saramago. Lisbon City Hall rushed out poster saying Congratulations Jose Saramago which were hung up around the capital during the night. Saramago wa born into a poor, illiterate family in Azinhaga, a small town near Lisbon. He never finished university but continued to study part-time while supporting himself a a metalworker. Nothing in my life would have led one to think I'd win the Nobel Prize, said Saramago. I wasn't born to win the Nobel. I didn't have my own book until I wa 18. Three American researcher on Monday won the Nobel Medicine Prize for discovering how nitric oxide act a a signal molecule in the cardiovascular system, a breakthrough with application ranging from hardening of the artery to impotence. The prestigious prize went to Robert F. Furchgott, Louis J. Ignarro and Ferid Murad. Furchgott is a pharmacologist at the State University of New York in Brooklyn, Ignarro is at University of California-Los Angeles and Murad is at the University of Texas Medical School in Houston. The citation by the Karolinska Institute said it wa a senation that the simple, common air pollutant (nitric oxide), which is formed when nitrogen burn . could exert important function in the organism. Because of the research, we know today that nitric oxide act a a signal molecule in the nervous system, a a weapon against infection and a a regulator of blood pressure. Signal transmission by a gas that is produced by one cell, penetrates through membrane and regulates the function of another cell represents an entirely new principle, the citation said. Understanding how nitric oxide transmits the signal ha sparked research on a wide range of new drug, including those that can be used in the treatment of heart problem, artherosclerosis, shock and impotence. The prize amount of 7.6 million kronor (dlrs 978,000) is divided equally among the three. Last year, the prize went to Stanley B. Prusiner of the University of California at San Francisco for his discovery of prion, the rogue protein identified a causing Mad Cow Disease. Winners generally aren't known outside the medical community, although the list of laureate contains a few familiar name including Ivan Pavlov, tuberculosis pioneer Robert Koch, and DNA researcher Francis Crick and James Watson. Generally, they are researcher who have made discovery that sound small on paper but carry large consequence. Among other well-known name to receive the prize is David Baltimore, although he shared the prize in 1975, long before becoming one of the world's most visible AIDS researcher. Alan Cormack of the United States and Sir Godfrey Hounsfield may not be familiar name, but what they won the prize for in 1979 is a term known by most patients: computer-assisted tomography or CAT scan. The medicine prize wa the second of the six Nobels to be announced this year. Last Thursday, the literature prize went to Portuguese novelist Jose Saramago. The physic and chemistry prize will be announced Tuesday, the economics prize on Wednesday and the peace prize on Friday. All the announcement are in Stockholm, except for the peace prize which is given in Oslo, Norway. The prize are presented on Dec. 10, the anniversary of the death of Alfred Nobel, the industrialist and inventor of dynamite whose will established the prize.

data: Secretary General Kofi Annan said Wednesday he wa extending his North African tour to include talk with Libyan authority. The remark wa made without elaboration at a news conference in Algiers hour before his arrival in Tunis, his final scheduled stop on a tour aimed at unblocking plan for a UN. referendum on the disputed Western Sahara. During his visit to Tunis, Annan is to meet with authority here to discus major regional and international issue and the various initiative aimed at solving unresolved problem, according to the local press. A Western diplomat, speaking in Algiers on condition of anonymity, said Annan would travel to Libya on Saturday to meet with authority there on the 1988 Pan Am bombing that ha led to UN. sanction against Libya. Annan's trip to Tunisia is scheduled to end Friday, according to the official program. The discrepancy in the timing could not be immediately clarified. The UN. Security Council imposed sanction in 1992, including a flight ban, to try to force Libya to hand over two suspect in the bombing that killed 270 people. The sanction ban flight to and from the country. Neighboring Tunisia provides a land route for those traveling to Libya from the region. A week ago, before leaving for North Africa, Annan held out the possibility of a Libyan trip -- but only to help close a deal to try the two suspect. A Libyan legal team ha been meeting regularly with Annan's legal counsel to discus a U.S.-British proposal to try the suspect in the Netherlands according to Scottish law and using Scottish judge. Annan had said last week that he had hoped for a breakthrough in the case by the end of November. He said then that a trip to Libya to bring the issue finally to closure . ha not been excluded. During his Algerian stay, After meeting Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi in a desert tent, UN. Secretary-General Kofi Annan said he think an arrangement for bringing two suspect to trial in the bombing of a Pan Am airliner could be secured in the not too distant future. Annan's comment came Saturday after he and Gadhafi failed to agree on handing over Abdel Basset Ali al-Megrahi and Lamen Khalifa Fhimah, who are suspected in the 1988 bombing that killed 270 people. Annan spoke to reporter in the Libyan capital of Tripoli after the meeting and again later when he arrived back at this Tunisian island, where he had begun his 15-hour stretch of diplomacy. The 60-year-old Annan is trying to get Libya to go along with a U.S.-British plan to try the two suspect before a panel of Scottish judge in the Netherlands for the Dec. 21, 1988, bombing over Lockerbie, Scotland. The talk have been fruitful and positive, Annan said in Tripoli. Libya ha confirmed it seriousness and readiness to find a solution to the Lockerbie problem. Libya ha also agreed to a trial in a third country and belief that it ought to be possible to find answer to all other outstanding issue, he said. So I hope that in the not too distant future we will be able to give the family good news, he added, referring to the relative of victim who have lobbied extensively for a trial. On Sunday, British Foreign Secretary Robin Cook said in an interview with the British Broadcasting Corp. that I think you could sum up our mood a one of qualified optimism. He said he spoke with Annan on Sunday and wa very encouraged by what he tell me. But Cook said Britain will not budge on the demand by Washington and London that the suspect serve any sentence in a Scottish jail. Annan said he wa tired after arriving back in Jerba. He left Sunday for a summit of the Gulf Cooperation Council, a federation of six Gulf state, which begin Monday in the United Arab Emirates. In Washington, James Foley, a State Department spokesman, said the United States is awaiting a briefing from Annan but is disappointed that Libya ha not complied with UN. Security Council resolution. Compliance mean turnover of the two suspect for trial, Foley said. It's been almost 10 year since the Pan Am 103 tragedy, this ha gone on for far too long. State-run Libyan Radio quoted an unnamed official in the Foreign Liaison Secretariat, which is the equivalent of a foreign ministry, a saying Sunday that a solution to this crisis is within reach. Annan's meeting with Gadhafi took place after Libya's official news agency, JANA, initially reported that Annan might not be able to meet with the Libyan leader because Gadhafi wa in the desert.
