data: The raw passion were such that the House Democrats did not to hesitate to bellow You resign! You resign! at Speaker-elect Robert Livingston when he called from the House floor for President Clinton to quit the White House in the face of certain impeachment. Shockingly, stunningly, Livingston did just that. He quit in one breathtaking utterance, a if flicking a trump card onto the heap of impeachment angst festering before his eye in the debating chamber. In his one and only strategem in leading his fellow House Republicans, Livingston's decision struck Congress like a verbal bomb. Stunned Democrats saw their fury vaporized upon the instant. They had to stand, almost staggering to their foot, to join the Republicans in a prolonged, emotional ovation for Livingston and his undeniable self-sacrifice. As they stood, the Democrats sensed Livingston had most suddenly closed a trap on the president and his defender. For, with the impeachment issue set to move to the Senate, Livingston, whose own marital indiscretion were now before the public to his obvious misery, chose to show how the question of a political leader's resignation wa very much in play in this tumult-tossed city. I must set the example that I hope President Clinton will follow, Livingston declared, flabbergasting all attending the impeachment debate and the nation watching beyond. Livingston walked off the floor like the sheriff in some bullet-pocked political High Noon, discarding the leadership badge he had wrested from the earlier speaker-casualty, Newt Gingrich. In the corridor just beyond, a doorman shouted to a police officer: Livingston just resigned! What? What? came the reply from the officer, who obviously thought the momentous announcement would be about Clinton's impeachment, not Livingston's political self-immolation. Just so, the Democrats, already deep into bone-raw exhaustion after their long fight to save the president, grasped for bearing. It is a surrender to a developing sexual McCarthyism! declared Rep. Jerrold Nadler, D-N.Y., a leading presidential defender trying to rally Democrats around the argument that Livingston should not resign any more than President Clinton should quit under fire. But the Republicans were surging to the fore on the strength of Livingston's announcement, fighting tear a they rose to salute him a the ultimate political role model in the grueling impeachment process a it roared into the final minute of debate. For some it is no longer good enough to make a mistake, to confirm that mistake and take the consequence of that mistake, said Tom DeLay, the Republican whip, his hand shaking, his eye tearing a he addressed the House and sought to drive the example of Livingston all the way down Pennsylvania Avenue. He understood what this debate wa all about honor, duty, integrity and the truth, said DeLay arguing that in one swift blow, Livingston had demonstrated himself to have been a far better speaker than Clinton ha been a president. With something of the political elan the president showed in initiating the Iraq attack a his own impeachment loomed, House Republicans, battered in public opinion poll, had found a rocket's red glare of their own. I have hurt you all deeply and beg your forgiveness, Livingston told the House, the nation and his family a he announced retreat. Only moment before, Democrats openly hissed the man a Livingston firmly read his own judgment upon the president: Sir, you have done great damage to this nation over the past year. Presidential resignation wa in order, he continued, and then came the shout of You resign! You resign! And a Livingston closed the circle on his career, he stunned the place into a collective breath of disbelief and somehow almost threatened to reduce the dark historic issue before the House the impeachment of the president into a matter of anticlimax. They must not succeed, David Bonior, the Democratic whip said of the Republicans a he wa given the task of refocusing the day on the misdeed of the president, not the departure of the speaker. We are here to debate impeachment and should not be distracted from that, he declared. The only way we can stop this vicious cycle, Bonior cried out from the floor, is if we refuse to give into it, whether it is Bill Clinton or Bob Livingston. But the House wa still reeling through the frenzied day a the fateful vote on the presidency approached and the notion of resignation licked about the capital city like a flame in a forest. Rejecting a last-minute Democratic attempt to soften it action to censure, the House of Representatives moved to impeach President William Jefferson Clinton for perjury on Saturday and to call on the Senate to try him, convict him and remove him from office. But even before the vote, Republicans pressed another line of attack, demanding Clinton's resignation. Rep. Robert Livingston, nominated for speaker last month by his party, startled the House when he announced he would not run for speaker and would resign from the House after 21 year of service. He urged the president to heal the wound that you have created. You, sir, may resign your post. Angry Democrats booed and shouted, You resign! Livingston continued, I can only challenge you in such fashion if I am willing to heed my own word. Apologizing again for extramarital affair revealed two day ago, he said, I believe I had it in me to do a fine job. But I cannot do that job or be the kind of leader that I would like to be under current circumstance. Then he bolted from the House chamber, nearly knocking reporter and member down. (The House voted 228-206 to approve the first article of impeachment, accusing Clinton of committing perjury before a federal grand jury. The vote wa announced at 1:24 pm. EST, leaving the 42nd president to face trial in the Senate on whether he should be removed from office.) Clinton rejected the advice immediately. His spokesman, Joe Lockhart, said, The president ha no intention of resigning. By calling on Livingston to reconsider, the president argued more broadly against resignation under fire. Perhaps speaking to both case, Lockhart said, It would be wrong to give in to this insidious politics of personal destruction. Unless Clinton change course, this would be only the second impeachment of a president in the 209-year history of the Republic, and the first since Andrew Johnson wa acquitted in 1868. Sen. Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, ha insisted that no bargaining over censure can prevent it from starting. But the Senate could halt a trial later a part of a deal. Considering the degree of partisanship displayed Saturday, assembling the two-thirds majority required under the Constitution for conviction is most unlikely. Sixty-seven vote would be required, and there are only 55 Republicans in the Senate, along with 45 Democrats. Four article of impeachment before the House charged Clinton with perjury in lying about his affair with Monica Lewinsky to a federal grand jury here on Aug. 17. He wa also charged with perjury in the Paula Jones sexual harassment suit, obstruction of justice and abuse of power. The Republican argument, over and over, wa that Clinton had lied in denying having sexual relation with Ms. Lewinsky. Rep. Dick Armey of Texas, the majority leader, said, A nation of law cannot be ruled by a person who break the law. Rep. Nancy Johnson of Connecticut said: There can be no justice without the truth. That is just profoundly so, and that is why perjury matter. Rep. Gerald Kleczka of Wisconsin began the Democrats' argument by saying, What the president did wa wrong, both personally and morally, but his act did not threaten our democracy and thus do not rise to the level of impeachable offense a defined by our founding father in our Constitution. Rep. Charles Schumer, New York's senator-elect, said: The rule of law requires that the punishment fit the crime. Allow u to vote for censure. Saturday's vote were the penultimate step in the most serious conflict between Congress and a president since Richard M. Nixon resigned in the face of impeachment and certain conviction on Aug. 9, 1974. But while that case spun out from a 1972 break-in at Democratic headquarters in the Watergate complex, this one began with a murky land deal in Arkansas in 1978. Through the effort of Kenneth Starr, the independent counsel under the law enacted in the wake of Watergate, the investigation spread to examine Clinton's affair with a White House intern. All year it ha preoccupied the capital despite an immense disconnect with public opinion; since the scandal became public in January, poll have shown that the public opposed impeachment and wanted the inquiry brought to an end. Even on Friday night, after a 13-hour debate, a CBS News Poll of 548 people showed that only 38 percent wanted their representative to vote for impeachment; 58 percent wanted a no vote. The conflict now enters uncharted sea, since the Nixon resignation cut the matter short and the Johnson trial occurred in a different America, with no nuclear weapon or cable television or public opinion poll. But the capital wa still rife with confident speculation. Some guessed, or hoped, that the result of the recent poll, which showed increase in support for resignation a a way to spare the nation a trial in which Ms. Lewinsky and Linda Tripp would be star witness, would weaken Clinton's resolve. Others thought the Republicans, seeing dismal number in poll about their party's standing in the United States, would be the first to blink. With a majority in the Senate, they have the power to end a trial at any time after the Senate receives notice of impeachment on the day it convenes, Jan. 6, or the next day. But while Clinton ha focused on the poll, and the CBS News survey showed that 64 percent still approve of his handling of his job a president, resignation could almost immediately subject him to criminal prosecution. And Republicans have steadfastly ignored the poll all year, and confronted them directly on Saturday. Representative JC. Watts of Oklahoma, newly elected a chairman of the Republican caucus, said: What's popular isn't always right. You say poll are against this. Polls measure changing feeling, not steadfast principle. Polls would have rejected the Ten Commandments. Polls would have embraced slavery and ridiculed women's right. You say we must draw this to a close. I say we must draw a line between right and wrong, not with a tiny fine line of an executive fountain pen, but with the big fat lead of a No. 2 pencil. And we must do it so every kid in America can see it. The point is not whether the president can prevail, but whether truth can prevail. Last weekend, when the Judiciary Committee recommended the four article of impeachment, Clinton's side still hoped to prevail with the help of 20 to 30 Republican moderate who were uncommitted. As the week wore on, almost all of them broke against the president. One who did not, Rep. Christopher Shays of Connecticut, said Saturday: After Judge Starr's report to Congress in September, and his presentation to the Judiciary Committee in November, I concluded that impeachable offense were not proven, and that the proven offense were not impeachable. But the president's continued failure to come to grip with his action, the sincerity and argument of member of the Judiciary Committee from both side of the aisle, the change of heart and conviction by member on my side of the aisle who originally opposed impeachment and who now support it, and the strong and powerful opinion of so many of my constituent who oppose my position and who wanted the president impeached caused me to rethink my position. He added: Yesterday morning, before I visited with the president, I concluded that my original position wa the correct one, for me. I believe that the impeachable offense have not been proven, and that the proven offense are not impeachable. But Rep. Tom DeLay of Texas, who ha led the Republican effort to force Clinton from office, dismissed his and other argument a moral relativism. He began by praising Livingston: There is no greater American in my mind, at least today, than Bob Livingston, because he understood what this debate wa all about. It wa about honor and decency and integrity and the truth; everything that we honor in this country. It wa also a debate about relativism v. absolute truth. He continued, The president's defender have said that the president is morally reprehensible, that he is reckless, that he ha violated the trust of the American people, lessened their esteem for the office of president and dishonored the office which they have entrusted him, and that but that doesn't rise to the level of impeachment. Rep. Jose Serrano of New York said, My constituent don't hate Bill Clinton; they love him and they're praying for him right at this very moment. Republicans called Clinton a liar, even a he wa committing American pilot to the sky over Iraq, and Democrats accused their rival of conducting a political lynching or a political coup d'etat. Bipartisanship may have been the biggest victim of all. Party line on Saturday's roll call held a firm a leg iron. Almost all of the Republicans who opposed impeachment did so not exclusively on legal principle but at least partly because of special political circumstance the Democratic majority in Rep. Constance Morella's district in the Maryland suburb of Washington, for example, and the gratitude of Rep. Peter King, R-N.Y., for Clinton's peacemaking in Ireland. It is hard to see who ha emerged from it with reputation enhanced, except perhaps Hillary Rodham Clinton, staunch in the face of deception. If some of the threat and dire prediction uttered by House Democrats in recent day are to be taken at face value, the nation is entering upon an Era of Bad Feelings, the polar opposite of a second Era of Good Feelings, similar to that of the 1820s, that Clinton had hoped to preside over. Rep. Tom Sawyer, D-Ohio, compared Clinton on Friday to Sir Thomas More, executed for treason in 1535 because of his religious belief. He quoted More's word a an admonition for today: What you have hunted me for is not my action but for the thought of my heart. It is a long road you have opened. God help the statesman who walk your road. But amidst all the loose talk about permanent damage to this institution or that, remember: Things change with startling speed in modern American politics, and the institution of American government have proved extraordinarily resilient. President Nixon, it wa almost universally agreed in 1974, had weakened the American presidency for many decade to come. Nobody said that after eight year under Ronald Reagan, and that wa only 15 year later. In the end, the will of the people meant nothing. Bob Livingston couldn't have been clearer about that. His mind and the mind of his follower were closed. Even a the bombing continued in Iraq and Americans from coast to coast were clamoring for an alternative to impeachment, even a his own adulterous past wa being flushed out in the grotesque invasion of privacy that inevitably followed the relentlessly prurient pursuit of the president, even a the country began to contemplate the destructive effect of a lengthy and bitter Senate trial, the speaker-designate arrogantly and stupidly proclaimed: Let u disregard the outside influence. The radical on the Hill would hear nothing but the echo of their own fanaticism. Impeach! Impeach! And that continued even after the stunning announcement Saturday morning that Livingston would quit the House. Dismayed by the partisan stampede, Dick Gephardt, the Democratic leader, warned during the impeachment debate on Friday: In your effort to uphold the Constitution, you are trampling the Constitution. David Bonior, the Democratic whip, said: This is wrong. It is unfair. It is unjust. At a time when event in the world and the challenge at home demand that we stand united, censure is the one solution that can bring u together. To my colleague across the aisle, I say let go of your obsession. Listen to the American people. But the voice of reason would not be heard. Livingston and his right-wing colleague, the Tom DeLays, the Henry Hydes, the Bob Barrs, were on a mission of destruction and would not be denied. Ordinary Americans could cry out all they wanted. They could protest and demonstrate, send fax and E-mails. It didn't matter. The right wa on the march and democracy wa on the run. Rep. Thomas Barrett, a Democrat from Wisconsin, tried to remind his Republican colleague that the Constitution doe not allow you to remove a president from office because you can't stand him. He wa, of course, ignored. The Republicans will pay a huge price for their brazen, utterly partisan attempt to drag a president from the White House in defiance of the will of the people. The party's contempt for the voter wa arrogantly but quite adequately summed up by Alan Simpson, the former senator from Wyoming, who said: The attention span of Americans is which movie is coming out next month and whether the quarterly report on their stock will change. If the voter are the dope that Mr. Simpson think they are, then come 2000 everyone will have forgotten there wa an impeachment crisis. But Rep. Robert Menendez, D-N.J., wa probably closer to the truth when he said, I warn my colleague that you will reap the bitter harvest of the unfair partisan seed you sow today. One of the many strange event of the past couple of week wa the way in which virtually all of the previously undecided Republicans, the so-called moderate, surrendered their independence and lined up like lackey to follow the right wing's lead. All proclaimed loudly that they were voting on principle, but in fact it wa an exercise in mass cowardice, exemplified by Rep. John McHugh of upstate New York. McHugh announced on Tuesday that he would vote for impeachment. But if his decision wa based on principle, he had an odd way of expressing it. The Washington Post said McHugh appeared to have no stomach for a Senate conviction or removal of the president from office. Of his colleague in the Senate, McHugh said, I, for one, would accept, even welcome, their mercy. In other word, let the Senate do the heavy constitutional lifting. McHugh may have wished out loud for mercy, but he clearly wa too frightened of the right-winger in the House to cast a compassionate vote himself. The GOP can no longer conceal that it is a party of extremist, of right-wing absolutist, a party out of step with the political and cultural orientation of most Americans. Bob Livingston may be leaving, but his arrogant comment can still serve a his party's slogan. Let u disregard the outside influence. Let u disregard the people.

Two astronaut ventured back out on another spacewalk Wednesday to attach antenna to the international space station under construction nearly 250 mile above Earth. For the second time this week, Jerry Ross and James Newman floated out the hatch of the shuttle Endeavour to work on the seven-story, 35-ton station taking shape in the open cargo bay. Their No. 1 priority wa to attach two 100-pound antenna to Unity, the American-made side of the space station. Their other job, time permitting, wa trickier: trying to open a stuck antenna on Zarya, the Russian-built control module. The planned seven-hour spacewalk wa not nearly a difficult or crucial a Monday night's outing, during which Ross and Newman hooked up 40 electrical connection between Zarya and Unity. The plan called for the men to lug two suitcase-size antenna about halfway up Unity and install them on opposite side of the 36-foot cylinder. Once activated, the antenna will provide a direct, virtually uninterrupted communication link between Unity and NASA's Mission Control. Otherwise, US. flight controller would have to rely on the sporadic coverage provided by Russian ground station. Other spacewalking chore for Ross and Newman on Wednesday evening included erecting a sunshade over a computer mounted to the outside of Unity. Mission Control decided just before the spacewalk to let Newman take a crack at unjamming the Zarya antenna. Flight controller urged caution. Newman also may try to unjam the other Zarya antenna. This wa the sixth spacewalk for Ross during his 18-year NASA career, the most by an American, and the third for Newman.

So far this year, the trade deficit is running roughly 50 percent above last year's level and is up to a projected $170 billion for the year, a gap that is expected to widen even further. One senior administration official who deal with economic issue, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Tuesday that internal projection suggest that the trade deficit in 1999 could reach $300 billion, a figure that he said will certainly cut into growth, and could well become a major political problem. Trade deficit carry with them both good and troubling signal about the economy. The current flood of import is helping contain inflation to some of the lowest level in decade. And while sale of American aircraft, computer chip and other good are suffering, the weakening of the dollar on world market in recent week may provide an end-of-the-year boost for American exporter. But at this moment of global upheaval, the biggest problem facing American company is the inability of many nation and some large company in Asia and Latin America simply to borrow money to make ordinary purchase. The result is such a freeze of economic activity that empty shipping container are stacking up on American pier. And the effect are hurting everyone from Midwest farmer who can no longer send wheat to an impoverished Russia, to East Coast fisherman who are discovering that Japan's appetite for salmon and lobster ha been ruined by the banking crisis. Among the most surprising element of Tuesday's report is that more than a third of August's deficit wa with one country that so far ha managed to ward off the worst effect of the global troubles: China. Despite continued growth of the Chinese economy, export to China have slowed dramatically and import of Chinese-made good have exploded, a the country desperately seek to sell here good that would ordinarily be sold elsewhere in Asia. That increased the monthly deficit with Beijing to $5.9 billion, level previously only seen in trade with Japan. The Chinese besieged by flood, deeply troubled state-owned industry and an incipient banking crisis have signaled to the United States in recent week that they have little interest in any swift move to open their market further in return for entry into the World Trade Organization. That amount to a major setback for President Clinton, who for three year ha been using the negotiation over China's entry to the world body a the centerpiece of his effort to open China both economically and politically. Ostensible progress in this area ha been cited by the administration until recently a one of the success of the administration's China policy, but now official say privately that the progress is evaporating. The decline in export will trim the growth of the American economy, and it wa one factor in the Federal Reserve's decision to lower interest rate two time in recent week. So administration official were going out of their way Tuesday to portray the number a another warning sign, but not a crisis. While the United States remains strong and sound, the troubled condition of the global marketplace continue to strongly influence the US. trade balance, Commerce Secretary Williams Daley said in a statement Tuesday. After China, the biggest deterioration in the American trade balance in August came in Mexico, where the peso ha weakened markedly a economic contagion ha spread through Latin America. Exports to Mexico have remained unchanged. But import from Mexico have increased markedly chiefly automobile and automotive part and telecommunication equipment a American manufacturer have taken advantage of the weakening currency. In contrast, America's trade surplus with Brazil, the latest focus of concern by the administration and the International Monetary Fund, barely budged from the same period a year ago. Normally, that would be cited a a sign of continued demand for American product in Latin America's largest economy, but there is fear it might be imperiled. The news come a the United States and the IMF complete a bailout package of $30 billion or more for Brazil, intended to help it stave off the kind of economic trouble that have swept through Asia, Russia and several other nation. Tuesday the IMF and Brazil reached agreement on the country's fiscal target for this year and next, a sign that the aid will likely be announced after election in Brazil this weekend. But for all these potential problem, the rising trade deficit ha barely caused a ripple on Capitol Hill. Because the rising level of import doe not appear to be triggering any unemployment here, the subject ha barely come up in race for the House and Senate around the country. The only exception ha been in region where the steel industry is strong. The major steel company have charged in recent week that Asian nation are dumping product on the American market at price well below their cost. The Commerce Department ha begun an inquiry. The Commerce Department's number showed that the deficit rose 15.3 percent to $16.77 billion in August, up from a revised figure of $14.55 billion in July. The department said that the resumption of production at General Motors Corp. after last summer's strike may have increased the size of the deficit's rise in August, a GM brought in part from abroad. The deficit wa the highest since the Commerce Department began a new method of tracking trade information in 1992. Exports, the department said, fell three tenth of 1 percent, to about $74.8 billion. Imports rose 2.2 percent to $91.6 billion.

President Bill Clinton won South Korea's support Saturday for confronting North Korea over a suspected nuclear site, and he warned the North's communist leader not to squander an historic chance to make a lasting peace on the peninsula. President Kim Dae-jung, appearing with Clinton at a news conference, pledged that his government would spare no effort in supporting the US. endeavor to resolve the nuclear question. He called for full access for US. inspector at a North Korean underground facility and said the North must constrain it development and export of missile. On the first of two day in South Korea, Clinton also held a roundtable discussion with business leader to hear their prescription for putting the nation's economy back on track. Economics and security are Clinton's twin theme on a five-day Asia trip that began in Japan. Clinton acknowledged that US. intelligence official are not yet certain that the suspicious underground construction project in North Korea is nuclear related. But he said the North risk closing the door on cooperation if it refuse a US. inspection of the site. It raise a strong suspicion, Clinton said at a joint news conference with Kim at the Blue House, the presidential mansion overlooking the capital. We need access to it. The foundation of US. effort to ease North Korea's decades-long hostility toward the South is a 1994 agreed framework in which the North halted it nuclear weapon program in exchange for a Western commitment to build modern nuclear energy source there. That deal would be shattered if the suspect site turned out to be a clandestine nuclear project. And that, in turn, would jeopardize preliminary North-South peace talk that could produce a treaty to replace the shaky armistice that ended the Korean War in 1953. Kim, who ha moved South Korea to a sunshine policy of engaging North Korea on cultural and economic front, firmly said his government support Clinton on the nuclear issue. We must require full access and way to ascertain the nature and the purpose of the construction site, Kim said. If it is, in fact, proven that it is nuclear related, we should demand immediate close down. He also said the North must limit it missile development, citing the great shock in Japan when the North Koreans test-fired a missile it way Aug. 31. In a dinner toast, Kim said that despite tension, North Korea is cautiously but noticeably taking measure to increase interaction and cooperation between the South and the North. And Clinton saluted Seoul's battle against Asia's economic woe. I believe Asia will emerge from this present crisis more prosperous, more stable, more democratic thanks in no small measure to Korea's example. After the state dinner, Clinton made a surprise late-night stop at a concert at the Sejong Culture Center where his younger brother, Roger, and his band were performing. The president listened to song off stage before his brother introduced the president a a very special person. The audience of 2,000 people stood and applauded. In meeting this week in Pyongyang, the North Korean capital, US. official were rebuffed in their request to see the suspicious underground site, which American intelligence official fear could be a secret effort to revive the North's nuclear weapon program. US. spy satellite photo show thousand of worker digging a massive complex. US. special envoy Charles Kartman said Thursday after the Pyongyang talk that there wa compelling evidence of an underground nuclear facility. But in a statement distributed by the US. Embassy here Saturday, Kartman backtracked, saying instead that the United States lack conclusive evidence the site is a nuclear facility. There is strong information that make u suspicious, but we lack conclusive evidence that the intended purpose of the underground site is nuclear related and, if so, what type of nuclear facility it might be, Kartman said, offering a clarification of his earlier remark. Kim said his government would spare no effort in supporting the US. endeavor to resolve the nuclear question. The North Koreans have denied the underground construction site ha any nuclear purpose, and it ha demanded a dlrs 300 million payment for proving that. In remark in Tokyo on Friday, Clinton rejected the idea of compensation. Directing his remark at North Korea, Clinton noted the significance of a new tourism deal that is bringing South Koreans to the North on cruise ship an arrangement touted by Kim a a sign the North may be opening up to it 1950s Korean War enemy. To risk that kind of cooperation and progress with America on other issue by stonewalling on the suspected nuclear site is contrary to the North's long-term interest, he said. Nothing could ever be put into that hole in the ground, given our defense partnership here, nothing could ever be put in that hole in the ground that would give the North Koreans a much advantage, a much power, a much wealth, a much happiness, a more of those ship going up there full of people from here, Clinton said. To underscore the US. military commitment to South Korea, Clinton wa scheduled to venture out of the capital on Sunday to visit US. Army troop at a training range north of Seoul. He also planned to address American troop at Osan Air Base from a U-2 spy plane hangar. North Korea ha demanded that the United States pay hundred of million of dollar for the right to inspect a huge underground center that US. intelligence analyst fear house a nuclear-weapons program, Clinton administration official said Wednesday. The United States rejected the request during meeting this week in Pyongyang, the North Korean capital, between North Korean official and a US. government delegation. As we expected, the North Koreans brought up the issue of compensation, and we flatly rejected it, said State Department Spokesman James Rubin. Asked how much money the North Koreans had demanded, Rubin said payment of the fee wa so not on a a possibility that I don't care to get into the figure. Other administration official said the fee would have been hundred of million of dollars; one put it at $300 million. The North Koreans have denied that the complex, which is being built on a mountainside about 25 mile northeast of Yongbyon, the former North Korean nuclear research center, is intended to be used for a nuclear weapon program. They have repeatedly said US. inspector could visit the site a long a Washington agreed to pay a large fee in compensation for what the North Koreans describe a the administration's slander. The North Korean representative at the United Nations, Kim Chang Guk, said last week that the United States could inspect the site on condition that when it is confirmed not to be a nuclear facility, the United States should pay compensation for slandering and defaming my country. US. intelligence agency fear that by building the complex, North Korea may have decided to abandon a four-year-old agreement with the United States in which North Korea pledged to give up it nuclear weapon program in exchange for billion of dollar in aid. The US. delegation, led by Charles Kartman, President Clinton's special envoy on North Korean issue, left Pyongyang on Wednesday after 12 hour of negotiation over three day with a team from the North Korean Foreign Ministry. The talk ended a Clinton began a trip to Asia that will include a visit to South Korea, where the issue of the North Korean construction site is expected to be among the major topic discussed with President Kim Dae-jung. Rubin said the US. delegation to North Korea had pressed for access to the site. We told them that access to the site is essential, he said. We've expected that this would be difficult, and we told the North Koreans, a we've said before, that verbal assurance, a they are wont to give, are simply unacceptable. US. official have said the construction of the underground site may not yet have technically violated the accord, because there is no evidence that North Korea ha begun pouring cement for a new reactor or a reprocessing plant to convert nuclear waste to bomb-grade plutonium. But if the United States determines that North Korea ha revived it nuclear program, Rubin said, it would go against the entire letter and spirit of the objective of the agreement, and it would affect the viability of the agreement. The administration ha expressed growing concern over North Korea's intention after several provocative act, including the underground construction near Yongbyon and the test firing last August of a missile over Japan. Last week Clinton named former Defense Secretary William Perry to review US. policy toward North Korea. Administration official say Perry is being asked to study way to salvage the 1994 nuclear agreement with North Korea, which had been among the administration's proudest achievement in foreign policy. North Korean news medium on Thursday said the communist nation's military is on full alert for war with the United States if a dispute over nuclear inspection come to blow. The North's official Korean Central News Agency reported that North Korean soldier and people of all walk of life were on full alert for war. North Korea typically sends out belligerent rhetoric, especially when it enters high-stake talk with Washington. The United States and North Korea are set to resume talk Friday about inspection of an underground North Korean site suspected of being used to produce nuclear weapon. KCNA broadcast brimmed with anti-American saber-rattling. Our People's Army will blow up the US. territory a a whole if the United States start a war on the divided Korean Peninsula, Vice Defense Minister Jong Chang Ryol wa quoted a saying Thursday. The general staff of the North Korean military accused Washington on Wednesday of pushing the situation in Korea to the brink of war by demanding inspection and talk aimed at preventing Pyongyang from developing nuclear weapon and long-range missile. Under the prevailing touch-and-go situation, the Korean People's Army is now bracing itself for a fight against the US. imperialist aggressor, KCNA quoted Jong a saying. The agency also quoted various party official, plant manager, even museum curator a pledging a thousandfold revenge or vowing to arm themselves with the spirit of human bomb and of suicidal attack. Washington demand unconditional inspection of the North's underground project. But North Korea asked Washington to pay dlrs 300 million for the right to inspect the site. Concerns that North Korea wa developing long-range missile capable of striking all of Japan and part of the United States escalated when North Korea fired a rocket on Aug. 31. Believed to be a test of it Taepo Dong missile, the rocket flew over Japan and landed in the Pacific Ocean. The North's 1.1 million-strong military is the world's fifth largest. It form the backbone of the North Korean government, with leader Kim Jong Il ruling the country a the head of the military. A congressman who visited remote part of North Korea last week said Saturday that the food and health situation there wa desperate and deteriorating, and that million of North Koreans might have starved to death in the last few year. The congressman, Tony Hall, D-Ohio, who ha had a longtime interest in world hunger, passed through Tokyo on his return to the United States and showed photograph he had taken of North Korean child with patchy hair, protruding bone, open sore and other sign of severe malnutrition. Hall also brought back a bag of what official called substitute food being distributed by a government food station: dried leaf and straw, so coarse that even cattle would normally turn away. They grind it into powder and make it into noodle, Hall said. The noodle have no nutrition and are indigestible, leaving people holding their aching stomach, he said. North Korea ha admitted that it is facing serious economic difficulty, but there have been sharply diverging assessment of how serious these are. Some visitor with the United Nations and other organization have said that the food situation seems to be a bit better now than a year or two ago. Hall said that the divergence might have arisen because in the North Korean capital, Pyongyang, life did seem to be slightly better than during his three previous trip to North Korea. But in rural area where foreigner are not often allowed to visit, he added, the overall situation is worse than ever. Based on visit to four hospital, Hall also emphasized that public health care had declined sharply. In one hospital, assistant were holding down a patient while surgeon conducted a stomach operation without electric light or anesthesia. Ordinary North Koreans are suffering, in part, because their government's hard-line policy have alienated would-be donor and aid agency. The United Nations ha repeatedly appealed for relief aid for North Korea, but the latest appeal ha raised le than one-third of the target. In September, Doctors Without Borders announced that it wa pulling it staff of 13 from North Korea because it feared that it aid wa going to the politically connected rather than to the most needy. North Korea doe not release mortality figure or health statistic, but Hall said that the United Nations had gathered and would soon release data indicating that 30 percent of North Korean child under age 2 are acutely malnourished and that 67 percent of all child are physically stunted. Hall said he thought that overall at least 1 million people had died and that the total wa probably closer to 3 million. In an indication of the seriousness with which professional demographer view the situation, the US. Bureau of the Census recently published estimate suggesting that North Korea's population peaked in 1995 at 21.55 million and ha since fallen to 21.23 million this year. That would be a decline of 320,000 over three year, a period when North Korea's population would have been expected to grow by about 925,000 people, based on the population growth rate of the early 1990s. Nicholas Eberstadt, an American specialist on North Korean population figure, say that there simply is not enough hard information for him to estimate the death toll from the famine. But he note one political tidbit: North Korea's constitution stipulates that there should be one delegate to the country's people's assembly for every 30,000 citizen. This year's assembly did not expand a previous one did, but rather had just 687 delegate, the same a the previous assembly held in 1990. While Eberstadt counsel caution, that could mean that North Korea's population, after eight year in which it had been expected to add several million people, is now back to 20.6 million people or fewer. The United States ha been supplying grain to North Korea, but strain are growing over a secret underground complex in the North that some expert worry may be the heart of a new nuclear weapon program. The United States warned last week that the agreed framework that is the basis for it relation with North Korea will be in jeopardy unless the North let American expert visit the underground complex and resolve their doubt. North Korea ha said that it will show off the complex only if Washington promise that if the complex is not a nuclear one, it will pay for vilifying u and impairing our prestige. Washington refuse to pay, and North Korea is warning that the standoff could lead the agreement to fall apart. Their shameless and wicked demand is an open infringement upon our sovereignty and wanton interference in our internal affair, declared North Korea's leading newspaper, Rodong Sinmun. A South Korean lawmaker said Friday communist North Korea could be producing plutonium and could have more secret underground nuclear facility than already feared. Without naming his source, Rep. Kim Deog-ryong of the Parliament's Foreign Affairs Committee said he had information that two underground facility captured on US. spy satellite photo may be nuclear plant. He said in a Parliament session that one of them is believed to already be producing plutonium and the other would be able to produce enough for 10 nuclear bomb starting around 2004. If true, the assertion paint a worse picture of suspected North Korean nuclear activity than already made public. Kim said he asked the government's Unification Ministry about the issue earlier this week and wa suspicious of it answer. It wa not sufficient or sincere, so I came to suspect that the government is trying to hide the truth, Kim said in a seven-page press release. US. and South Korean official said in August they had detected a huge underground construction site on a mountainside 40 kilometer (25 mile) northeast of Yongbyon, the country's main nuclear complex. The United States ha said it suspect the construction is nuclear-related, though it ha no evidence. North Korea ha denied it. Kim, a lawmaker from the main opposition Grand National Party, said there may actually be two underground facility not far from the Yongbyon complex. It wa activity at Yongbyon that prompted the United States to negotiate a 1994 accord promising development of two light-water reactor and fuel-oil shipment if North Korea would halt nuclear weapon development. At the time, North Korea wa believed to have made enough plutonium for one or two atomic bomb. The Yongbyon complex, which house a 500-megawatt laboratory nuclear reactor, ha been frozen under the 1994 accord. Kim said Friday that one new facility is already operating and the other is under construction and will be operational in four to six year. We estimate that the reactor will go on-line in 2002 or 2003, enabling the production of enough plutonium to build one nuclear weapon within six to 12 month, Kim said. North Korea would be able to make sufficient plutonium to make eight to 10 nuclear weapon every year after that. North Korea ha said the underground construction is for civilian use and not nuclear-related. It ha offered to open the facility to US. inspector, but say Washington must pay compensation if the facility is been proven to be for civilian use. President Clinton made an unusual, direct appeal to North Korea on Saturday to set aside any nuclear ambition in favor of strengthening tie to South Korea and the United States. The appeal came during a meeting with reporter at which he also counseled patience over Iraq's refusal to comply with a request from weapon inspector. I think it's important that we not overreact here on the first day, Clinton said in response to report that Iraq had balked at a request by UN. inspector for document on it weapon program. But, speaking at a joint appearance with South Korean President Kim Dae Jung, Clinton called the requested document quite important and said Iraq had some affirmative obligation to help weapon inspector. Aides to Clinton denied that his comment represented any softening toward Iraq. They said that because the situation wa still developing and the president wa preparing for meeting with Kim he had not been briefed in detail on Iraq's resistance when he appeared before reporter Saturday. National Security Adviser Sandy Berger said the administration wa consulting with other member of the UN. Security Council about the matter. If Iraq fails to meet it obligation under UN. resolution, he said, We obviously are prepared to act. Last weekend, Clinton called off a strike against Iraq minute before it wa to begin, delayed his departure for Asia to monitor the crisis and said that US. force remained poised to strike if Iraq reneged on it agreement to let UN. weapon inspector do their work. The Clinton administration is urgently seeking to inspect a vast construction site in North Korea that it belief may be the beginning of a nuclear weapon plant. Saturday, Clinton called that site, together with North Korea's test firing in August of a missile over Japan, cause for deep concern. But the Clinton administration is trying a very different approach toward North Korea than toward Iraq, partly at the urging of Kim, who is pursuing a sunshine policy of engagement with the North. As Clinton and Kim delivered prepared statement and answered question Saturday, Clinton became most animated in describing what he called a very beautiful picture that he happened to spot after turning on his hotel television on arriving in Seoul on Friday night: film of a cruise ship recently permitted to carry South Koreans on a tour into the North. I ask the North Koreans to think about this, he said, arguing that Kim's policy of engagement with the North presented them with a great opportunity. Nothing could ever be put in that hole in the ground that would give the North Koreans a much advantage, a much power, a much wealth, a much happiness a more of those ship going up there full of people from here. The Clinton administration fear that the construction site may be evidence that North Korea ha abandoned a 1994 pledge to the United States to give up it nuclear weapon program in exchange for billion of dollar in aid. The North Koreans have denied that the complex is intended to help build nuclear weapon. But they have demanded that the United States pay $300 million to inspect it, a request rejected this week by a US. delegation to Pyongyang, the North Korean capital. The new complex is being built on a mountainside about 25 mile northeast of Yongbyon, the former North Korean nuclear research center. Kim continued Saturday to emphasize his hope for a new opening toward North Korea. But he said, We will not tolerate any possible attempt of North Korea to proliferate nuclear weapon, missile and other weapon of mass destruction. The Clinton administration plan to resume negotiating with North Korea over inspecting the site in December. In addition to strategy for easing the Asian financial crisis, Clinton discussed North Korea during a visit to Tokyo on Thursday and Friday. The subject of North Korea consumed most of his two hour of meeting with Kim here Saturday at the Blue House, which contains the Korean president's office and home. The administration ha been criticized in Congress and in this region for letting it policy on North Korea drift, but Clinton called that policy a clear-eyed mix of diplomacy and deterrence. He said that so far the 1994 agreement had worked, because without it North Korea already would have produced a sizable amount of weapons-grade plutonium. Under pressure from congressional critic, Clinton last week appointed William Perry, his former defense secretary, to review his policy on North Korea. On other matter, Clinton declined to criticize the government of Indonesia for using force to crack down on protester there, saying that he did not have enough fact at this moment to give you the right answer. But he said he hoped there would be no backsliding in Indonesia. Clinton followed his appearance with Kim with a visit to the National Folk Museum here, where he conducted an hourlong conversation with six Korean academic, businessmen and union leader about the troubled state of Korea's economy and it impact on the society. He attended a state dinner Saturday night, before stopping by a concert where his brother, Roger, a musician, happened to be performing. Clinton repeatedly congratulated Kim for his effort at economic reform, noting that interest rate had fallen here and the currency had stabilized. But he also pressed Kim during their private meeting to restructure the five huge conglomerate, or chaebols, that account for some 40 percent of the Korean economy. In describing the leaders' conversation, Berger called restructuring the chaebols perhaps the most serious remaining problem in the South Korean economy. Clinton said during the economic forum Saturday afternoon that he felt impatient about South Korea's failure to act on the chaebols. It may be necessary to proceed slowly with the restructuring, he said, but they should begin. On Sunday, Clinton plan to visit some of the 37,000 American troop stationed here. In a green aviator jacket and black cap, President Clinton spent Sunday visiting American troop stationed in South Korea. He promoted a private, sang birthday greeting to a sergeant major and described the threat to his hope for peaceful engagement with North Korea. Lately, sign of danger have intensified, Clinton said in an address to airman here, standing before a gunmetal gray F-16 and A-10 parked nose-to-nose. So we must remain vigilant. And thanks to you, we are. For all his eagerness to talk about information-age economic danger like quicksilver currency flow, Clinton ha returned again and again during his five-day trip to Japan and South Korea to the old-style regional military threat posed by North Korea. The subject consumed most of his meeting with President Kim Dae-jung of South Korea on Saturday and formed the backdrop for his visit with the troop Sunday. It's kind of tense around here, said John Kelley, a 26-year-old airman from Wisconsin, describing life on this base. You know you're only four minute away from a missile. In his speech, Clinton pointed to recent North Korean missile test, incursion into the south and a mysterious underground site that may be a nuclear weapon installation a sign of the potential threat. And he compared North Korea to Iraq, saying that North Korea wa also a major concern because of it chemical and biological weapon. Until North Korea fully commits itself to a constructive role on this peninsula, he said, we must remain ready. Clinton restated his support for Kim's policy of engagement with North Korea, though, saying that there were some hopeful sign to justify it. He pointed to talk that began over the summer between the American military command in Korea and the North Korean military to prevent problem along the demilitarized zone between the south and north. Clinton planned to leave South Korea early Monday and return to Washington Monday night, after paying a visit to Guam. On a bright but icy afternoon, Clinton wa warmly received here by soldier in camouflage and black boot, some of whom waited almost three hour, shifting from foot to foot and rubbing their hand. The official crowd estimate wa only 3500, but the turnout seemed even smaller. The base, about 30 mile south of Seoul, is one of two major American airfield in Korea, housing 7,500 airman. Others who wanted to see the president were bused in from site that are hour away. Before flying here by helicopter, Clinton attended church on an Army base in Seoul, then visited a firing range just 12 mile from the demilitarized zone. In a brief ceremony there, he promoted Matt Prickett of West Liberty, Ohio, from private first class to specialist. And he led the troop in a round of Happy Birthday for Sgt. Maj. David Price and Julia Carson would have had little in common other than that they were Democrats with relatively safe seat. Price is a centrist who ha represented this high-tech district in North Carolina for all but 2 of the last 12 year, a political scientist who ha taught at Duke and Yale. Mrs. Carson, fairly liberal, is a House freshman who worked her way up in politics from the grass root, having been reared in poverty. But party official who opened this election year with high hope of recapturing the House are beginning to worry that Democratic incumbent like Price and Mrs. Carson share something else: greater-than-expected peril on Election Day. As in many congressional race, the biggest variable is the White House scandal, which ha injected fear and uncertainty into campaign around the country. Other Democratic incumbent who Republican official cite a locked in contest that are more competitive than expected include Reps. Corrine Brown of Florida, Vic Snyder of Arkansas, Lois Capps and Ellen Tauscher of California, Martin Frost of Texas, Melvin Watt of North Carolina, John LaFalce of New York and Sander Levin of Michigan. Here in North Carolina's 4th Congressional District, Price, acknowledging that his own poll showed him in a tight race, said: This is a swing district that is sensitive to any tide or trend. It's something you think about a lot in connection with the president's trouble. The effort of Price and Mrs. Carson to contain the Lewinsky debacle and their opponents' attempt to capitalize on it offer important clue suggesting how Clinton's problem are influencing the conduct of race around the country. Many Democrats are straddling a line that seems to shift a bit with every new scandal-related disclosure: they do not want to appear close to a president whose conduct embarrasses them, and yet, sensing the possibility of a public backlash against Republicans, they are weighing their word carefully and are wary of hopping on any impeachment bandwagon. And while publicly these Democrats express confidence that the scandal will have little impact on them, their campaign are preparing for the worst by placing greater emphasis than ever on behind-the-efforts to prod their core constituency to vote. In a reflection of the uncertainty that the Clinton scandal ha cast even among Republicans, the challenger in the Price and Carson district both are political novice seeking office for the first time have differing strategies: Tom Roberg, a computer executive in Raleigh who is taking on Price, ha broadcast a television commercial exploiting the scandal. Tom Roberg ha called for Bill Clinton's resignation, the narrator say. This is not the time to be silent, Price. Where do you stand? But in Indianapolis, Gary Hofmeister, a conservative jeweler challenging Mrs. Carson in Indiana's 10th Congressional District, is taking a more subtle approach: rather than mention the scandal directly, he note a often a he can that Julia vote with Clinton almost 100 percent of the time. Asked why he wa not much raising the scandal directly, Hofmeister said: Don't murder somebody when they're in the process of committing suicide. There would be a danger if we went overboard. The best evidence of the discomfort of both Price and Mrs. Carson is that when asked in separate interview whether they would want Clinton to campaign in their district, both said it would be impossible at this late date for the White House to schedule a visit. What if there wa a sudden schedule change? Both paused, squirmed a bit and mustered answer that were hardly affirmative. Given the president's popularity, I doubt it will hurt me, Mrs. Carson said. And Price? I don't think that would be such a good idea, he said. I've never had a president campaign here, and I wouldn't want to start this time although he is eagerly welcoming Erskine Bowles, the president's chief of staff and a popular native son in North Carolina, to stump with him here this Sunday.) Making strategy for the stump is further complicated by anecdotal evidence that run counter to Democratic fear and Republican hope. In three day of campaign stop here in North Carolina and in Indianapolis, the scandal wa rarely raised by any voter being courted by the candidate of either party. When a reporter asked about it, many voter said that a appalled a they were at Clinton's behavior, they had a hard time relating it to their decision on which way to vote in the congressional election in five week. As Hofmeister walked through the parking lot outside a gun and knife show at the Indiana National Guard Armory in Indianapolis last Sunday, Billy Derringer, a 57-year-old machinist who is retired on disability, called him over to express outrage about the million of dollar that had been spent to investigate Clinton. It's pathetic to spend all of our money, said Derringer, who identified himself a an independent. It shouldn't have gotten this far. Hofmeister tried his best to make the Republicans' case. There ha to be rule of law, he said. Mrs. Carson said she hoped that Democrats and swing voter alike would become so fed up with the Lewinsky inquiry that the issue might even help her. To that end, she proudly informs audience that she voted against making public the report delivered to the House by Kenneth Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel. I wa one of 63 member of Congress who voted against putting all that filth on the Internet, she said, adding that Starr's inquiry had been a cruel hoax in term of fiscal responsibility and accountability. The Carson campaign is counting on voter like Timothy Daly, a 38-year-old real estate executive who voted for a Republican two year ago but now favor Mrs. Carson. I'm pulling the Democratic ticket because I'm tired of it: the right side of the Republican Party is playing politics, Daly said. We'd like to see them go on with the people's business. Back here in the 4th District, Price ha some reason to be worried. He wa first elected to the House in 1986 but, a a four-term incumbent, wa ousted in the Republican sweep of 1994 (only to win his seat back two year later). In addition, the district wa redrawn last year to include a large Durham section where voter do not know him well. Determined not to be a midterm casualty of Clinton once again, Price say he is waging the most vigorous get-out-the-vote ground campaign of his career. Rather than engage Roberg over the Clinton scandal, Price ha begun broadcasting a television commercial that emphasizes his central issue: education. The congressman's adviser say they intentionally produced an advertisement that appears decidedly nonpolitical it feature school child in a play in an effort to break through the television clutter about the scandal. But the Price campaign also ha a weapon it is holding in reserve, in the event Roberg appears to be riding the Clinton scandal to advantage: the incumbent's adviser say they would not be timid about running commercial underscoring that he earned a divinity degree before getting his doctorate in political science. At a coffee with voter in a wealthy enclave of Raleigh the other night, Roberg opened his remark by asserting that Clinton had lost the moral authority to lead. Yet none of those assembled asked him about the scandal; they were more concerned about the state's plan to build a highway near their neighborhood. The last time George Voinovich ran for office, he won re-election a Ohio's governor with 72 percent of the vote, stunning even his most optimistic supporter and setting a 20th-century record for victory margin in Ohio politics. This year, Voinovich, a Republican who is barred from seeking a third term, is running again, this time for the Senate seat held by John Glenn, a Democrat who is retiring. And while there are few who expect Voinovich to repeat his electoral benchmark of four year ago, politician of both party generally acknowledge that he is well positioned to increase the Republican majority in the Senate. That ha not prevented Voinovich's Democratic opponent, Mary Boyle, from undertaking a vigorous campaign. Ms. Boyle, a former commissioner in Cuyahoga County, which encompasses Cleveland, is crisscrossing the nation's seventh-most populous state in what she describes a a grass-roots campaign that, while operating on a comparative shoestring, ha nonetheless attracted to her side nationally known Democrats President Clinton foremost among them on the campaign trail. Glenn, the former astronaut who is preparing to return to space this month at the age of 77, ha not made an endorsement in the Senate race. Like many candidate this year, Ms. Boyle, 55, is campaigning hard on the issue of education, seeking to portray Voinovich, 61, a a lackluster steward who allowed the state's school to decline. He promised to be the education governor, said Ms. Boyle. But after seven and a half year he ha failed the student of this state. Her role in the campaign, she said, is to remind the people of the state of Ohio that George Voinovich made a promise and that he didn't deliver on it. Specifically, she discus a decision last year by the Ohio Supreme Court that cited wide disparity in the quality of the state's school and ruled unconstitutional the formula for funding them. She ha also attacked her Republican opponent for supporting a proposal to raise the state's sale tax by one percent. Under that plan, half the additional fund would have been used for school improvement with the remainder earmarked for reducing property tax. That statewide ballot initiative last May proved to be wildly unpopular, with about 80 percent of the voter opposing it. While the topic of tax and education are hot one this political season in Ohio, it is not clear that Ms. Boyle's emphasis on them ha helped her campaign. Despite some narrowing in the opinion poll, she is still trailing Voinovich by 10 percentage point in some poll and a much a 18 point in others. There is also a sharp fund-raising disparity. Ms. Boyle, who is running her first statewide race and ha widespread union support, ha raised nearly $2 million so far, far le than the nearly $7 million Voinovich ha taken in. Also, Voinovich, a former lieutenant governor, ha been on statewide ballot five time over the last 20 year and thus is the better-known candidate. The electoral dynamic of Ohio are also aiding Voinovich. The northern half of the state, with it history of industrial, unionized city, ha a tradition of voting largely for Democratic candidate, while the southern tier of the state is considered more conservative and typically lean Republican. But Voinovich and Ms. Boyle share the same home terrain, depriving Ms. Boyle of the geographic advantage that often accompanies Democratic candidate. Indeed, a a boy, Voinovich once delivered newspaper to the Boyle home in the working-class Collinwood section of Cleveland. And Voinovich, a former mayor of Cleveland, ha developed a reputation a a moderate Republican who work well with Democrats. Voinovich, while campaigning vigorously himself, is keeping a full schedule of official duty, assuming the role of the experienced, elected official. If I get into the Senate, I will probably know more about domestic policy than any member of the Senate, he said in an interview on Wednesday in Canton, sandwiched between a ribbon-cutting ceremony and a fund-raising reception at a vacuum cleaner museum. As mayor, I had my nose rubbed into the problem of urban America and wa fairly successful in dealing with them. And, a governor, I have dealt with the problem of Medicaid, welfare and education. I'm the only person in the United States who ha been president of the National League of Cities and chairman of the National Governors Association. To his opponent's charge on his record on education, Voinovich is dismissive. I'm probably the only Republican in the United States who ha been endorsed by the Ohio Education Association and National Education Association, he said, adding that Ms. Boyle wa a member of the state Legislature during the period cited in the Supreme Court ruling. Mary Boyle wa vice chairman of the Ways and Means Committee and a member of the Democratic leadership during those year, Voinovich said. They did nothing to fix the building, they did nothing for technology and the urban school district. Ms. Boyle, who ha not yet begun to run campaign commercial on television, said her status a the underdog had allowed me to be more focused, more intense. Pausing after a campaign fund-raising breakfast with former Democratic Sen. Bill Bradley of New Jersey here on Wednesday, Ms. Boyle said: This ha been a marathon and it's been pretty much uphill. But now, we're down to the last three mile. It's a tough race. Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, the New York Republican who is running for re-election, went to Manhattan's Grand Central Terminal the other morning to accept an award from mass-transit advocate. But the reporter who had gathered there showed little interest in the shiny train car at the senator's back. Instead, they repeatedly asked him how he would vote on an impeachment of President Clinton. Look, I'm not going to make any comment with respect to that subject matter, D'Amato responded. I am not just a citizen. I am a citizen-senator who may be called upon to make a decision. But D'Amato is something else a well: a candidate in what may be the tightest Senate race in the nation. And variation of his elliptical response can be heard in Senate race around the country, where both Republicans and Democrats are encountering similar question. All of which suggests that after the House voted Thursday to authorize an impeachment inquiry, this year's 34 race for the US. Senate have become, beyond what they already were, the electoral equivalent of jury selection. If the House vote to impeach Clinton, the matter go to the Senate, which must decide by a two-thirds majority whether to convict him and, thus, remove him from office. As a result, the Monica Lewinsky matter ha suddenly injected a new disruptive force into the Senate contest. Voters, even those who support Clinton, expect their political leader, Republican or Democratic, to renounce Clinton's behavior, and candidate have been doing that. But impeachment is another matter; most poll show the nation is against it. The danger for Senate candidate is that with impeachment now a real possibility, the debate may move beyond the president's behavior about which there is little disagreement to the more problematic issue of whether he should be removed from office. For most of the strategist involved in the race, there is little guidance on how to handle the impeachment issue. Advisers to candidate of both party said in interview last week that they were perplexed and worried, unsure what they can or should do on the issue to gain the advantage or guard against harm. I can't tell how this one is going to go, said Mike Russell, a spokesman for the Republican Senatorial Campaign Committee. This is a very surreal environment. Of the 34 Senate seat in play, 18 are held by Democrats and 16 by Republicans, who now hold 55 seat in all. Republicans would have to win 28 of the 34 race to produce the 67 vote necessary for conviction, assuming such a vote were to go along party line. Only an electoral catastrophe for the Democrats, which seems almost unthinkable, could produce such a huge loss. Jennifer Duffy, who follows Senate race for the Cook Political Report, a nonpartisan newsletter, said that so far, at least, none of the Senate candidate ha made an explicit appeal for vote based on how they would vote on a presidential jury. But she and others are wondering if this may be about to change. This is difficult ground to measure. One of the central question of this political year ha been how Clinton's dealing with Ms. Lewinsky might affect turnout. For a long time, politician assumed that dispirited Democrats would stay home a a rebuke to Clinton, just a many Republicans did in November 1974, three month after President Richard M. Nixon resigned. But now some analyst wonder if the partisan fight in Congress last week might have the opposite effect among some Democrats. That's the problem, said Stuart Rothenberg, the editor of an independent political newsletter in Washington. It's not that we don't know, and that the politician don't know, where the general public stand on impeachment. The problem is that we don't know where the electorate stand on impeachment. And asking voter to think ahead to an impeachment proceeding a they cast their ballot in a Senate race is, in the word of Stuart Stevens, a Republican consultant, a double bank-shot. Such strategy, he said, tend to work only with a small number of single-minded or sophisticated voter. Against that complicated backdrop, the prevailing thinking is that the use of the impeachment issue will vary from race to race, state to state and week to week, depending on the circumstance of the candidate and the composition of the electorate. If Democrats try to turn the image of Clinton in the dock to their advantage, it would be in state with a Democratic edge or with sizable number of black voter, who overwhelmingly support the president. In contest like those, it might well prove to be in the interest of a Democratic candidate to, a one consultant put it, sit down in front of a camera and tape an advertisement in which the candidate denounces the president's behavior but solemnly pledge to vote against impeachment. Strategists in both party believe that kind of approach could prove effective. This is an issue where there is a huge disconnect between the elite and the public, said Fred Yang, a Democratic consultant with client in Wisconsin and the Carolinas. That kind of Democratic strategy might emerge in California, New York, Illinois, Wisconsin, Washington and perhaps Arkansas. By contrast, Democrats in South Carolina, Georgia and Nevada would be le likely to oppose Clinton's impeachment. On the other side, Republican consultant are telling their candidate to stress Clinton's misdeed and stay away from talk of impeachment. The last thing the party want is to turn the Senate election into a referendum on whether Clinton should be forced from office. The White House might think from the overall public number that maybe they would like to make this a referendum election, said Ed Goeas, a Republican pollster who is working in Senate race this year. Republicans certainly aren't going to let that happen. D'Amato responded to question about Clinton with the language that Republican consultant have been suggesting to their candidate. When and if that matter come to the Senate, I will decide on the fact that are presented to me at that time, D'Amato said. It would be very premature for me to suggest any course of action without it being referred. Because, indeed, we may be called upon to act a a jury of some kind. But Schumer, a member of the House Judiciary Committee, which is conducting the impeachment investigation, virtually embraced the issue. In a live telecast of the hearing, he said the president deserved a lesser punishment, such a censure or reprimand. And Schumer plan to campaign in New York on Monday with Clinton at his side. Schumer's medium adviser, Hank Morris, seemed to suggest last week that impeachment will grow a an issue. Senator D'Amato claim he doe not want to share his opinion with the people of New York, Morris said. And if he doesn't have an opinion, he's the only New Yorker who doesn't have an opinion. Asked if Schumer would raise the issue in a television commercial, Morris responded: We don't talk about what we're going to do. I wouldn't rule it in and I wouldn't rule it out.

data: The Yugoslav war crime tribunal Monday acquitted a Muslim military commander of war crime against Bosnian Serb prisoner in 1992, but convicted three underling in the first UN. case dealing with anti-Serb atrocity. The Yugoslav war crime tribunal cleared Zejnil Delalic, a Muslim, of responsibility for war crime committed against Serb captive at a Bosnian government-run prison camp under his command. Prosecutor Grant Niemann said he would appeal Delalic's acquittal, and asked judge to keep him in custody pending the outcome of the appeal. The UN. court convicted camp commander Zdravko Mucic, a Croat, of 11 war crime and grave breach of the Geneva Conventions because he oversaw guard who murdered nine Serbs and tortured six. Mucic smiled a he heard his sentence of seven year in prison read out. His conviction wa the first by an international court on the basis of so-called command responsibility since post-World War II tribunal convicted Nazi and Japanese superior for the crime of their subordinate. Mr. Mucic wa clearly derelict in his duty and allowed those under his authority to commit the most heinous of offense, without taking any disciplinary action, said presiding Judge Adolphus Karibi-Whyte. Hazim Delic, a Muslim who served a Mucic's deputy, wa found guilty of two murder and of raping two woman a well a torturing other inmate. He wa sentenced to 20 year. Esad Landzo, a Muslim guard, wa convicted of three murder and the torture of at least three other inmate. He wa jailed for 15 year. All four defendant had faced up to life imprisonment, the maximum punishment at the tribunal, which ha no death penalty. Monday's verdict ended a marathon 20-month trial that focused on the brutal mistreatment of the Bosnian Serbs, themselves blamed for the vast majority of the conflict's war crime. During the trial the tribunal's longest to date involving 122 witness survivor described the campaign of terror unleashed against Serbs in the area. Inmates at the Celebici prison camp were beaten to death by guard wielding baseball bat, wooden plank and rifle butt, according to testimony. Others were set on fire, raped and forced to commit sexual act with member of their own family. The 49-page indictment detailing atrocity at Celebici asserts that at least 14 prisoner were killed in 1992. One prisoner wa beaten to death and had a Muslim party badge nailed to his head, a witness claimed. Yet a few witness also praised Delalic and Mucic for humanitarian gesture, such a getting food and clothing to some prisoner and releasing others. The tribunal, set up by the Security Council in 1993, ha convicted only one other person following a trial Bosnian Serb Dusan Tadic, who wa sentenced in May 1997 to 20 year for killing and torturing Muslims in 1992. Two other men have confessed to killing Muslims, handing the tribunal two more conviction while sparing it the need for trial. He called himself the Serb Adolf, and his crime were a chilling a his nickname. In a trial opening Monday at the Yugoslav war crime tribunal, UN. prosecutor were seeking to convince a three-judge panel that Goran Jelisic is guilty of genocide, the court's most serious offense. The 30-year-old former Bosnian Serb mechanic confessed in October to murdering 12 Muslims and Croats in 1992, astonishing many observer by reversing his earlier declaration of innocence. Although his guilty plea mean an automatic conviction for war crime and crime against humanity and the likelihood of a maximum life sentence Jelisic ha denied that the killing spree constituted genocide. By pressing on with a genocide trial, prosecutor will be able to call evidence about the background of Jelisic's murder, including the involvement of more senior Serbs. The trial also will give survivor of his ruthless campaign a chance to tell their story in court. To convict Jelisic of genocide, prosecutor must prove that the murder most of them carried out with close-range shot from an automatic pistol were part of a campaign intended to wipe out an entire ethnic group in the northern Bosnian town of Brcko. Jelisic, who wa arrested in January by US. troop serving in the NATO force in Bosnia, ha pleaded guilty to a total of 31 count of war crime and crime against humanity. The charge cover the murder a well a three beating and the plundering of property. In entering those guilty plea, Jelisic told the tribunal he wanted to cleanse my soul. He will officially be convicted of those charge during the genocide trial. Jelisic's victim were killed in or near the Serb-run Luka prison camp, a former port complex on the bank of the Sava River. Although most victim were men, Jelisic also clubbed one female inmate with a police baton and then fatally shot her. UN. prosecutor say Jelisic identified himself to prisoner a the Serb Adolf, a reference to Hitler, and bragged about the number of Muslims he had killed. Set up in 1993, the UN. court ha convicted three Muslims, two Bosnian Croats and a Bosnian Serb of war crime including murder, rape and torture, but it ha yet to register a genocide conviction. An earlier genocide trial wa halted when the defendant, Bosnian Serb Milan Kovacevic, died of a ruptured artery in his tribunal cell.
