Hundreds of people gathered at Sarajevo airport on Saturday to welcome Zejnil Delalic, who wa cleared of war crime charge earlier this week after spending 980 day in jail of the international war crime tribunal in The Hague. Delalic, a Muslim, wa cleared of charge of war crime committed in 1992 against Serb prisoner in the Muslim-led Bosnian Army prison camp Celebici near his hometown of Konjic. Three others involved in the same case were convicted and will serve prison term at The Hague for crime committed a camp guard. Delalic held up his verdict a he arrived and wa first greeted by his family and then by many friend from Konjic, 50 kilometer (31 mile) south of Sarajevo, where a huge welcome party for him wa planned. This is the book of 500 page in which it say 12 time Delalic is not guilty, he told reporter. More important is that act commited by some weren't ordered by officer of our Bosnian Army. These act were qualified a act of individual that happened on a daily basis, he said. Edina Residovic, Delalic's lawyer, said she will seek compensation for wrongful imprisonment on behalf of Delalic, who spent almost three year in confinement. Yugoslavia must cooperate with the UN. war crime tribunal investigating alleged atrocity during the war in Croatia and Bosnia, international legal expert meeting in Belgrade said Sunday. The meeting wa the first international debate in Yugoslavia over the UN. tribunal's work and the government's cooperation with it. The tribunal, established by the UN. Security Council in 1993, sits in The Hague, Netherlands. Despite objection to the tribunal, Yugoslav authority allowed the two-day discussion organized by the Belgrade-based, non-governmental Humanitarian Law Center to take place without any problem. State-run medium largely ignored the event. Though there were some disagreement, participant in the discussion generally agreed that crime against humanity cannot go unpunished. The indicted who are not in The Hague are at-large because of the refusal by Croatian and Yugoslav authority to arrest and extradite them, said Mark Ellis, a lawyer and representative of the American Bar Association. Present-day Yugoslavia, consisting of Serbia and Montenegro, cooperates with the tribunal in case where Serbs were the victim in Bosnia and Croatia, the two former republic that fought war for their secession. But Yugoslavia ha questioned the tribunal's jurisdiction and refuse to indict three army officer wanted for alleged war crime in Croatia. Last week, it also refused to allow UN. investigator to probe alleged atrocity in Serbia's southern Kosovo province where ethnic Albanian separatist are fighting government force. The tribunal wa founded to satanize Serbs, said Miodrag Mitic, a former legal adviser in Yugoslavia's foreign ministry. He said the UN. court wa influenced by powerful country that dominate the international body. On Saturday, David Scheffer, the US. State Department's ambassador at-large for war crime, demanded Yugoslavia's full cooperation. Some of the closest combat in the half year of the Kosovo conflict, to the point of fighting room to room and floor to floor, occurred near this village six week ago, in the day before 21 woman, child and elderly member of the Delijaj clan were massacred by Serbian force, their mutilated body left strewn on the forest floor. Piecing together what happened, from surviving family member, ethnic Albanian separatist force and official Serbian information, a story emerges of fierce guerrilla resistance to an onslaught by Serbian tank, artillery and infantry. The Serbian force fighting here appear to have suffered unusually heavy loss and, after the guerrilla finally fled, took revenge against the civilian, shooting woman and child at close range a they tried to run away from their pursuer. According to relative who found the body, Pajazit Delijaj, 65, wa decapitated, his brain left on display on the ground. Hava Delijaj, 65, wa shot and one of her foot cut with a knife so that it hung by a thread of skin. Young woman and child who had run a few hundred yard up a rocky path were mowed down. Miraculously, a 6-week-old baby, Diturie, wa found by her father alive in the clasp of her dead mother, Lumnije, 30, more than 24 hour after the killing. Blood wa in her mouth and her mother's hand on the baby, said Imer Delijaj, the father, an avowed member of the Kosovo Liberation Army, the ethnic Albanian guerrilla force, who returned in uniform to discover the body. I moved her hand and at that moment she opened her eye. I realized she wa alive. I tried to clean the blood from her mouth and she put her tongue out. Several member of the Delijaj clan survived. Zejnije Delijaj, 39, who had cooked for the guerrilla at the family compound when they returned from fighting in the day before the massacre, recalled how she fled, crawling, falling, running and hiding in the wood a the Serbs shot at her. I could feel the dirt hitting me from the impact of the bullet, she said in an interview, her nose still bloodied from what she said wa a heavy fall during her flight. First it wa machine gun, then grenade, then cannon, she said. Every time I moved and they heard leaf rustling, they shot. The massacre of the Delijajs, whose forebear settled in the Drenica Valley about 150 year ago, wa not the first in the conflict that ravaged the Serbian province between March and October and ha now lulled into an uneasy truce. Indeed, the conflict between Serbian force bent on keeping Kosovo in Serbia and guerrilla fighting for the independence of it heavily ethnic Albanian population first drew international attention with the massacre of the Jasari clan in early March by Serbian unit at Prekaz, in central Kosovo. But the killing of the Delijajs, ranging from the paralyzed patriarch, Fazli, 94, who wa burned in his bed, to the slaughter of Valmir, 18 month, who wa found shot, is the most thoroughly documented so far. Human Rights Watch, a New York-based group, belief the knowledge gathered so far increase the possibility of prosecution by the UN. war crime tribunal in The Hague, Netherlands. The Hague's prosecutor could also draw on the observation of diplomat, human right monitor and reporter who saw the body scattered in the ravine where the victim were killed before they were buried in shallow graf in the clan's nearby compound. In other Kosovo massacre, body had been moved from the site before they were seen by independent observer. Further, family member who survived the assault have described what they saw and the circumstance in the hill and valley around Obrinje a the Serbs pushed forward early Saturday morning, Sept. 26, from their headquarters at Likovac, north of here. By then, the Albanian guerrilla had fled the area around the Delijaj compound, dispersing after what a senior commander of the Kosovo Liberation Army, Naim Maloku, termed particularly fierce combat with the Serbs. In the day before Sept. 26, he said, the guerrilla caught in a Serbian pincer movement had decided to fight rather than surrender. The fighting sometimes house to house, even room to room took an unusually heavy toll among the Serbs, said Maloku, a former officer in the Yugoslav army. He said he believed that it wa those death the Serbs avenged with the massacre of the Delijajs. In other major attack during the conflict, the guerrilla generally found an escape hatch. In Obrinje, led by another former officer of the Yugoslav army whom Maloku declined to name, the guerrilla fought, using land mine and rocket-propelled grenade. Maloku said he knew from a report made by rebel headquarters that at least 47 Serbian soldier and police officer were killed in the fighting between here and Bajince, three mile east. We took weapon from 47 Serbs, he said. The state-controlled Serbian medium center in Kosovo's capital, Pristina, said 10 Serbian police officer were killed in the fighting, including five reservist who died when their vehicle hit an antitank mine on Sept. 25. The announcement of 10 Serbs killed in one action is unusually high. The practice of taking violent revenge is a time-honored tradition in the Balkans. From 1991 to 1995, in the war in Croatia and Bosnia, Serbs, Croats and, to a far lesser extent, the main victim, the Muslims, avenged World War II massacre and new blood feud, driven into killing by leader who exploited old conflict to carve new fief for themselves a the old, Communist Yugoslavia collapsed. In this case, it appears, Serbian vengeance wa visited upon the Delijajs. Survivors of the clan said they had feared an assault on their collection of mud and brick home lining a rocky dirt track directly opposite the village of Likovac, the Serbs' base just a mile away. The Serbs had pushed the rebel out of Likovac in August and the guerrilla had established new headquarters around Bajince, six mile east of Obrinje. As the Serbs swept down from the nearby Cicavica Mountains, and up from the road that run from Pristina to Klina, it wa clear that Obrinje would be a target. Most woman and child in the area had moved into Apple Valley, where more than 10,000 refugee had gathered outdoors, seeking safety in number. But Imer Delijaj, 38, said he decided that the ravine below his family compound would be a better hiding place. He said he believed the woman, child and elderly would be spared if the Serbs found them. As the Serbs approached on foot the Saturday morning of the massacre, the last person to flee the compound itself wa Bashkim Delijaj, 21, the youngest son of 94-year-old Fazli. Bashkim Delijaj said he had stayed behind to look after his bedridden father. The shelling started again at 7 am. on Saturday and I saw a tank convoy approaching, with infantry behind the tank, Bashkim Delijaj recalled in an interview. I wa smoking a cigarette when a grenade fell on the roof and from a hole in the gate I saw soldier coming from about 30 meter away. They were in brown army uniform, had huge knife or small ax. Many had beard. Bashkim Delijaj said he wa unable to carry his father to safety, and did not have the courage to tell him what wa happening. I told him I wa getting the animal out of the barn, he said. He said he ran, hid, ran some more, and eventually received shelter from a farmer, all the time hearing shooting and shelling. When the firing had died down Monday morning, he returned to the compound and ran into Imer, still wearing his guerrilla uniform. They went to one of the house and found Imer Delijaj's brother, Adem, 33, shot dead, his body sprawled on the ground in the rain, and the burned torso of Fazli. I looked in the window of our house and saw only the bone of my father, which looked like what we learned in biology class, he said. Together, the two men went to find out what had happened in the ravine. There they found the body. First, Ali, 65, who, Imer Delijaj said, had been cut through the neck with his own tobacco cutting knife. Then Pajazit, who had been decapitated in a makeshift tent, his brain placed between two foam mattress. Then Hava, 65, who wa sprawled near the tent. They moved on to find Jeton, Imer's 10-year-old son, and Imer's mother, Hamide, 60, not far away. Imer's sister-in-law, Luljeta, who wa seven month pregnant, had been mutilated, he said. A little further up the ravine, Imer said he saw his wife, Lumnije, 30. He opened his wife's coat and found his 6-week-old baby girl, now 3 month old and recovering at a relative's home in Likovac. He said he tried to clean the baby and then put her under his jacket and walked a few foot further to find the body of his 4-year-old daughter, Menduhije, and two other young child, Donieta, 5, and Gentiana, 7. The corps of other family member were found in the wood and two older men, Habib, 51, and Hysen, 53, were found the next morning, Imer said. On Oct. 3, the body of two missing teen-age girl, Mehane, 16, and Antigua, 13, were found in the bush at the side of a road near an abandoned Serbian police compound. Later in the month, the body of Hajriz wa found pushed down a well, close to the ravine. One uncle, Sharif, who wa in the ravine, is still missing, presumed dead. Human Rights Watch, which ha been documenting the Delijaj massacre, ha described it a the most vicious of a pattern of attack on civilian by the Serbs in the Kosovo conflict. (To a lesser extent, Albanian guerrilla also attacked Serbian civilian, forcing them from their home, and allegedly carried out at least two massacres.) The evidence strongly indicates that the Gornje Obrinje killing were followed by conscious mutilation carried out after the victim were killed, a coming report by Human Rights Watch say. Delijaj family member have told Human Rights Watch monitor and others that they saw an ethnic Albanian police officer accompanying the Serbian police officer during the fighting. They believe that the police officer, who is posted at the nearby Glogovac police station, wa used by the Serbian special police officer a a guide to the Obrinje area. This police officer, who is apparently one of a small group of ethnic Albanians officer who have remained loyal to the Serbs, could be an important witness for criminal investigator from the war-crimes tribunal in The Hague, according to human right expert. The ethnic Albanian policeman could be an important witness to identifying the police and army unit responsible for the atrocity, said Peter Boueckhart, a researcher for Human Rights Watch. It is vital that those who carried out these atrocity are prosecuted by the Hague tribunal. At the burned Delijaj compound in the last week, Imer Delijaj ha been acting a the host of a wake which, following Albanian tradition, will last several week and began after family member returned from their hiding place in the wood. Color photograph of the youngest member of the family, and of Imer's mother and grandmother, have been mounted behind glass on a table outside the gate. A 30-year-old faded black and white picture of Fazli in a double-breasted suit stand apart, a sign of ultimate respect. An outsized Albanian flag with a black double-headed eagle on a red field is draped behind the table. Imer Delijaj's face seemed tense and his word were spare a he described his family's death. He did not express direct remorse for allowing his family to use a hiding place so close to the family compound, which for all practical purpose wa an informal base for fighter. His lawyer, Bajram Krasniqi, who said he wa eager to be helpful to investigator of the Hague tribunal, said in Pristina that he believed Imer Delijaj felt guilty for a faulty decision. Whether the tribunal will closely examine the case remains unclear. Slobodan Milosevic, the Yugoslav president, ha issued only a handful of visa to investigator from the tribunal. Two investigator who were in Kosovo at the time of the massacre left six day later without visiting the site or contacting Krasniqi about the killing. Would Imer Delijaj seek revenge? As he sat on the floor of his living room with a group of male visitor, he replied: It's easy to answer. If I can see eye to eye with men I will fight them. But only with men in uniform and in a fair fight. If I see child with them, I will treat them like child all over the world. Children are child. American and allied force in Bosnia on Wednesday arrested a Bosnian Serb general who wa charged with genocide by the international war crime tribunal in a recent secret indictment. Maj. Gen. Radislav Krstic, arrested without incident in the American sector in northeast Bosnia, is the highest-ranking official to be seized so far, and the first serving military officer. He is accused of directing the attack on Srebrenica in 1995, one of the most chilling and influential event of the Bosnian war, when some 7,000 Bosnian Muslim men were marched off, presumably to their death, a UN. peacekeeper stood by. The indictment of Krstic accuses him of having committed genocide during and after the fall of Srebrenica between July 11 and Nov. 1, 1995. He is indicted both in connection with direct personal involvement in the commission of these crime a well a his command responsibility. He is also accused of murder and other crime against humanity. Krstic wa a colonel in 1995, and the deputy commander of the Drina battalion, but wa promoted to general within day of the fall of Srebrenica. He is considered a close associate of the Bosnian Serb commander, Gen. Ratko Mladic, and the former Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, both of whom are wanted by the tribunal. And he is considered capable, if he is willing to testify, of implicating Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic, who ha not been indicted. Louise Arbour, chief prosecutor of the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia, called Krstic a very significant military leader and said she wa delighted with the arrest. The general wa only indicted on Oct. 30, tribunal official said, but the indictment wa kept secret so there would be a better chance of a successful arrest. NATO Secretary-General Javier Solana warned that other war crime suspect still at large should realize that they, too, will be brought to justice. James Rubin, the State Department spokesman, said that the arrest serf a a standing warning to those indicted for war crime, who remain at large, that they will be held individually accountable for their action. The Bosnian Serbs reacted angrily to the arrest, with the hardline Bosnian Serb president, Nikola Poplasen, saying that his government would now reduce contact with NATO-led peacekeeping force to the necessary minimum. Poplasen, who defeated a more moderate candidate backed by Washington in September election, said the arrest of Krstic had embittered and upset the Bosnian Serbs and would harm the implementation of the Dayton agreement that ended the 1992-1995 Bosnian war. He said he would protest the arrest, and his remark were later endorsed by parliament in a majority vote. A senior official of a NATO country called the arrest very good news and said it wa a warning to Milosevic himself and others who have not been publicly indicted that the murder committed have not been forgotten. A Pentagon official said the arrest, the most important made in the American sector, wa a sign that this is a continuing process. NATO-led peacekeeping troop have now arrested nine people wanted for war crime in the former Yugoslavia, four of whom were the subject of sealed indictment. There have been numerous call for the arrest of Mladic and Karadzic, the two most infamous men indicted, but they normally are accompanied by armed guard. NATO force have never tried to arrest them, apparently fearing casualty and an angry public reaction from Bosnian Serbs. Officials say that both Mladic and Karadzic are believed to have left the Bosnian Serb Republic to live in Serbia, which is part of Yugoslavia and controlled by Milosvevic. Krstic, who wa transferred to The Hague for trial, is the 35th suspect who ha been taken there and the 26th person currently being held there. He is the commander of the Bosnian Serb 5th Corps and wa arrested while traveling on the road to Bijelina. At the outset of the war in 1992, he wa an officer of the Yugoslav Army, and like all senior Bosnian Serb officer, wa transferred to the new Bosnian Serb force. In 1994, he lost a leg in a mine explosion. One Bosnian Serb official said in a telephone interview that, at the time, Krstic had responsibility for anti-terrorist unit who were given some of the most difficult task. Srebrenica is a dark part of our history and people don't talk about it, the official said. But everyone belief it wa the anti-terrorist unit that were sent to do the killing. In Banja Luka on Wednesday, some member of the Bosnian Serb parliament protested the arrest, saying that Krstic wa simply doing his job a a soldier. Ivo Daalder, a former Bosnia expert on the National Security Council, now with the Brookings Institution, said the arrest showed a new and promising coordination between the Tribunal and NATO troop, given the rapid arrest after the Oct. 30 indictment. He also said that the arrest of a serving officer for an important war crime would send an important message. Srebrenica wa a key town in the Bosnian conflict. It wa where the United Nations first made a stand in March 1993, when the commander of UN. troop personally led a convoy of truck to the surrounded town and promised the Bosnian Muslims there that Srebrenica would be a safe area and the United Nations would protect them. But in July 1995, the United Nations did not protect Srebrenica with air strike, and peacekeeping troop watched a the Serbs marched in, separated Muslim men and woman and marched the men off. Srebrenica signaled the massive failure of the West, said Daalder. It galvanized the United States and NATO to act. At a London conference later in July, NATO agreed to defend Gorazde and remaining safe area with massive air strike if necessary. After a mortar attack on the Sarajevo marketplace in late August, NATO air strike began, signaling the last chapter of the war and leading to the American-brokered Dayton Accords. In Sarajevo Wednesday, an aide to the Bosnian Muslim member of the collective presidency, Alija Izetbegovic, praised the arrest. We welcome this action, hoping very soon that the time will come for Karadzic and Mladic to be brought to justice, said the aide, Mirza Jajric. The arrest took place a foreign minister of the member country of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe met in Oslo, Norway, to discus the international effort to keep the peace in Kosovo, the southern Serbian province. Under a deal pressed on Milosevic in October, the organization will provide up to 2,000 civilian to monitor a cease-fire in Kosovo and to promote a political settlement there to give Kosovo enhanced autonomy. Macedonia's government Wednesday formally approved the basing of 1,700 NATO troop near it border with Kosovo. Those troop will be prepared to rush to the aid of the civilian monitor if necessary. The president of the Yugoslav war crime tribunal harshly criticized Belgrade authority anew for refusing to let UN. investigator probe alleged atrocity in Kosovo. In a letter to the United Nations Security Council released Wednesday by the tribunal, presiding judge Gabrielle Kirk McDonald of the United States said the failure of Yugoslav official to grant visa to investigator is an affront. The intentional and continuous refusal by the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia to comply with it clear and incontrovertible legal obligation to the tribunal is an affront to the Security Council and all law-abiding nation, she said. The Texas judge fired off the letter last Friday following the refusal of Belgrade authority to allow tribunal Chief Prosecutor Louise Arbour of Canada and a team of investigator to visit Kosovo. McDonald asked the Security Council to impose measure which are sufficiently compelling to bring the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia into the fold of law-abiding nation. Hundreds of people, mostly ethnic Albanians, have been killed, and a many a 300,000 driven from their home since February, when Serb force began a crackdown on ethnic Albanian separatist in Kosovo. The tribunal want to look into allegation of war crime on both side of the conflict. In it first case to deal with atrocity against Serbs during Bosnia's civil war, a UN. war crime tribunal on Monday convicted three prison official and guard, but acquitted a top military commander who oversaw the facility. The Yugoslav war crime tribunal cleared Cmndr. Zejnil Delalic, of the Bosnian Muslim Army, of responsibility for war crime committed at a government-run prison camp under his overall command. Prosecutor Grant Niemann of Australia said he would appeal Delalic's acquittal. Judges freed Delalic pending the outcome of the appeal. Let me thank you for a just and fair judgment, Delalic told the court. The judgment ha even increased my trust in this institution. Starovoitova wa shot to death Friday evening a she and an aide scaled the stair to her apartment in St. Petersburg. The 3,500-page report by the Truth and Reconciliation Commission culminates more than two year of nationwide hearing. But it also blamed the ANC for gross human right violation during it anti-apartheid struggle, saying the group tortured suspected spy and dissident and killed innocent civilian with land mine and bomb. Mbeki who became ANC president last year and will likely be elected South Africa's next president in 1999 when Mandela retires took a hard line Saturday against the report, and indicated all ANC member must do the same. No member, 5th graf, 1st Ld-Writethru Following are excerpt from the final report issued by South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission on Thursday: PRIMARY FINDING On the basis of the evidence available to it, the primary finding of the Commission is that: The predominant portion of gross violation of human right wa committed by the former state through it security and law-enforcement agency. Moreover, the South African state in the period from the late 1970's to early 1990's became involved in activity of a criminal nature when, amongst other thing, it knowingly planned, undertook, condoned and covered up the commission of unlawful act, including the extrajudicial killing of political opponent and others, inside and outside South Africa. In pursuit of these unlawful activity, the state acted in collusion with certain other political grouping, most notably the Inkatha Freedom Party (IFP). . . . Certain member of the State Security Council (the state President, Minister of Defense, Minister of Law and Order, and head of security force) did foresee that the use of word such a take out, wipe out, eradicate, and eliminate would result in the killing of political opponent. They are therefore responsible for deliberate planning which caused gross violation of human right. PW. BOTHA During the period that he presided a head of state (1978-1989) according to submission made to and finding made by the Commission, gross violation of human right and other unlawful act were perpetrated on a wide scale by member of the South African Defense Force, including: The deliberate unlawful killing and attempted killing of person opposed to the policy of the Government, within and outside South Africa. The widespread use of torture and other form of severe ill treatment against such person. The forcible abduction of such person where were resident in neighboring country. Covert logistical and financial assistance to organization opposed to the ideology of the ANC. and other liberation movement. . . . INKATHA The Commission find that in 1986, the South African Defense Forces (S.A.D.F.) conspired with Inkatha to provide the latter with a covert, offensive paramilitary unit (or hit squad) to be deployed illegally against person and organization perceived to be opposed to both the South African Government and Inkatha. The SADF. provided training, financial and logistical management and behind the scene supervision of the trainee, who were trained by the Special Forces unit of the SADF. in the Caprivi Strip. The Commission find furthermore that the deployment of the paramilitary unit in KwaZulu led to gross violation of human right, including killing, attempted killing and severe ill treatment. The Commission find the following people, among others, accountable for such violations: Mr. P. W. Botha, Gen. Magnus Malan, Chief Mangosuthu Buthelezi. . . . The ANC. While it wa ANC. policy that the loss of civilian life should be avoided, there were instance where member of it security force perpetrated gross violation of human right in that the distinction between military and civilian target wa blurred in certain armed action, such a the 1983 Church Street bombing of the South African Air Force headquarters. . . . In the course of the armed struggle, the A.N.C., through it security force, undertook military operation which, though intended for military or security force target, sometimes went awry for a variety of reason, including poor intelligence and reconnaissance. The consequence in these case, such a the Magoo's Bar and Durban Esplanade bombing, were gross violation of human right in respect of the injury to and loss of life of civilian. Individuals who defected to the state and became informer and/or member who became state witness in political trial . . . were often labeled by the ANC. a collaborator and regarded a legitimate target to be killed. The commission doe not condone the legitimization of such individual a military target and find that the extrajudicial killing of such individual constituted gross violation of human right. The commission find that, in the 1980's in particular, a number of gross violation were perpetrated not by direct member of the ANC. or those operating under it formal command, but by civilian who saw themselves a ANC. supporter. In this regard, the Commission find that the ANC. is morally and politically accountable for creating a climate in which such supporter believed their action to be legitimate and carried out within the broad parameter of a people's war a enunciated by the ANC. ANC. CAMPS The Commission find that suspected agent were routinely subjected to torture and other form of severe ill treatment and that there were case of such individual being charged and convicted by tribunal without proper regard to due process, sentenced to death and executed. WINNIE MADIKIZELA-MANDELA The Commission find that Ms. Madikizela-Mandela wa central to the establishment and formation of the Mandela United Football Club, which later developed into a private vigilante unit. It is the Commission's view that Ms. Madikizela-Mandela wa aware of the criminal activity and the disquiet it caused in the community, but chose deliberately not to address the problem emanating from the football club. The Commission find that those who opposed Ms. Madikizela-Mandela and the Mandela United Football Club, or dissented from them, were branded a informer and killed. The Commission find that Ms. Madikizela-Mandela . . . is accountable, politically and morally for the gross violation of human right committed by the Mandela United Football Club. The Commission find further that Mrs. Madikizela-Mandela herself wa responsible for committing such gross violation of human right. . . . BUSINESS Business wa central to the economy that sustained the South African state during the apartheid year. Certain business, especially the mining industry, were involved in helping design and implement apartheid policy. The white agriculture industry benefited from it privileged access to land.
r1: South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission, appointed to reconcile the sides involved in the crimes of the apartheid era, is releasing its final 2.5- year report.Its purpose is to identify those who committed gross violations of human rights.The report is to lay most of the blame for the violations on the State, but the ANC also shares blame.The program offers amnesty to the accused if they confess but execution if they refuse.The process has angered many people of all walks of life.De Klerk, Apartheid's last president, is not being implicated but he is suing to stop publication.Criminal cases are nonetheless expected to go on for six years.
r2: South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission headed by Desmond Tutu proposes amnesty to heal the wounds of the apartheid era.If those accused of atrocities confess, they will be given amnesty, if not, they will be prosecuted.The Commission's report said most human rights violations were by the former state through security and law enforcement agencies.The African National Congress, Inkatha Freedom Party, and Winnie Mandela's United Football Club also shared guilt.Former president de Klerk, who shared the Nobel Peace Prize with Nelson Mandela, was not named as an accessory after the fact, since his threatened lawsuit would delay the report.
r3: South Africa Truth and Reconciliation Commission's 3,500-page report on apartheid-era atrocities was issued on Oct 30.This report was intended to clear the air, grant amnesty to those who confessed, and begin the healing process.Those named for prosecution were warned before the release.Ex-prime minister de Klerk's name was removed.The ruling African National Congress remained.While the white government bore the brunt of the blame, several black movements were included.After the release many talked of a new amnesty period or a limited time to prosecute.Prosecutions could take 6 years; diverting judges, threatening elections, and slowing recovery.
r4: The Truth and Reconciliation Commission, which was established to look into the human rights violations committed during the long struggle against white rule, released its final report.In what has been described as one of the most complete reports of its kind, the commission blames most of the atrocities on the former South African government.The ANC also came under fire for committing some atrocities during the struggle.Nelson Mandella's ex-wife, Winnie could be prosecuted for the part she played in such violations.Missing from the report was De Klerk, who threatened to sue if he was mentioned in connection with the atrocities.

data: As a gay college student lay hospitalized in critical condition after a severe beating here, this small city, which bill itself a Wyoming's hometown, wrestled with it attitude towards gay men. On Saturday, at the University of Wyoming's annual homecoming parade, Pistol Pete and his uniformed brass band were overshadowed by a larger group of marcher 450 people, many wearing yellow armband and carrying sign in support of the 21-year-old student, Matthew Shepard, who suffered severe head injury in the attack last week. Hate is not a Small Town Value No to Violence and Evil, read one sign, a watcher applauded. With passersby spontaneously joining the protest group, two woman held another sign that read, No Hate Crimes in Wyoming. Two candlelight vigil were held Sunday night at church near the campus. At the Poudre Valley Hospital in Fort Collins, Colo., where Shepard's health continued to deteriorate, the hospital ha received so many flower that nurse have started to distribute bouquet to other patient. A vigil at the hospital on Saturday evening drew about 500 people. We live in the Equality State, Shannon Rexroat wrote Friday in a special edition of the Branding Iron, the campus newspaper. Referring to Wyoming's pioneer heritage a the first state to grant woman the right to vote, Ms. Rexroat, the campus newspaper's editor added: That mean nothing to me anymore. We live in a state where a young man wa brutally beaten because he is gay. But others recalled another side of Wyoming's hometown,which ha a population of more than 26,000. Jamie Lewis, another editor, said that on Friday he wa handing out copy of the special edition when a passerby backed away from him and used an anti-gay epithet. Last week's brutal assault bubbled out of an ongoing climate of hostility toward gay men and lesbian, leader of the local Unitarian church said in a letter published Sunday in the city's newspaper, The Laramie Daily Boomerang. This incident wa atypical in it brutality, but not in it underlying motive, wrote Jeffrey Lockwood and Stephen Johnson. Gay people in Laramie, they wrote, are frequently assaulted with derision, intolerance, insult and hostility if not gun and rope. Ric Turley, who dropped out of college here after one year in the 1970s, recalled driving here to see his family for Christmas in 1993 and seeing a vandalized billboard on the main highway. Under a brace of pistol, an advertising appeal for a state history museum had been changed, he said, from Shoot a Day or Two, to Shoot a Gay or Two. Turley, who is gay and said he only came out after he had left Wyoming, said that he immediately complained to the museum. But returning a month later, he found the message had not been erased. After complaining to the museum for a second time, he said he took a can of black spray paint and blotted out the word gay. It wa this kind of complacency and apathy that allowed this to happen, he said of the beating in which two local men have been charged, Russell Henderson and Aaron McKinney. According to the local police and prosecutor, the two men lured Shepard out of a bar by saying they were gay. Then, the Laramie police say, the pair kidnapped Shepard, pistol-whipped him with a .357 Magnum and left him tied to a ranch fence for 18 hour until a passing bicyclist spotted Shepard, who wa unconscious. On Sunday, the Laramie police said that McKinney had been arrested on Thursday at the same hospital in Fort Collins where Shepard wa being treated. McKinney wa being treated for a minor skull fracture unrelated to the fracas with Shepard, said Ben Fritzen, a Laramie police detective. President Clinton ha condemned the attack, saying on Saturday, I wa deeply grieved by the act of violence perpetrated against Matthew Shepard. Clinton urged Congress to pas the federal Hate Crimes Prevention Act, saying, There is nothing more important to the future of this country than our standing together against intolerance, prejudice and violent bigotry. Wyoming is one of 10 state that doe not have a hate crime law. The latest attempt died in the state Legislature in Cheyenne in February. On Saturday, Wyoming's governor, Jim Geringer, said he wa outraged and sickened by the attack. Here in Laramie, McKinney's father, Bill, also condemned the attack. His pickup truck wa apparently used in the kidnapping. But he also complained about the massive attention by the national medium. The national press blew it totally out of proportion because it involved a homosexual, McKinney told The Denver Post. `Had this been a heterosexual these two boy decided to take out and rob, this never would have made the national news. Shepard grew up in Casper until his sophomore year in high school, when his father, an oil rig safety engineer, wa transferred to Saudi Arabia. The young man completed high school at a boarding school in Lugano, Switzerland, where he learned Italian and German. On Saturday, his parent, Dennis and Judy Shepard, released a statement from Fort Collins thanking the American public for their kind thought about Matthew. He is a trusting person who take everybody at face value and he doe not see the bad side of anyone, the Shepards wrote. He ha always strongly felt that all people are the same, regardless of their sexual preference, race or religion. Noting that their son wa born prematurely and that his life ha often been a struggle, they added, He is physically short in stature, but we believe he is a giant when it come to respecting the worth of others. Last Saturday morning, while Matthew Shepard lay comatose from a beating, a college homecoming parade passed a few block from his hospital bed in Fort Collins. Propped on a fraternity float wa a straw-haired scarecrow, labeled in black spray paint: I'm Gay. Few people missed the message. Three day earlier, Shepard, a gay University of Wyoming freshman, wa savagely beaten and tied to a ranch fence in such a position that a passerby first mistook him for a scarecrow. Tuesday, official at Colorado State University reacted with outrage to the fraternity float, opening an investigation and disciplinary procedure against the fraternity, Pi Kappa Alpha. The fraternity chapter immediately suspended seven member and said they had acted independently. But in a week when candlelight vigil for Shepard were being held on campus across the nation, the scarecrow incident highlighted how hostility toward gay people often flourish in high school and university, gay leader said Tuesday. People would like to think that what happened to Matthew wa an exception to the rule but, it wa an extreme version of what happens in our school on a daily basis, said Kevin Jennings, executive director of the Gay, Lesbian and Straight Education Network, a New York group dedicated to ending anti-gay bias in the school. Shepard, a slightly built 21-year-old, died on Monday morning from the injury suffered in the beating. He never regained consciousness after being discovered on the evening of Oct. 7, 18 hour after he wa lashed to the fence. Two men, Russell Henderson, 21, and Aaron McKinney, 22, were arraigned late Monday night on first-degree murder charge. Their girlfriend, Chasity Pasley, 20, and Kristen Price, 18, have been arraigned a accessory after the fact. In response to the killing, about 50 candelight vigil were scheduled this week, from Texas to Vermont, from Wayne, Neb., to New York City. At the Poudre Valley Hospital in Fort Collins where Shepard wa in intensive care for five day, his parent, Dennis and Judy Shepard, received about 6,000 electronic message of condolence. Tuesday, when funeral arrangement were announced for Friday in Casper, Wyo., the hospital Web site received 30,000 hit an hour. Friends at the University of Wyoming in Laramie, Wyo., have set up The Matthew Shepard Memorial Fund to raise money to pressure the state legislature to pas anti-hate crime legislation. I see his name going down in gay history a a catalyst for renewed activism, said Matt Foreman, a former Wyomingite who directs Empire State Pride Agenda, a gay political organization in New York. From around the nation Tuesday, gay leader stressed that campus homophobia is not restricted to college town in the Rocky Mountain West. Last year, in a survey of almost 4,000 Massachusetts high school student, 22 percent of gay respondent said they skipped school in the past month because they felt unsafe at school, and 31 percent said they had been threatened or injured at school in the past year. These percentage were about five time greater than the percentage of heterosexual respondent. The survey wa conducted at 58 high school by the Massachusetts Department of Education. In a separate study of nearly 500 community college student in the San Francisco area, 32 percent of male respondent said they had verbally threatened gay people and 18 percent said they had physically threatened or assaulted gay people. The study wa conducted this year by Karen Franklin, a forensic psychologist who is a researcher at the University of Washington. Surveys of gay college student conducted in the late 1980s at Yale University, Oberlin College, Rutgers University and Penn State found that 16 percent to 26 percent had been threatened with violence, and that 40 percent to 76 percent had been verbally harassed, said the National Gay and Lesbian Task Force, a lobbying group based in Washington. Last year, a student group in Des Moines, Iowa, called Concerned Students, recorded hallway and classroom conversation at five high school on 10 homophobia recording day. They estimated that the average Des Moines high school student hears about 25 anti-gay remark every day. Nine out of 10 `teaching tolerance' course weed out gay, Foreman said. There are a lot of people preaching anti-racism and anti-semitism. But it is still very much OK to make anti-gay joke, to express anti-gay sentiment. In a survey of the nation's 42 largest school district, 76 percent do not train teacher on issue facing gay student, and 42 percent do not have policy to protect student from discrimination based on sexual orientation, said the Gay, Lesbian and Straight Education Network, which conducted the survey last month. In Fort Collins, while hospital official struggled with an electronic avalanche of condolence, city police detective were investigating a different kind of e-mail. On Monday, hour after Shepard's death, two gay organization, the Rainbow Chorus and the Lambda Community Center, received identical message applauding Shepard's murder. The message closed with the words: I hope it happens more often. Matthew Shepard, the gay college student who wa kidnapped and severely beaten, died here Monday, five day after he wa found unconscious on a Wyoming ranch where he had been left tied to a fence for 18 hour in near-freezing temperature. His death, announced at Poudre Valley Hospital here, fanned the outrage that followed word of last week's attack, spawning nationwide vigil, producing a call for federal hate-crimes legislation from President Clinton and fueling debate over such law in a host of Western state, including Wyoming, that have resisted them. From Denver to the University of Maryland, people turned out to honor the The slight, soft-spoken 21-year-old Shepard, a freshman at the University of Wyoming, who became an overnight symbol of anti-gay violence after he wa found dangling from the fence by a passerby. Two men and two woman have been charged in the case. The men were charged with attempted murder and are expected to face first-degree murder charge that could bring the death penalty. There is incredible symbolism about being tied to a fence, said Rebecca Isaacs, political director of the National Gay and Lesbian Task Force in Washington. People have likened it to a scarecrow. But it sounded more like a crucifixion. Gay leader hope and Christian conservative fear that Shepard's death will galvanize Congress and state legislature to pas hate-crime legislation or broaden existing law. Conservatives generally oppose such law because they favor one group's right over another. In the last two decade, 21 state and the District of Columbia have passed law that increase penalty for crime that are committed because of a person's race, religion, color, national origin, and sexual orientation. Another 19 state, including Colorado, do not include sexual orientation in their hate-crime law. Ten state, including Wyoming, have no hate-crime law at all. In Washington, Clinton responded to news of Shepard's death by urging Congress to pas the federal Hate Crimes Protection Act, which would make federal offense of crime based on sex, disability and sexual orientation. Wyoming ha been one of the nation's holdout, rejecting three hate crime bill since 1994, most recently in February. But Monday, after Shepard's death, Gov. Jim Geringer appealed to lawmaker to reconsider their opposition. I ask for a collective suggestion for anti-bias, anti-hate legislation that can be presented to the Wyoming Legislature for their consideration in January, Geringer said. The governor met Monday morning with Dennis Shepard, the slain student's father, and said that the elder Shepard did not want his son's death to become a medium circus and that we should not use Matt to further an agenda. Geringer said that Shepard's father also said: Don't rush into just passing all kind of new hate-crimes law. Be very careful of any change and be sure you're not taking away right of others in the process to race to this. Leaders of gay right group interviewed Monday said they would respect the family's privacy by not attending the burial in Casper, Wyo., on Saturday. But they added that they hoped the death would have an impact on legislator around the nation. Matthew's death, I hope, will bring about a better and deeper understanding of hate crime law, said Elizabeth Birch, executive director of the Human Rights Campaign, a lesbian and gay right group that ha 250,000 member. Matthew's death may lead to an awakening in Wyoming and in the United States Congress a the need for this legislation. In 1996, 21 men and woman were killed in the United States because of their sexual orientation, according to the Southern Poverty Law Center, an Alabama group that track violence against minority. According to the FBI, sexual orientation wa a factor in 11.6 percent of the 8,759 hate crime recorded in 1996. But Christian conservative warn that gay leader want to use Shepard's death to expand hate right law and to curtail freedom of speech. Hate crime law have nothing to do with perpetrator of violent crime and everything to do with silencing political opposition, said Steven Schwalm, an analyst with the Family Research Council, a Washington group dedicated to defending faith, family and freedom. It would criminalize pro-family belief, Schwalm said. This basically sends a message that you can't disagree with the political message of homosexual activist. Agreement came from John Paulk, who wa featured this summer in a series of advertisement about how he and his wife, Anne, overcame homosexuality through religious conversion. We have every right to speak out against an agenda that is contrary to Biblical norm, said Paulk, who describes himself a a homosexuality specialist for Focus on the Family, a Christian group in Colorado Springs, Colo. Because we are standing up and opposing the homosexual agenda, we are being looked upon a advocating violence against homosexual, when we categorically reject violence against homosexual. Last Thursday, the Family Research Council unveiled a series of television advertisement that preach the healing of homosexuality through religious conversion. Gay leader charge that these advertisement help create a hostile climate for homosexual, a climate that can lead to violence. Hate crime law that are on the book in 40 state have not impinged on freedom of speech, said Brian Levin, a criminal justice professor who directs the Center on Hate and Extremism at Stockton College, in Pomona, NJ. Instead, he said, hate crime law send a clear message that society doe not tolerate attack on minority. We want to deter the broken window and simple assault before they escalate, he said. Referring to murder of homosexual, he added: These crime are preventable. Offenders get emboldened if they are not punished the first time. Levin said that his research indicated that homosexual suffered higher rate of violent crime than the population at large. He also said that roughly half of the people who attack homosexual are male, aged 22 or younger. The two men charged in the killing of Shephard are both white, Russell Henderson, 21, and Aaron McKinney, 22. With other crime, violence is a mean to an end. With hate crime, the violence becomes an unstoppable goal, Levin said. Shepard suffered a dozen cut around the head, face and neck, a well a a massive blow to the back of his skull. Because their social stature in society, gay are often viewed a appropriate target, Levin added. Citing the need for hate crime law to send a clear message to gay bashers, Levin said: The discourse in society leaf many of these people to believe that what they are doing is socially acceptable. While some gay leader saw crucifixion imagery in Shepard's death, others saw a different symbolism: the Old West practice of nailing a dead coyote to a ranch fence a a warning to future intruder. This University of Wyoming student wa beaten and left to die, tied to a fence like an animal because he wa honest and open about being gay, Beatrice Dorhn, legal director of the Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund, said Monday, Matthew Shepard's horrible suffering and death cannot be dismissed simply a the fault of deranged, isolated individual. His attacker are among million of Americans who constantly hear the message that gay people are not worthy of the most basic equal treatment, Ms. Dorhn said. On the same day Americans learned last week that Matthew Shepard, a 5-foot-2, 105-pound gay college student, had been tortured, strung up like an animal and left to die on a fence outside Laramie, Wyo., the Family Research Council wa co-hosting a press conference in Washington. It wa the latest salvo in a six-month campaign by the religious right, with the tacit, even explicit, approval of Republican leader, to demonize gay people for political gain in this election year. This particular press conference wa to announce a new barrage of ad a TV follow-up to a summer print campaign in which alleged former homosexual who have changed implore others to do likewise through the power of Jesus Christ. The commercial, gooey in style, end with a slogan: It's not about hate . It's about hope. But it's really about stirring up the fear that produce hate. If these ad were truly aimed at gay people, they wouldn't be broadcast at extravagant cost to the wide general audience reached by TV, and they wouldn't be trumpeted in Washington, insuring free national exposure, three week before Election Day. The ad themselves, despite the sugar-coating of hope, ooze malice. In one of them, homosexuality is linked to drug addiction and certain death by AIDS; all of them implicitly posit that homosexuality is itself a disease in need of a cure. Matthew Shepard ha now been cured, that's for sure. As his uncle, RW. Eaton, told The Denver Post, the 21-year-old Matt, who aspired to a career in diplomacy and human right, wa a small person with a big heart, mind and soul that someone tried to beat out of him. Of his nephew's shattered body Eaton said, It's like something you might see in war. And a war it is. Go to the Family Research Council's Web site and you will find a proud description of it readiness to wage the war against the homosexual agenda and fight to maintain the traditional meaning of `family.' The head of the Family Research Council is Gary Bauer, a GOP power broker and putative presidential candidate, who disingenuously go on talk show to say that his organization hate no one and deplores violence. But if you wage a well-financed medium air war in which people with an innate difference in sexual orientation are ceaselessly branded a sinful and diseased and un-American seeker of special right, ground war will follow. It's a story a old a history. Once any group is successfully scapegoated a a subhuman threat to normal value by a propaganda machine, emboldened thug take over. Two week after James Byrd wa savagely dragged to his death from a pickup truck in Texas in June, I wrote a column about an ugly incident outside the GOP state convention in Fort Worth, where a mob threatened a group of gay Log Cabin Republicans who were protesting discriminatory treatment by their own party. The gay-bashers had been directly preceded by steady saber-rattling from Republican politicians: Sen. James Inhofe of Oklahoma had likened James Hormel, a gay nominee to an ambassadorship, to David Duke; Pat Robertson had wondered on TV if God might wreak havoc on Disney World for it Gay Days; the Texas GOP spokesman had likened Log Cabin to the Ku Klux Klan. Just two day after this near-brush with violence in Fort Worth, Trent Lott wa on TV seconding the religious right's condemnation of gay people a sinful and sick. A frightened gay Texas Republican who had been at the convention melee asked when I interviewed him then: Do you have to have someone hurt and beat up and dragged from a truck to stop this? Months later not even the murder in Laramie ha moved Lott to apologize for his word, and still no major GOP leader dare take on it religious wing and it crusade against people like Matthew Shepard. In one of the new ad in that supposedly hate-free crusade, an ostensibly loving mother condemns her son for the bad choice of being gay. Is it that mother who speaks for American value, or is it Matthew's? Go home, give your kid a hug, Judy Shepard said in a message read by a tearful hospital spokesman who announced her child's death early Monday morning, and don't let a day go by without telling them you love them. At first, the passing bicyclist thought the crumpled form lashed to a ranch fence wa a scarecrow. But when he stopped, he found the burned, battered and nearly lifeless body of Matthew Shepard, an openly gay college student who had been tied to the fence 18 hour earlier. On Friday, the 22-year-old University of Wyoming student wa in a coma in critical condition. At Albany County courthouse here, Russell Henderson, 21, and Aaron McKinney, 22, were arraigned on charge of kidnapping, aggravated robbery and attempted first-degree murder. Two woman described a friend of the men, Kristen Leann Price, 18, and Chastity Vera Pasley, 20, have been charged a accessory after the fact to attempted first-degree murder. Shepard's friend said that he did not know his alleged tormentor. Laramie police say the primary motive wa robbery, although court paper filed Friday indicate Shepard's homosexuality may also have been a factor. Shepard's friend call the attack a hate crime. He wa very open about his sexuality, Tina LaBrie, an anthropology student here, said of her friend. I admired him for that because it is very courageous to be yourself even when others disagree. A few hour before he wa beaten, Shepard, a slight 5-foot, 2-inch man who wore brace on his teeth, had attended a meeting of the Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgendered Association, said Walter Boulden, a friend of Shepard's. He wa sitting at the bar, having a beer, when two men came up and talked to him, Boulden, a 46-year-old university lecturer of social work here, said today between tear. He indicated he wa gay, and they said they were gay, too. Now, he is in a coma, continued Boulden, who visited his friend at a hospital in Fort Collins, Colo., on Thursday. I don't think anybody expects him to pull through. Shepard, who spoke Arabic and German, studied at a boarding school in Switzerland before moving back to the United States to attend the University of Wyoming, the alma mater of his father, an oil rig safety inspector in Saudi Arabia. Matthew Shepard wa born in Casper, the capital of Wyoming's oil belt, and spent much of his youth there. But six week after returning to Wyoming and enrolling a a freshman here, Shepard fell into a depression, said Ms. Labrie and her husband, Phillip. Accustomed to life in Europe and Denver, this foreign language student who wanted to become a diplomat found himself living in this isolated city of 27,000 people. Set in a treeless landscape defined by barbed wire fence, grazing cattle and a busy freight railroad line, Laramie is a town where pickup truck outnumber sport utility vehicle, where fall entertainment revolves around this Saturday's homecoming football game and the start of the hunting season in the nearby Medicine Bow mountain. Although Wyoming often bill itself a the equality state, in reference to it being the first state to give woman the vote, the state legislature ha repeatedly voted down hate crime legislation on the ground that it would give homosexual special right. Wyoming is not really gay friendly, Marv Johnson, executive director of the Wyoming chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union, said from Cheyenne. The best way to characterize that is by a comment a legislator made a few year back, when he likened homosexual to gay bull a worthless and should be sent to the packing plant. Shepard joined the campus gay association at the university within day. One of his favorite haunt wa the Fireside Bar, which drew a mixed crowd of college student and rodeo cowboy, gay and straight. He definitely wasn't drunk when he came in, recalled the bartender, Matt Galloway. He wasn't drunk when he went out. Calvin Rerucha, the county attorney, charged in court document today that McKinney and Henderson posed a homosexual and lured Shepard out to McKinney's pickup truck. Beating him inside the truck, the pair drove him one mile southeast to an isolated part of a new rural subdivision, the County Attorney's report charged. There, it said, the men tied their captive to a post-and-rail fence and pistol-whipped him with a .357 magnum while he begged for his life. Relatives said that Shepard also suffered burn on his body. After nearly beating the young man to death, Laramie Police Commander David O'Malley said, the assailant stole his wallet and shoe and left him tied to the fence. The police commander said that when his officer arrested the two men on Thursday, they found in McKinney's pickup truck a .357 magnum pistol covered with blood and Shepard's shoe and credit card. He said they found Shepard's wallet at McKinney's home. The police commander said that the two woman helped the two men dump their bloody clothing, and that they reported hearing the men make anti-gay remark. Ms. Pasley, a freshman art student at the university, lived with Henderson. Ms. Price lived with McKinney. The police did not say what the other three did for a living. On Friday, friend and Laramie resident struggled to understand the incident. Shepard, some said, may have felt a false sense of confidence because the local Gay Association completed plan on Tuesday night for Gay Awareness Week 1998. A week after the Turkish government fell in a corruption scandal, President Suleyman Demirel on Wednesday asked a veteran left-wing politician known for his personal honesty, Bulent Ecevit, to form a new government. Ecevit, who served a prime minister three time in the 1970s, said he would immediately begin working to fashion a government that could command a majority in the faction-ridden Parliament. He also suggested that although Parliament ha set April 18 a the date for a new election, he might seek to remain in power for a longer period. It is wrong to see this government a simply an election government, he said. There are problem that will not wait until an election. Military commander, who hold ultimate power in Turkey, have quietly told senior political figure, including Demirel, that they do not want a quick election. They fear it will produce a Parliament just a divided a the present one, perhaps with the Islamic-oriented Virtue Party a the largest bloc. The commander are also hoping to exclude two of the country's leading politician, outgoing Prime Minister Mesut Yilmaz and former Prime Minister Tansu Ciller, neither of whom they trust, from post in the new government. Ecevit must now try to build a government that includes their center-right party but not them a individual. In a meeting this week the country's senior policy-making body, the National Security Council, in which military officer have a strong say, set three priority for the coming month. Among Ecevit's immediate challenge will be to resolve a political crisis with Italy that broke out last month when the Kurdish rebel leader Abdullah Ocalan wa arrested in Rome and then asked for political asylum there. Turkey want Ocalan sent here for trial, but Italy say it cannot extradite him a long a Turkey retains the death penalty. Ecevit (pronounced EH-che-vit) is among the few senior Turkish politician who favor the abolition of capital punishment. Together with Demirel, Ecevit is often cited by Turks who complain about the continued dominance of a geriatric political elite here. He is 73 and ha been in politics for most of his adult life. Early in his career Ecevit emerged a a spokesman for Turkey's downtrodden mass. Perhaps more than any other figure, he legitimized social democratic ideology in a climate where leftist sympathy were often considered subversive. At the same time, however, he ha shown himself to be a fierce nationalist. He wa prime minister when Turkey sent troop to occupy northern Cyprus in 1974 and is still considered a hard-liner on Cyprus. He is also uncompromising in his opposition to Kurdish nationalism. During his term a prime minister in the 1970s, Ecevit successfully undermined effort to move Turkey toward membership in the European Union, then called the European Economic Community. He considered it an instrument of capitalist exploitation. Ecevit ha also disturbed the United States by flirting with anti-Western ideology. On many issue that Turkish society is encountering now, he represents an orientation which doe not seem to be totally in tune with the time, Turan said. He ha failed to grasp where the world is heading. He look at and analyzes the world in category that are no longer useful or appropriate. He speaks fluent English, and his reading taste run to poetry and intellectual journal such a The New York Review of Books. He ha translated the work of TS. Eliot into Turkish and published several volume of his own poem. President Suleyman Demirel appeared likely to turn to some widely trusted lawmaker to form Turkey's next government, after a veteran politician abandoned effort Monday to persuade bickering political leader to support him in a pro-secular coalition. Denise O'Donnell, the US. attorney for the western district of New York, said Kopp wa not considered a suspect at this time but wa believed to have information material to the case. She is one of thousand of people across the country loosely associated with anti-abortion group like the Lambs of Christ who have opened their home to the Lambs' founder, the Rev. Norman Weslin, and other itinerant demonstrator. While many including Mrs. Hayes disavow violent tactic, supporter of abortion right say that people like her bear some responsibility when the protester they help blockade clinic or threaten doctor. These people who provide Father Weslin with food and shelter when he come into town to close the clinic are not innocent, said Ann Glazier, the director of clinic defense for the Planned Parenthood Federation. It's just not credible to say they aren't part of the extremist activity that is taking place at these clinic. They are still guilty of interfering with women's access. But Mary Quinn, a local organizer for the Lambs of Christ who also offer her home to protester, see matter in a differing light. Taking people in like this is an act of Christian charity, Mrs. Quinn said. `People who travel around the country doing this work are taken in by those of u that who don't want to lose their stupid house. We take in these people because they are willing to make the sacrifice. Members of the Lambs of Christ have been persistent figure in protest at the Buffalo women's clinic where Dr. Barnett Slepian worked before he wa shot to death last month. Although no suspect ha been identified in the shooting or in several similar attack in New York and Canada over the past several year, official are looking to question a Vermont man whose car wa seen near Dr. Slepian's home. While Mrs. Hayes say she would never so much a obstruct a clinic's door, some of those to whom she ha given refuge have no qualm about doing so. Weslin, the leader of the Lambs of Christ, is one of those who ha benefited from Mrs. Hayes' hospitality, a modern version of the generosity that Christ and the Apostles knew well. He pride himself on being arrested more than 60 time during protest in front of medical clinic. And throughout the 1980s and early '90s, he wa active in clinic rescue, in which protester tried physically to restrain patient trying to enter clinic. Weslin stayed at Mrs. Hayes' home only once, beginning in May 1996 when he first came to speak at local church about the anti-abortion movement. But during a stay that lasted several month, he wa arrested on Federal charge of blocking access to a Rochester health clinic where abortion were performed. He wa later convicted and served two and a half month in prison. During the protest outside the clinic, he and several other protester locked themselves in a homemade contraption called the oven, made of cement and iron. It took police officer several hour to lug the device to a horse trailer that carted it off. At the same protest, one man glued his head to a lock on a gate surrounding the clinic, a move some protester later said wa an accident. Abortion opponent like Mrs. Hayes and Mrs. Quinn speak of attending peaceful observance at abortion clinic and offering prayer for the unborn. They talk about counseling woman about alternative to abortion at Roman Catholic pregnancy center, and their support of anti-abortion candidate. But they also say they saw nothing wrong with Weslin trying to block access to clinic. They describe the activity a peaceful resistance meant to stop what they see a murder. Weslin and the other house guest of Mrs. Hayes and Mrs. Quinn come recommended from friend and member of local Catholic church, they said, adding that most are speaker at local church or anti-abortion event. And although they say they would never take into their home a stranger wanted by the FBI, like Kopp, they concede that they sometimes know little about their guest. But Mrs. Hayes and Mrs. Quinn say they know a lot about Weslin. An Army veteran, he ha been a leader of the anti-abortion movement for more than 25 year, they say, and founded a home for unwed mother. Mrs. Hayes said that when she met him, it wa obvious he wa a man of peace who had a tremendous devotion to the Blessed Mother and basically recognized that we are helpless lamb. Barbara Fredericks, another local abortion opponent who developed tie to the Lambs after Weslin came to town, added that the priest epitomized a man of God. I just knew when I looked at his holy shoe and his simple coat that had been mended 50 time, she said. He wa humble, a man who wa doing this for a higher purpose, trying to save people through sacrifice and prayer. opp also ha robust defender among the people who housed him a he rode about the country from protest to protest. E. Kenny, 20, said that his parent housed Kopp in their St. Albans, Vt., home for two year after he spoke at their local church in 1988. During Kopp's stay, he wa a pleasure, Kenny said, always helping around the house. He wa a nice guy, kind of like an uncle to u, Kenny said. He'd sit around and play video game with u and make u model plane out of wood. Like Weslin, Kopp wa consumed by a need to fight abortion and often talked about it evil, Kenny said, adding that Kopp wa a gentle man who wanted to become a Catholic priest. He wa always in a good mood, Kenny said. He never did anything violent at all. Both Kopp and Weslin have been arrested repeatedly during abortion protest. The men have moved in the same circle and at time found themselves arrested at the same event. Mrs. Quinn said that Weslin told her in a recent telephone conversation that he knew Kopp. Weslin could not be reached for comment, but it is clear that the two men have encountered each other. Both faced misdemeanor charge after blocking a Burlington, Vt., health clinic in 1990 that Kopp called the mill. And they spent time in the same jail in Atlanta in 1988 after a clinic protest. Slepian's death ha abortion opponent like Mrs. Hayes and Mrs. Quinn worried, both about how the killing is being portrayed in the medium and what it will do to membership in group like the Lambs of Christ. For a long time, you felt like the voice in the desert that wasn't being heard, Mrs. Hayes said. And then there wa this horrible tragedy of this doctor's death becoming the face of the movement. We're about saving life, she said. The FBI ha not talked to Mrs. Hayes, but Kenny said that agent have spoken to him. Mrs. Hayes looked at her 3-month-old daughter, Bernadette, then pointed to the prenatal image of the infant, a sonogram taken at 13 week that she keep on her refrigerator door. data: Top-level budget negotiator for congressional Republicans and the White House concluded yet another bargaining session late Sunday afternoon with plan to resume talk on Monday morning and probably extend their midnight Monday deadline for another day or two. Both side were amiable a they emerged from a two-hour session, but they had little to report and indicated that their relatively early departure, compared with the last three night, should not be interpreted a a sign of crisis or of imminent peace in the budget talk. Sunday's discussion focused on education and President Clinton's request for $1.1 billion to hire 100,000 teacher, but aide said the bargainer did not delve into much detail and nothing wa resolved. I think we made some real progress today, but we still have a significant difference in the area of education, said Erskine Bowles, Clinton's chief of staff and top negotiator, after Sunday's meeting. We're going to try to plow through that over the next two day. Asked how far apart the two side were on education, Rep. Dick Armey of Texas, the Republican majority leader, replied: I don't know. We're not together. He said the two side had made some progress, but not enough. The talk came during another day of escalated political confrontation a congressional Democrats and Republicans, painfully aware that they have three week until Election Day, tried to take advantage of the static budget situation. Congress ha passed only six of the 13 required spending bill and are negotiating now with the White House on a final omnibus package that will contain the remaining seven bill and major issue including how to conduct the census in the year 2000, how much money to provide the International Monetary Fund and under what condition it should be provided, and how much emergency money to provide for item like increased security at US. embassy around the world and for American farmer. Also to be resolved are a host of issue that have little to do with financing and more to do with ideology, including environmental matter, contraception and national student testing. Republicans said the president had been disengaged from the process, and they were irked at what they said wa his swooping in at the 11th hour and pushing his education agenda in an apparently successful portrayal of himself a the guardian of that popular topic. Democrats countered that the Republican-led Congress had done nothing all year, and cast the Republicans a extremist for blocking the president's plea for more money to hire teacher and modernize school. In fact, Republican bargainer said Saturday night that they would provide the money if local government, not Washington, could decide how the money would be used. Armey wa one of many who castigated the president for apparent disengagement, an indirect reminder that Clinton ha been steeped in a sex scandal and is facing an impeachment inquiry in the House. The scant number of congressional Republicans who did not leave town for the weekend used the House floor to press this same message. What about the president? asked Rep. Tom DeLay of Texas, the majority whip. Maybe in Martha's Vineyard? Aspen? Camp David? Where is the president? I bet the American people don't know that he spent 152 day out of the 283 day this year fund raising, traveling and on vacation. Republicans said that Clinton had participated in 98 fund-raising event so far this year and that two event on Monday in New York, supporting the Senate campaign of Rep. Charles Schumer, would bring him to 100. A sticking point for White House and congressional budget negotiator ha been the issue of how the 2000 census will be conducted, and the White House is finding itself negotiating on the issue a much with House Democrats a it is with the House Republican leader. On Monday, White House negotiator, led by chief of staff Erskine Bowles, tried to determine whether Democrats would accept a deal to finance for six month the department of State, Justice and Commerce, which oversees the Census Bureau. Bowles told the group of Democrats that the House Republicans were willing to give on a number of outstanding issue that were stalling final agreement on the budget, but that they were digging in their heel when it came to financing the census for six month. The Democrats met in the office of Minority Leader Dick Gephardt. The rationale for the half-year financing is that by next March the Supreme Court is expected to rule on whether using sampling is legal or constitutional. The Supreme Court ha already agreed to review two lower court ruling that said sampling would violate federal law. Oral argument on the case are set for November. But House Democrats balked at the idea of six months' financing for the census, arguing that even if the Supreme Court allowed sampling, the Republicans would be under no obligation to approve money for a census that included sampling. The general feeling among many Democrats wa that even if we won the case, there would be a lot le leverage in March, especially if it wa the only issue left to be debated, said a House Democratic official who insisted on anonymity. Democrats contend that now is the time to press the Republicans, while they want to complete work on the budget and go home to campaign. Rep. Lucille Roybal-Allard, D-Calif., who attended the meeting Monday, said, It wa, sort of, this is where we are. We've been able to accomplish great thing, what do you think? We made it very clear that unless the census wa included, along with some other issue, like school construction, the deal wouldn't be acceptable. Statistical sampling would allow the Census Bureau to estimate population that are difficult to count, and would have the largest effect on the counting of African-Americans in city and black and Hispanics in rural area, group that are traditionally undercounted by the standard mean. Republicans fear, and Democrats hope, that the method would raise the count of people living in traditionally Democratic area, giving the party an advantage when new boundary for election district are drawn following the 2000 census. At Monday's meeting, the Democrats reminded administration official that Clinton had promised that he would veto any legislation that restricted the Census Bureau's ability to conduct an accurate census. I can't think of any way that restricts the census more than not to fully fund it, said Rep. Carolyn Maloney, D-NY. The willingness of House Democrats, including Gephardt, to press the president on the issue represents a realization of their leverage with Clinton, who will need all of their support in the coming impeachment inquiry. Gephardt is a major player now, and the irony is we helped make him that, said Rep. Christopher Shays, R-Conn., who support the use of sampling in the census. The Democrats' position also indicates how little trust many have in the White House on this issue. The proposal to finance the department of Commerce, Justice and State for six month is similar to one reached last November between Bowles and House Speaker Newt Gingrich. The idea then wa that holding all three department hostage in the census fight would place maximum pressure on all side to work out their difference over sampling. But House Democrats were not consulted before that agreement wa struck and later grumbled about it. At a meeting of the Democratic caucus Tuesday, Ms. Maloney briefed lawmaker on dealing with the White House and declared that Clinton had promised that he would hold firm on the census and that she believed him, a participant said.
