House and Senate negotiator agreed Thursday to require most federal health plan to cover prescription contraceptive for woman, giving an unusual victory on Capitol Hill to advocate of abortion right. But the future of the measure wa in doubt because it wa attached to a spending bill that includes a controversial provision regarding the Federal Election Commission. That provision could scuttle the spending bill, which would finance the Treasury Department and the Postal Service and which still must be approved by the House and Senate. The contraceptive measure would require the federal health plan, which affect 1.2 million female federal employee who are of child-bearing age, to cover the five method of contraception that have been approved by the Food and Drug Administration for use in this country birth control pill, diaphragm, inter-uterine device, Norplant and Depo-Provera. Currently, only 19 percent of federal health plan cover those method. The House and Senate approved the contraceptive measure earlier this year. But the opponent of abortion were furious about the approval and persuaded Republican leader to have negotiator reopen discussion on the matter. The cost of contraceptive ha driven up the out-of-pocket cost of health care for woman. And many male member of Congress seemed persuaded to support coverage of contraceptive for woman, since almost all of the 285 federal health plan cover Viagra, the male impotency drug. Thursday, with pressure building to resolve the spending bill before Oct. 9, when temporary financing of the government expires, the negotiator agreed to include the contraceptive measure in their conference report on the $13.4 billion bill for the Treasury Department and Postal service. Rep. Nita Lowey, D-N.Y., who pushed the contraceptive measure through the House, hailed Thursday's agreement a the first major accomplishment by abortion right advocate since the Republicans took control of Congress in 1994. She said the negotiator had agreed to include the measure because in an election year they did not want to be perceived a opposing contraception or be seen a rejecting a measure that had passed both the House and Senate. But many Democrats said the were upset that the bill contains a provision that is seen a interfering with the independence of the Federal Election Commission. That provision would require a four-vote majority among the seven federal election commissioner every four year to retain the general counsel and staff director. The provision is aimed at getting rid of Lawrence Noble, the current general counsel, who ha investigated the campaign finance practice of group like the Christian Coalition. The contraceptive measure is one of four related matter that have helped stall four spending bill. The three other bill that are stalled in part because of abortion-related matter include the agriculture bill, in which there is a dispute over whether the federal Food and Drug Administration should use taxpayer money to approve drug like RU-486, which induce abortion. The foreign operation bill is also stalled over whether to finance international family planning program that may also promote abortion, while the labor and health bill is delayed because of a provision that would block access of minor to contraception. Addressing the measure on insurance coverage for contraceptive, Helen Alvarez, a spokeswoman for the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, said that the bill wa bad policy. She said contraception had failed to stem the number of abortion, teen-age pregnancy or out-of-wedlock birth. Public-relations-wise, it's a good tactic for them, she conceded, but in term of social policy, this is a failure. For the first time in decade, Congress and the White House negotiated tax and spending legislation this year with the budget in surplus. The result wa chaos. The lawmaker were never able to agree on a budget resolution the framework into which all the tax and spending bill are supposed to fit. This had not happened since congressional budget procedure were established in 1974. Then, without the discipline of such an overall plan, the Senate and the House could not pas eight of the 13 spending bill needed to keep the government running. So the lawmaker had to stay in session more than a week longer than they had hoped. Finally, they lumped all eight bill together this week and announced an agreement. But the only way they could get this far wa to resort to gimmick. One wa to designate $20 billion a emergency expenditure so that program did not have to be cut elsewhere to offset the new spending. This will use up more than one-quarter of the anticipated budget surplus in the current fiscal year. Another gimmick extended the tax break for Individual Retirement Accounts to couple with income from $100,000 to $150,000. This will actually raise a small amount of revenue in the next five year the period covered by budget accounting but it will make the picture considerably worse in later year. As hard a it wa to negotiate a budget in the bad old day of budget deficit, say the politician involved, it wa exponentially more difficult this year. At least in year past, there wa a common goal. As much a they disagreed on policy and principle, they were all aiming at a reduction in the deficit. This year, some member of Congress wanted to use the surplus for a big tax cut. Others wanted to pay off the national debt. Others wanted to spend part of it on medical research, school and weapon for the Pentagon. Others wanted to spend large sum on highway. Still others wanted to continue cutting government spending. And that wa just among the Republicans. The Democrats had their own idea about the budget, and President Clinton laid down his marker about saving the surplus until a way wa found to shore up the Social Security system. In budget term, said Robert Reischauer, a former director of the congressional budget office, this is like the end of the Cold War. There are other difference a well in the way thing were negotiated with the budget in a surplus. In 1990, 1993 and 1995, when politician staked their career on striking a budget deal to lower the deficit, the fundamental question wa how to divide up the bitter medicine of more tax and le spending. Republicans, for the most part, opposed tax increase and favored cutting spending on social program. Democrats wanted to raise tax, especially on the rich, and protect social spending. In the end, balance were carefully drawn. But plenty of politician President George Bush, to name one lost their job in the process. This year, with Democrats and Republicans alike claiming victory, the burning issue wa how to parcel out the candy. Democrats got more money for education and farm assistance. Republicans got more money for the military and an extension of popular tax break for business. Some of the $20 billion that will eat into the surplus really will go for emergency, like relief for victim of Hurricane Georges. But much of the money, like the $90 million that will pay for six new helicopter for the national police in Colombia to use in drug interdiction, wa designated emergency spending simply because there wa no other way to get it into the budget. For the politician, the new way is more fun. It is hard to imagine that anyone will be voted out of office because of this year's budget. But that did not make it easier to reach an agreement. The other big difference is that the principal fight this year were not over money at all. They involved delicate policy issue like needle exchange, contraception, global warming, immigration and the census. In Congress, there is no consensus on these matter. So the only way policy could be set wa to wrap them into the giant spending bill. It may be more pleasant to debate policy than money. But it is probably harder to find a way to split the difference. As long a the surplus last, the lack of discipline that characterized the budget-writing this year is likely to continue. This is distressing to those devoted to controlling government spending. The temptation, said L. Ari Fleischer, spokesman for the House Ways and Means Committee, is to grab the loot and spend it. Some conservative sounded note of discord Friday over the federal spending agreement, but they also said they would probably vote for the $500 billion package because it boosted defense spending and provided aid to farmer. However, no one can vote on the package just yet, because it is not finished. The deal that President Clinton and Republican leader hailed Thursday wa a broad outline of area of agreement on the final portion of the $1.7 trillion budget, not a written document. That is now being crafted by the chairman of the spending committee and their aide, who said Friday that there were still dispute that needed to be resolved and that the final document could run to more than 3,000 page. For example, still unresolved is a dispute over whether airline can create a peanut-free zone to protect passenger who are allergic to peanut. House Speaker Newt Gingrich and other member from Georgia, a major peanut-producing state, are fighting the proposal, which would force airline to ban peanut within three row of someone with an allergy. Congress gave itself until midnight Tuesday to vote on the final bill, agreeing with President Clinton to a fifth extension of temporary financing to keep the government open. The budget wa due Oct. 1, the start of the new fiscal year. The vote wa initially expected Friday, but the bill is nowhere near to being written. Only a handful of top-level bargainer including Gingrich, Senate Majority Leader Trent Lott and White House chief of staff Erskine Bowles were in the room for the final deal. Excluded were the committee chairman and the head of the appropriation committee, who now must write the language that will put the deal into law. Almost everyone on Capitol Hill expects the budget to pas eventually, with the biggest defection coming from conservative who object to the $20 billion taken from the surplus to address so-called emergency and for the package's failure to offer voter a serious tax cut. The lag time before the bill is officially closed is making some conservative nervous that more member will try to add provision that will further expand a bill they already consider overly bloated. And some worry that once the hometown pork that is stuffed into the bill is publicly revealed, voter could put pressure on member not to support it. The election are Nov. 3. But several conservative said that despite these problem, they expected to support the bill anyway. Rep. Mark Souder, R-Ind., said: `Most of my friend, who are predominantly activist conservative, are split about 50-50. If tax cut were your primary thing, then you're unhappy, but many conservative have a mixed agenda. My position is, hold the nose and vote yes. We have no tax cut and far too much spending that I oppose, but that's the nature of compromise. Every member ha a little different focus. Souder said he liked the extra money for defense spending, and he liked the price support for farmer. Hog farmer in his district, whose biggest customer were Japan and China, had been hit hard by the collapse of Asian market. Several Republicans said that the bill seemed skewed in favor of the Democrats. Clinton wa buying vote, said Rep. David Hobson, R-Ohio. He wa sucking up to the liberal Democrats so they would support him in impeachment. Rep. WJ. (Billy) Tauzin, R-La., said the leader seemed motivated by a desire to avoid the political damage they incurred from the partial government shutdown of 1995 and 1996. He also cited the president's need to placate the left by adding costly domestic program. The combination of the lesson learned three year ago and the scandal on the president's side yielded the inevitable result, a budget that lean way to the left, Tauzin said. Still, he said he would probably support the bill. It won't be enthusiastically, he said. It won't be holding my nose either. I would have preferred to spend more of this money on a tax cut. I think we would have gotten a tax cut, but for the scandal. Voting mainly on party line on a question that ha become a touchstone in the debate over development and preservation of wilderness, the Senate on Thursday approved a gravel road through remote wildlife habitat in Alaska. The road, barely 30 mile long, would slice across the edge of a wildlife refuge and wilderness area on the Aleutian Peninsula, where it would connect an isolated village called King Cove to a long-range air strip in the town of Cold Bay. Without the road, it backer say, about 700 resident of King Cove must continue to use unreliable air and boat service in emergency, often risking dangerous wind and sea a they seek medical evacuation to Anchorage. Opponents of the road call the project an unjustifiable precedent that threatens the seasonal breeding ground of protected migratory bird, and they say that improved air or sea service would be a better alternative. The vote Thursday, 59-38, wa a victory for the state's congressional delegation. But with President Clinton likely to veto the measure, the final outcome may depend on whether it sponsor can insert the road proposal into a huge spending bill that is likely to emerge just before Congress head home for the Nov. 3 election. Three Republicans voted against the bill, and six Democrats voted for it. The Clinton administration ha repeatedly warned that it will veto a big spending bill if it contains an array of anti-environmental provision that are under consideration. Indeed, the White House seems to be itching for a partisan fight over environmental priority. But while many Republicans in Congress still appear reluctant to engage in that broad fight, they were willing Thursday to cast their lot with the Senate's two powerful Alaskans, Ted Stevens and Frank Murkowski, both Republicans. A companion bill in the House, sponsored by Rep. Don Young of Alaska, also a Republican, ha not come to the floor. Even Sen. John Chafee of Rhode Island, a leader of Republican environmentalist, voted for the road. Last February Chafee's staff had assembled a score of environmental lobbyist in his office to plan strategy for opposing the road, environmental advocate said Thursday. They speculated that the senator had changed his position out of deference to the power of Stevens, who a chairman of the Appropriations Committee exerts tremendous influence at a time when a dozen spending bill are in their final stage. A Chafee aide said Chafee voted reluctantly for the road after Alaska's senator convinced him of it merit. Stevens said in angry tone Thursday that two-thirds of Alaska's land wa off limit to development and that vital health service were being denied to his state's resident. We can't use it without permission from some bureaucrat who is compelled by extreme environmentalist, he said. They are so extreme that they say this 330,000-acre Izembek refuge, the smallest wilderness in Alaska, is so sacrosanct that it can't move it border 60 foot. But Sen. Dale Bumpers, D-Ark., called the road project a dangerous precedent. An Act to Protect Trade And Commerce Against Unlawful Restraints and Monopolies: Section 1. Every contract, combination in the form of trust or otherwise, or conspiracy, in restraint of trade or commerce among the several States, or with foreign nation, is hereby declared to be illegal. The case of United States v. Microsoft Corp., the government's most aggressive move against a monopolist in almost 25 year, is playing out against a century of antitrust law so broadly worded and court ruling so ambiguous that both side are citing the same ruling to support their opposing argument. Whatever the outcome of the trial, scheduled to begin Monday in US. District Court in Washington, an almost certain appeal will leave to the Supreme Court the task of bringing legal order to 100 year of clashing antitrust doctrine. The case focus on Microsoft's Windows, the operating system that control about 90 percent of all personal computer sold today. The government say it objective is to curb illegal monopolistic business practice that threaten to render large part of the economy vulnerable to the vicissitude of a single company. Microsoft asserts that the case is intended to give the government control over which feature can be added to Windows. However grand the economic stake, the legal dispute is narrow. The government say that Microsoft's contract with computer manufacturer and with company that provide access to the Internet illegally stifle competition. The contract prohibit manufacturer from substituting Netscape Communications Corp.'s Navigator browser for Microsoft's Internet Explorer. They also prohibit them from removing from the Windows main screen, or desktop, link to site on the World Wide Web run by Microsoft or it partner. Microsoft's contract with company that connect people to the Internet and with business that sell good and service on the Web require favored treatment for Internet Explorer over Navigator in exchange for link on the Windows desktop. In the wake of the lawsuit, Microsoft ha voluntarily dropped some of these requirement, though it could reinstate them at will. Microsoft say that it contract are legal because they produce tangible benefit for customer, including easier Internet access. The Justice Department say that the bundling of Explorer with Windows 95 and the inclusion of the browser a part of Windows 98 amount to tying, an illegal practice that force customer of one product to purchase another. The contract with manufacturer and Internet service are illegal, the government say, because they are intended not only to create a monopoly in the browser market but to protect Microsoft's existing monopoly in operating system. The latter threat is key, according to the Justice Department. Browsers have the potential, like an operating system, to act a a software platform on which other program run. So contract intended to drive browser out of the market would also insulate the Windows monopoly. Many antitrust expert say the problem facing the Justice Department is that the court have provided no clear definition of tying and no clear guideline for determining when contract are illegally exclusionary. Professor Lawrence White of New York University, who wa chief economist of the Justice Department's antitrust division in the early 1980s, say that the court treat tying a an unusual practice when in fact it is ubiquitous. No one, he said, would challenge the right of manufacturer to tie eraser to the tip of pencil, tire to an automobile or button to shirt. His point, shared widely among economist, is that some tying benefit consumer if, for example, it result in product that are easier to use or enables a company to recover development cost. But tying can be bad if it lock in monopoly power. The court, White say, have not offered enough guidance for distinguishing good tying from bad, which is the nub of the legal dispute. Microsoft say it need only to show that bundling Windows and Explorer pass what might be called a gross consumer benefit test that it offer an immediate benefit, whether or not it cause long-term damage to competition and, therefore, ultimately to consumer. The Justice Department say that Microsoft's practice must clear a higher hurdle: yielding net consumer benefit that are immediate and large enough to balance possible long-term harm to competition. So which test of consumer benefit satisfies antitrust law? The simple answer is that no one know for sure, which is why both side can reasonably cite the same case without fear of embarrassment. Consider a 1985 case, Aspen Skiing Co. v. Aspen Highlands Skiing Corp., and a 1951 case, Lorain Journal Co. v. United States. In the first, Aspen Skiing, the owner of three major ski run in Aspen, Colo. the monopolist had for year sold a ticket in cooperation with Aspen Highlands, a competitor, that gave skier access to both companies' run. When Aspen Skiing unilaterally canceled the agreement, it rival's revenue shriveled and the rival sued. The Supreme Court ruled that Aspen Skiing had violated antitrust law because there wa no evidence it action helped consumer. In the Lorain Journal case, the only local newspaper in Lorain, Ohio, refused to sell advertising to company that advertised on a new radio station. Here, too, the Supreme Court ruled that the exclusionary practice did nothing to benefit consumer. Indeed, in Aspen Skiing, the court even forced the monopolist to do business with it rival, a precedent that augur well for the Justice Department, which seek to force Microsoft to install Netscape's browser alongside it own. But Charles Rule, a legal consultant to Microsoft, say that in both case the court threw out exclusionary practice only because they offered no consumer benefit. The court, he argues, never pounced on practice that resulted in lower price or better product or service. Nor did the court in either case call for balancing immediate benefit against hypothetical long-term harm. Rule argues that Microsoft's practice produce demonstrable consumer benefit. Besides, he say, unlike the action taken by The Lorain Journal or Aspen Skiing, Microsoft's contract do not prevent consumer from installing Netscape's browser or from using the Web site of Microsoft's rival. In truth, though, neither case answered what consumer benefit test should apply to product design. In Jefferson Parish Hospital District No. 2 et al. v. Hyde, another case cited by both side, the Supreme Court in 1984 recognized that surgeon and anesthesiologist provide an integrated service. Yet, the court said, a hospital with monopoly power would still not be allowed to force surgical patient to use it panel of anesthesiologist if consumer wanted to purchase the two service separately. That principle could undercut Microsoft's defense that the functional interdependence of Windows and Explorer requires bundling. But Microsoft will point to a strong concurring opinion that called for a tougher standard for the government to meet when it alleges tying. Microsoft will also draw support from several court ruling that allowed IBM to change the design of it computer in way that made it hard for vendor to attach peripheral equipment. But perhaps Microsoft's best argument is that nowhere ha the government identified a single case in which the court explicitly called for throwing out a tied product on the basis of a balancing test. The court, Microsoft will emphasize, steer clear of redesigning technically sophisticated product. The Justice Department's rejoinder is to note that the sole purpose of antitrust law is to protect consumer, so it make no sense to bless practice that provide a dollar's worth of benefit today but, by stamping out competition, drive price up by $1,000 tomorrow. The Justice Department will ask the court to at least insist that monopolist use the least exclusionary mean possible to achieve whatever service they provide customer. Experts agree that the court will subject Microsoft's restrictive contract with Internet company to a balancing test. A balancing test would have the court weigh the immediate benefit to consumer of one-click access to Internet site and of feature of a bundled Windows-Explorer package versus the harm over time of diminished competition in the market for browser and operating system. Under this standard, a contract is illegal only if it is intended to drive out competition and thus to pave the way for a monopolist to raise price later. Microsoft will have an easier time defending itself against a charge of predation, which amount to victimizing it customer, than it would defending itself against a charge that it bundled product doe consumer slightly more harm than good. But mostly it strengthened the hand of those within the Justice Department who had been urging that the case be broadened, according to people who have worked on the investigation. At the same time, they say, new evidence wa coming in a the investigation moved ahead and prosecutor raced to meet the accelerated trial schedule approved by the court. Speed wa a priority from the outset, they say. The Justice Department and the state filed their suit in May to move before Microsoft's new operating system, Windows 98, wa introduced in June. While not seeking to block the release of Windows 98, government lawyer wanted to get to the the courtroom a early a possible a PC maker and computer user adopt this latest version of Microsoft's Windows operating system, which function a the central nervous system for more than 90 percent of personal computer sold. The key allegation, government lawyer note, have not changed since May namely, that Microsoft illegally used it market power in operating system to defend it monopoly position and to try to extend into new market. But the only thing that wa wrapped up in a bow in time for the May filing wa the browser, said one person who worked on the case. The real game plan wa always to get a broader case. What is more, one person noted, the prosecution team wa not at full strength until shortly before the suit wa filed. David Boies, a renowned courtroom litigator and a former partner at Cravath, Swaine & Moore who successfully defended IBM in it 13-year confrontation with the government, wa named a special counsel for the Justice Department last December. But Boies, who left Cravath last year, did not start working full-time for the Justice Department until mid-April, because he wa still finishing private case for his own firm, Boies & Schiller. The antitrust suit filed in May leaned heavily on the Netscape story, mentioning Microsoft's main rival in the browser market some 130 time in the complaint and a supporting memorandum. But it also prominently mentioned Microsoft's tactic against Sun Microsystems, creator of Java, an Internet programming language, and cited it a an example of Microsoft's behavior. It wa crafted a a template that could be added to without much stretching, one person involved in the case said. And so, a new evidence piled up and seemed to fit into a pattern, Klein step by step approved the widening of the case, the person said. And that explains, the person continued, how it is that evidence that ha been in the hand of the Justice Department for year ha been added to the case since May; only after gathering new evidence did it become apparent that the older material fit the pattern of the current case. For example, the government ha added the contention that Microsoft pressured Intel Corp., the big microchip maker and a close partner of Microsoft, to curb it development effort in multimedia and Internet software because they might conflict with Microsoft's plan. The government contends that the arm-twisting occurred at meeting between the two company three year ago, especially one on Aug. 2, 1995, which wa attended by Andrew Grove, the Intel chairman, and Bill Gates, the Microsoft chairman. Part of the government's evidence in the Intel-Microsoft episode is copy of the handwritten note taken by Steven McGeady, an Intel vice president who attended the meeting, and a memo written by him on Aug. 28, 1995. The memo, still under court seal, said that Gates made vague threat and wa livid about Intel's investment in the Internet and wanted them stopped. A handwritten note, also under court seal, quote Paul Maritz, a Microsoft executive, a saying that Netscape is their common enemy and that Intel's role should be to fill in stuff in and around Microsoft's strategy. These document were sent by Intel to the Justice Department's office in San Francisco in November 1995, in response to a Civil Investigative Demand a civil subpoena served on Intel on Nov. 10, 1995. On it own, the Intel material wa intriguing, but it became part of the antitrust suit only a other evidence surfaced, one person close to the case said. The government is contending that Microsoft also tried to urge Apple to stop selling it Quicktime multimedia software in the Windows market and tried to convince Real Networks Inc. to pull back in the market for so-called streaming software. The government case ha also broadened, people involved in the case say, a more witness from the industry have been increasingly willing to testify. In the beginning, most people in the industry believed that the government would lose and Microsoft would retaliate if they came forward, one person said. But a the strength of our case wa perceived to improve, more people were willing to come forward, and thing snowballed. You get Intel, it's easier to get Apple and so on.

data: Lebanon's Parliament on Tuesday ratified a constitutional amendment to clear the way for the election of the army's commander, Gen. Emile Lahoud, a president. Lahoud ha received the backing of Syria, the main power broker in the country, making the election by Lebanon's pro-Syrian Parliament later this week just a formality. A total of 113 deputy voted for the amendment and four deputy against, including the general's cousin, Nassib Lahoud, a presidential aspirant. Eleven deputy were absent. Among those who were absent wa Walid Jumblatt, a Cabinet minister who had said he would boycott the session to protest the choice of a military man even though Lahoud ha wide public and political support. The 128-member legislature is expected to meet Thursday to elect Lahoud after outgoing President Elias Hrawi sign the constitutional amendment. The amendment to Article 49 of the constitution revoke a ban on senior civil servant from running for the presidency. The new president will be sworn in Nov. 24, the day Hrawi leaf office. Hrawi ha served for nine year, including a three-year extension in 1995 to his six-year term. Lahoud, a Maronite Catholic, will keep alive a 55-year-old tradition under which the president is a Maronite, the prime minister a Sunni Muslim and the Parliament speaker a Shiite Muslim. Lahoud, appointed army commander in 1989 amid a rebellion in the fractured military during the 1975-90 civil war, is credited with rebuilding the 55,000-strong Lebanese army and in ending the reign of militia. Many hope he will copy his success with the military in the government, which is plagued by nepotism and waste of public fund. But some fear of military dominance of public life. Prime Minister Rafik Hariri ha declined an informal invitation from Lebanon's new president to form the next government, sparking a political crisis in this country a it rebuilds from it devastating civil war. Sources close to the prime minister, whose Cabinet ha been in care-taker capacity since last Tuesday's swearing in of Emile Lahoud a president, said Hariri turned down the invitation from Lahoud to select a new Cabinet. There ha been no formal announcement from Lahoud reappointing Hariri a prime minister. Although Hariri's move could be a bargaining tactic, since he remains the front-runner for the premiership, the apparent tension between the two powerful men could affect Lebanon's economic stability a it recovers from the 1975-90 civil war. Hariri, 53, the architect of Lebanon's multibillion dollar postwar reconstruction program, ha been in power since 1992. A billionaire businessman who made his fortune in Saudi Arabia, Hariri is credited with restoring economic confidence and stabilizing the national currency. Lahoud, 62, commander of Lebanon's army who wa propelled to power with widespread popular backing, pledged in a tough inauguration speech to clean up the graft-riddled administration. The British-trained general made his name rebuilding the army after it disintegrated in the civil war. Previous dispute among government leader have cost the Central Bank hundred of million of dollar in it effort to stabilize the Lebanese pound. Such political dispute in Lebanon in the past were solved only with the intervention of Syria, the main power broker in this country. Damascus support both Lahoud and Hariri. Lahoud had been expected to issue a presidential decree last week asking Hariri to form the next government. The decree wa to be issued after the president polled member of the 128-seat Parliament on their choice for prime minister. But many legislator, who in the past gave their overwhelming support to Hariri, did not name him and, instead, left it to the president to select a prime minister. The two leader met Friday, but no presidential decree followed. The source close to Hariri, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the prime minister's decision to bow out came because he did not feel Lahoud wa following constitutional procedure in selecting the premier. The Hariri camp argues that the president can poll Parliament member on their choice for prime minister but cannot accept a mandate to name a person of his choice. The dispute, in fact, appears to be the opening salvo of a struggle on how Lebanon will be governed during Lahoud's six-year term. Toward the end of former President Elias Hrawi's nine year in office, Hariri virtually had a free hand in running the country. Parliament on Thursday formally elected Gen. Emile Lahoud, the popular army commander who ha the backing of powerful neighbor Syria, a Lebanon's next president. All the 118 legislator present at the session cast vote in his favor. Lahoud is to be sworn for a six-year term on Nov. 24, the day President Elias Hrawi leaf office.
